Moreover, such requirements are unlikely to discourage excessive consumption of alcoholic beverages.  Let's place at least a small amount of responsibility on adult consumers for their decisions. This industry is already being squeezed by insurance premiums, taxes, and regulations.'}]
comment_text: The cost of implementing such detailed labeling information will quickly drive the small producers out of the market. Moreover, such requirements are unlikely to discourage excessive consumption of alcoholic beverages.  Let's place at least a small amount of responsibility on adult consumers for their decisions. This industry is already being squeezed by insurance premiums, taxes, and regulations.
document_title: Notice No. 237:  Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages

comment_text_sources:
[{'source': 'DIRECT (NON-ATTACHMENT)', 'text': 'Health Risks of Alcohol Consumption:
Road traffic accidents are a pressing public health issue in the US, with 32 people dying of
automobile crashes each year, involving alcohol impaired driving, accounting for one death in every
45 minutes. According to National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA), driving
under influence deaths were highest among young individuals aged 21 to 24 yrs (29%) and 25-34
yrs (28%). Excessive consumption of alcohol causes 178,000 deaths each year in the US, and
leads to chronic heart and liver diseases, stroke, digestive issues, cancer, and a weakened immune
system. It has also caused a shorter life span, leading individuals to die by an average of 24
years. Effective regulations like TTB-2025-0002 can help reduce deaths by making people
choose to limit their alcohol consumption.
Evidence-Based Impact of Labelling Alcoholic Beverages:
According to Vasiljevic, M. et al. (2018), a randomized controlled trial found that when
alcoholic beverages are labeled with clear information about Alcohol by Volume (ABV), and
amount of pure alcohol content per serving, individuals aged 18-40 years, social and non-
dependent drinkers are significantly less likely to select high strength drinks. These findings show
quantitative labels of alcoholic drinks reduce the appeal of strong alcoholic beverages
especially among individuals with low literacy levels about the risks of alcohol consumption, and
groups that are at an elevated risk of binge drinking and impaired driving. Another study done
by Center for Science in the Public Interest (CSPI), conducted a national survey with the aim to
receive consumer’s opinion about transparency in labeling alcoholic beverages with information
such as calories, serving size, nutritional content, and alcohol content, that are a part of the
regulation, TTB-2025-0002, along with other alcohol facts. The sample for the survey was
nationally representative of US adults from all demographics. This study found that 63% to
77% of respondents supported policies that required the inclusion of nutrition and alcohol content
information on the labels of alcoholic beverages, either somewhat or strongly. Whereas, 72% to
90% of respondents supported having more information on the labels, as it would impact their
choice to purchase alcohol. A systematic review done in the UK also shows moderate evidence
of labeling calories and ABV on purchasing choices of consumers, showing increased preference
for alcoholic beverages with calorie count labels, and a reduction in the purchase of high-calorie
alcohol. While there is not much research done on evaluating the direct impact of labeling on
“Driving While Intoxicated” (DWI) and alcohol related health issues among people in the US,
The above evidence-based research shows the psychological impact of labelling on consumers
purchasing and alcoholic beverage choices based on content, which in turn suggests an increase in
consumer awareness about alcohol risks and a reduction in driving under the influence and health
issue prevalence due to alcohol consumption. While labeling alcoholic beverages alone
cannot eliminate the issue of impaired driving, it can be a valuable evidence-informed strategy to
complement other policy tools such as age limits, taxes, and enforcement to help people make
Informed health choices.
Addressing Health Equity:
Standardized “Alcohol Facts” panel on labels of alcoholic beverages would be an equitable and
low-cost strategy in bridging the information gap.10 Rural and low-income communities often lack
access to resources and education. Labeling helps people from all socioeconomic and
educational backgrounds stay informed about alcohol risks through clear information on labels of
alcoholic beverages.12 If standardized labels are not clearly presented, it would perpetuate a lack of
access to resources and education about alcohol risks among communities, causing them to face
alcohol-related health issues.
Recommendations:
Integrating linguistic competency in the labels would help communities that don’t have literacy
in English understand the information on the labels. Having alcohol facts panels on labels in
different commonly spoken languages in the US would help people understand it and make
informed health choices.'}]

issue prevalence due to alcohol consumption. While labeling alcoholic beverages alone
cannot eliminate the issue of impaired driving, it can be a valuable evidence-informed strategy to
complement other policy tools such as age limits, taxes, and enforcement to help people make
Informed health choices.
Addressing Health Equity:
Standardized “Alcohol Facts” panel on labels of alcoholic beverages would be an equitable and
low-cost strategy in bridging the information gap.10 Rural and low-income communities often lack
access to resources and education. Labeling helps people from all socioeconomic and
educational backgrounds stay informed about alcohol risks through clear information on labels of
alcoholic beverages.12 If standardized labels are not clearly presented, it would perpetuate a lack of
access to resources and education about alcohol risks among communities, causing them to face
alcohol-related health issues.
Recommendations:
Integrating linguistic competency in the labels would help communities that don’t have literacy
in English understand the information on the labels. Having alcohol facts panels on labels in
different commonly spoken languages in the US would help people understand it and make
informed health choices.
document_title: Notice No. 237:  Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages

comment_text_sources: [{'source': 'DIRECT (NON-ATTACHMENT)', 'text': 'I am strongly in favor of requiring an alcohol facts statements on alcoholic beverages. I realize there are intricacies involved at the regulatory level since the FDA has authority over food labeling while the TTB has authority over alcohol labeling, but from the perspective of a general citizen, it does not make sense that foods and nonalcoholic beverages are required to declare nutrition facts but alcoholic beverages get a pass. I can understand there are individuals who may not wish to know, producers who may want to use that space for the design of a bottle, etc., but these reasons can seem like excuses to continue keeping consumers in the dark. Consumers do not have to look at the information if they do not want to, and producers are creative enough to find ways to create attractive labels while still being honest with their consumers. Citizens deserve to know the contents of what they purchase and consume, whether alcoholic or not. Additionally, to suggest that this information is already online ignores the matter of accessibility. Information may be available online, but it may not be accurate, and consumers may not know the best way to access it. Decreasing the amount of barriers to information should be seen as a benefit to the consumer, not a drawback.'}]
comment_text: I am strongly in favor of requiring an alcohol facts statements on alcoholic beverages. I realize there are intricacies involved at the regulatory level since the FDA has authority over food labeling while the TTB has authority over alcohol labeling, but from the perspective of a general citizen, it does not make sense that foods and nonalcoholic beverages are required to declare nutrition facts but alcoholic beverages get a pass. I can understand there are individuals who may not wish to know, producers who may want to use that space for the design of a bottle, etc., but these reasons can seem like excuses to continue keeping consumers in the dark. Consumers do not have to look at the information if they do not want to, and producers are creative enough to find ways to create attractive labels while still being honest with their consumers. Citizens deserve to know the contents of what they purchase and consume, whether alcoholic or not. Additionally, to suggest that this information is already online ignores the matter of accessibility. Information may be available online, but it may not be accurate, and consumers may not know the best way to access it. Decreasing the amount of barriers to information should be seen as a benefit to the consumer, not a drawback.
document_title: Notice No. 237:  Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages

comment_text_sources:
[{'source': 'DIRECT (NON-ATTACHMENT)', 'text': "Including sugar or carbohydrate content on alcohol labels, while seemingly informative, could be misleading because it frames sugar/carbs (carbohydrates are a sugar, after all) as the primary concern, overshadowing alcohol’s more profound metabolic and nutritional impacts. It reinforces the false narrative that sugar/carbs are inherently worse, despite being a nutrient essential for survival.

Considered the following:

1. Public Perception: Sugar is Already Vilified
•In recent years, sugar has been intensely demonized in public discourse, largely due to its association with obesity, diabetes, and other metabolic disorders. While these concerns are valid, they have led to a disproportionate fear of sugar compared to other harmful substances, including alcohol.
•If sugar content is prominently displayed on alcohol labels, consumers may incorrectly assume that a lower-sugar alcohol is “healthier,” ignoring the far more harmful effects of alcohol itself.

2. Alcohol’s Unique Metabolic Harm
•The public often views sugar and calories as the main nutritional concerns, but alcohol has effects that far exceed those of sugar. For example:
•Alcohol Suppresses Fat Burning: Even sugar doesn’t impair fat oxidation as dramatically as alcohol does.
•Toxic Byproducts: Alcohol metabolizes into acetaldehyde, a toxin, while sugar breaks down into glucose and fructose, which the body can utilize or store.
•Highlighting sugar content on labels could distract from alcohol’s inherently toxic nature and lead consumers to prioritize sugar levels over the far more significant health risks of alcohol consumption.

3. Alcohol’s “Hidden” Calories and Nutritional Impact
•Alcohol itself is calorically dense (7 calories per gram) and contributes “empty” calories with no nutritional benefit. These calories are metabolically disruptive, regardless of sugar content.
•Low-sugar alcoholic beverages still carry the full burden of alcohol’s toxic and caloric effects, but labeling them as “low sugar” could create a false sense of healthfulness.

4. Misleading Comparisons with Other Beverages
•In soft drinks or juices, sugar content is a key health indicator because sugar is the primary source of calories and metabolic impact. However, in alcoholic beverages, sugar is a secondary factor—alcohol is the primary source of both calories and harm.
•A sugary cocktail may appear “worse” than a low-sugar spirit on paper, but the spirit’s alcohol content will have a far greater negative impact on metabolism and overall health than the sugar in the cocktail.

5. Encourages Misguided Consumer Choices
•If sugar content is emphasized on labels, consumers may be tempted to choose alcoholic beverages with low sugar but higher alcohol content, believing they are making a healthier choice. This could inadvertently encourage higher alcohol consumption, increasing the risk of liver damage, addiction, and other alcohol-related harms.
•For example, a vodka soda with zero sugar may be perceived as “better” than a beer with moderate sugar, even though the metabolic harm from the vodka (due to alcohol content) is significantly greater.

6. Focus Should Be on Alcohol Content
•Alcohol’s harmful effects—on metabolism, hormones, and organ health—are independent of its sugar content. The focus of labeling should remain on alcohol content (e.g., ABV) rather than secondary factors like sugar, to accurately communicate the primary health risks.
•Informing consumers about the risks of alcohol itself, rather than its sugar content, provides a clearer picture of the metabolic harm associated with drinking.

Conclusion

Including sugar content on alcohol labels risks creating a misleading narrative that positions sugar as the primary health concern in alcoholic beverages, downplaying alcohol’s inherently harmful effects. This could lead to misguided consumer choices, encouraging higher alcohol consumption under the guise of reducing sugar intake. To promote metabolic health, public awareness should focus on the dangers of alcohol itself, rather than deflecting attention to sugar.

"}]

Including sugar or carbohydrate content on alcohol labels, while seemingly informative, could be misleading because it frames sugar/carbs (carbohydrates are a sugar, after all) as the primary concern, overshadowing alcohol’s more profound metabolic and nutritional impacts. It reinforces the false narrative that sugar/carbs are inherently worse, despite being a nutrient essential for survival.

Considered the following:

1. Public Perception: Sugar is Already Vilified
•In recent years, sugar has been intensely demonized in public discourse, largely due to its association with obesity, diabetes, and other metabolic disorders. While these concerns are valid, they have led to a disproportionate fear of sugar compared to other harmful substances, including alcohol.
•If sugar content is prominently displayed on alcohol labels, consumers may incorrectly assume that a lower-sugar alcohol is “healthier,” ignoring the far more harmful effects of alcohol itself.

2. Alcohol’s Unique Metabolic Harm
•The public often views sugar and calories as the main nutritional concerns, but alcohol has effects that far exceed those of sugar. For example:
•Alcohol Suppresses Fat Burning: Even sugar doesn’t impair fat oxidation as dramatically as alcohol does.
•Toxic Byproducts: Alcohol metabolizes into acetaldehyde, a toxin, while sugar breaks down into glucose and fructose, which the body can utilize or store.
•Highlighting sugar content on labels could distract from alcohol’s inherently toxic nature and lead consumers to prioritize sugar levels over the far more significant health risks of alcohol consumption.

3. Alcohol’s “Hidden” Calories and Nutritional Impact
•Alcohol itself is calorically dense (7 calories per gram) and contributes “empty” calories with no nutritional benefit. These calories are metabolically disruptive, regardless of sugar content.
•Low-sugar alcoholic beverages still carry the full burden of alcohol’s toxic and caloric effects, but labeling them as “low sugar” could create a false sense of healthfulness.

4. Misleading Comparisons with Other Beverages
•In soft drinks or juices, sugar content is a key health indicator because sugar is the primary source of calories and metabolic impact. However, in alcoholic beverages, sugar is a secondary factor—alcohol is the primary source of both calories and harm.
•A sugary cocktail may appear “worse” than a low-sugar spirit on paper, but the spirit’s alcohol content will have a far greater negative impact on metabolism and overall health than the sugar in the cocktail.

5. Encourages Misguided Consumer Choices
•If sugar content is emphasized on labels, consumers may be tempted to choose alcoholic beverages with low sugar but higher alcohol content, believing they are making a healthier choice. This could inadvertently encourage higher alcohol consumption, increasing the risk of liver damage, addiction, and other alcohol-related harms.
•For example, a vodka soda with zero sugar may be perceived as “better” than a beer with moderate sugar, even though the metabolic harm from the vodka (due to alcohol content) is significantly greater.

6. Focus Should Be on Alcohol Content
•Alcohol’s harmful effects—on metabolism, hormones, and organ health—are independent of its sugar content. The focus of labeling should remain on alcohol content (e.g., ABV) rather than secondary factors like sugar, to accurately communicate the primary health risks.
•Informing consumers about the risks of alcohol itself, rather than its sugar content, provides a clearer picture of the metabolic harm associated with drinking.

Conclusion

Including sugar content on alcohol labels risks creating a misleading narrative that positions sugar as the primary health concern in alcoholic beverages, downplaying alcohol’s inherently harmful effects. This could lead to misguided consumer choices, encouraging higher alcohol consumption under the guise of reducing sugar intake. To promote metabolic health, public awareness should focus on the dangers of alcohol itself, rather than deflecting attention to sugar.

comment_text_sources:
[{'source': 'DIRECT (NON-ATTACHMENT)', 'text': 'The proposed changes to alcohol labeling regulations, while well-intentioned in increasing transparency, present several challenges that may inadvertently harm the industry and not deliver the intended benefits to consumers.

1. Increased Costs: The new labeling requirements impose significant financial burdens on producers, especially smaller craft brands. These costs stem from redesigning labels, undergoing compliance checks, and possibly halting production to implement new labeling. These expenses are likely to be passed on to consumers, increasing the cost of alcohol products without providing proportional value.

2. Innovation Stifling: Small and mid-sized enterprises, which are often the source of innovation within the industry, may find the cost of compliance prohibitive. This could limit the variety of products available to consumers and stifle the creativity that has driven the industry forward.

3. Consumer Overload: While the intent is to inform, there is a risk of overwhelming consumers with too much information, leading to confusion rather than clarity. Consumers benefit from clear, concise, and relevant product information. Overloading labels with detailed data might detract from key information that guides consumer decisions.

4. Market Entry Barriers: New entrants to the alcohol industry might find the enhanced labeling requirements a significant barrier. This could reduce competition in the industry, ultimately disadvantaging consumers who benefit from the competitive pressures that drive quality up and prices down.

5. International Trade Implications: Different countries have varied labeling requirements. The proposed changes could complicate international sales for U.S. producers, potentially limiting market access and reducing the diversity of products available domestically and abroad.

In conclusion, while consumer protection and product transparency are crucial, the proposed labeling changes may lead to higher prices, reduced innovation, consumer confusion, greater barriers to market entry, and complications in international trade. It is essential to find a balance that promotes transparency and consumer protection without undermining the industry’s ability to provide diverse, high-quality, and affordable products to consumers.'}]
comment_text:
The proposed changes to alcohol labeling regulations, while well-intentioned in increasing transparency, present several challenges that may inadvertently harm the industry and not deliver the intended benefits to consumers.

1. Increased Costs: The new labeling requirements impose significant financial burdens on producers, especially smaller craft brands. These costs stem from redesigning labels, undergoing compliance checks, and possibly halting production to implement new labeling. These expenses are likely to be passed on to consumers, increasing the cost of alcohol products without providing proportional value.

2. Innovation Stifling: Small and mid-sized enterprises, which are often the source of innovation within the industry, may find the cost of compliance prohibitive. This could limit the variety of products available to consumers and stifle the creativity that has driven the industry forward.

3. Consumer Overload: While the intent is to inform, there is a risk of overwhelming consumers with too much information, leading to confusion rather than clarity. Consumers benefit from clear, concise, and relevant product information. Overloading labels with detailed data might detract from key information that guides consumer decisions.

4. Market Entry Barriers: New entrants to the alcohol industry might find the enhanced labeling requirements a significant barrier. This could reduce competition in the industry, ultimately disadvantaging consumers who benefit from the competitive pressures that drive quality up and prices down.

5. International Trade Implications: Different countries have varied labeling requirements. The proposed changes could complicate international sales for U.S. producers, potentially limiting market access and reducing the diversity of products available domestically and abroad.

In conclusion, while consumer protection and product transparency are crucial, the proposed labeling changes may lead to higher prices, reduced innovation, consumer confusion, greater barriers to market entry, and complications in international trade. It is essential to find a balance that promotes transparency and consumer protection without undermining the industry’s ability to provide diverse, high-quality, and affordable products to consumers.

comment_text_sources:
[{'source': 'DIRECT (NON-ATTACHMENT)', 'text': 'I oppose nutritional labeling for wines. As both a producer and a consumer of dry wines, I know that the nutritional content does not vary significantly among them. Wines that are not dry, for instance wines that contain 5g/L or more residual sugar, are really a different category. I am not opposed to such labeling on those wines, but they first need to be identified as a separate category.

There is no value to the consumer in nutritional labels that do not meaningfully vary from (dry) wine to (dry) wine. None will have fat, cholesterol, measurable vitamins, etc., and the calorie count will vary minimally. If the TTB wants to share this information with consumers, they could post the standard information for dry wines on their website.'}]
comment_text:
I oppose nutritional labeling for wines. As both a producer and a consumer of dry wines, I know that the nutritional content does not vary significantly among them. Wines that are not dry, for instance wines that contain 5g/L or more residual sugar, are really a different category. I am not opposed to such labeling on those wines, but they first need to be identified as a separate category.

There is no value to the consumer in nutritional labels that do not meaningfully vary from (dry) wine to (dry) wine. None will have fat, cholesterol, measurable vitamins, etc., and the calorie count will vary minimally. If the TTB wants to share this information with consumers, they could post the standard information for dry wines on their website.

comment_text_sources:
[{'source': 'DIRECT (NON-ATTACHMENT)', 'text': 'Please see the attached file.'}, {'source': 'https://downloads.regulations.gov/TTB-2025-0002-0055/attachment_1.pdf', 'text': ' 
Page 1 of 4 
 
 
 
   
 
 
 
 
 
February 28, 2025 
 
Amy Greenberg 
Director, Regulations and Rulings Division 
Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau 
1310 G. Street NW, Box 12 
Washington, DC 20005 
 
RE: Docket No. TTB-2025-0002, Notice No. 237: Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of 
Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages - Request for 120-Day Extension for Comments  
 
Dear Ms. Greenberg, 
 
Wine Institute is the public policy advocacy association representing over 1,000 California 
wineries and affiliated businesses.  California is responsible for more than 81 percent of the 
nation’s wine production and more than 95 percent of U.S. wine exports .  Distilled Spirits 
Council of the United States (“DISCUS”) is the principal trade association for the leading 
producers and importers of distilled spirits products sold in the  U.S. and represents 
distillers of all sizes .  The Beer Institute (“BI”) represents the $ 409.2 billion beer industry – 
an industry that includes over 6,600 brewers and more than 2.4 million American jobs.  BI is 
a national trade association for the American brewing industry, representing both large and 
small brewers, as well as importers and industry suppliers.  The Brewers Association (“BA”) 
seeks to promote and protect the interests of craft brewers and the craft brewing 
community, including beer consumers and home brewers. Today the BA  has roughly 5,000 
full voting brewery members – including members in every state – as well as over 1,000 allied 
trade members and over 30,000 home brewer and beer enthusiast members.   The National 
 
Page 2 of 4 
 
Beer Wholesalers Association’s (“NBWA”) purpose is to provide leadership, which 
enhances the independent beer and beverage distribution industry; to advocate before 
government and the public; to encourage the responsible consumption of alcohol; and to 
provide programs and services that will benefit its members.  Wine & Spirits Wholesalers of 
America (“WSWA”) is the only national membership organization of wine and spirits 
distributors.  On behalf of its more than 380 member companies, WSWA advocates on their 
behalf with regards to federal, state, regulatory, and legal issues impacting distributors and 
the beverage alcohol industry.   WineAmerica is the National Association of American 
Wineries, representing wineries, winery associations, and wine industry supply companies 
across the country.  WineAmerica’s mission is to encourage the dynamic growth and 
development of American wineries and winegrowing through the advancement and 
advocacy of sound public policy.  The American Craft Spirits Association (“ACSA”) the only 
national registered non-profit trade association representing the U.S. craft spirits industry. 
Its mission is to elevate and advocate for the community of craft spirits producers, and 
membership in ACSA is open to anyone. American Distilled Spirits Alliance (“ADSA”) i s a 
trade association comprised of 29 leading companies with common needs and interests in 
the manufacturing, importation, and marketing of distilled spirits products in the U.S. and 
around the world.  ADSA member companies represent over 70 percent of all distilled spirit 
sales nationwide. 
We refer to Wine Institute, DISCUS, BI, BA, NBWA, WSWA, WineAmerica, ACSA, and ADSA 
collectively as “the Associations” in this joint letter.   
 
The Associations respectfully request an extension of the comment period in  Notice No. 
237: Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages 
(“Notice 237”).  The comment period for Notice 237 is scheduled to end on April 17, 2025. 
The Associa tions request a 120-day extension to the current comment period that would 
extend to August 15, 2025. 
 
As a threshold matter , we note that these rulemakings come at a time when heavily 
regulated industries, and the agencies that regulate them , are adjusting to the priorities of 
the new administration .  There were many potentially impactful rulemakings published in 
the final days of the previous administration and then a regulatory freeze put in place on the 
first day of the new administration.  Additional time will allow agencies, and the industries 
they regulate, to better understand new priorities, expectations, and directives put into 
place since Notice 237 issued.  This is particularly important for the thousands of small and 
midsize wineries , c raft brewers, and craft distillers, who will bear great costs and 
operational burdens that a new and sweeping mandatory labeling regime imposes .  Even 
meaningfully participating in  the comment process means they must redirect time and 
resources. 
 
Notice 237 is expansive—i.e., 53 pages in the Federal Registers’ 10-point, single -spaced 
font—and poses more than 90 questions and expressly solicits comments in other areas.  It 
is also the first opportunity in a long while to comment on the important issues that it raises.  
Indeed, it has been over 17 years since TTB last raised these issues and it rightly recognizes  
Page 3 of 4 
 
in Notice 237 that the comments received almost two decades ago “may no longer fully and 
accurately reflect the opinions ” of industry members, trade associations, and other 
interested parties.  We agree with TTB that addressing this issue again years later necessarily 
requires updated input  and add that the beverage alcohol landscape has fundamentally 
evolved over the past 17 years.   That said, it will take time to conduct a detailed analysis of 
the proposed rule —including the many questions and requests fo r comments in Notice 
237—and for our members to provide comprehensive and useful feedback that will benefit 
the overall process and TTB’s objectives with this rulemaking. 
 
It is important to keep in mind that the  issues and questions addressed in Notice 237  will 
impact small, midsize, and large industry members in different ways.  Given the importance 
of the issues, the Associations will need substantial time to collect, deliberate, and convey 
the input of all our members to ensure their perspectives are included and well-reflected.  
Moreover, TTB seeks comments in Notice 237 on important but sweeping areas of interest 
such as comments on “ any other options available to reduce regulatory burdens and 
economic costs while still providing the consumer with adequate information about the 
products in question .”  Our members will need additional time to consider other options 
available for those purposes and then explain and discuss them in submitted comments. 
 
Last, additional time is necessary due to several ongoing and overlapping rulemakings that 
impact our members.  As you know, TTB also published a rulemaking proposing major food 
allergen labeling for wines, distilled spirits, and malt beverages on the same day as Notice 
237 and with the same deadline for comments.  One day prior to Notice 237’s publication , 
the FDA published a rulemaking proposing front-of-package labeling for nutrition which will 
also impact industry members.  All these rulemakings, including Notice 237, propose new 
rules with many potential impacts that de serve due consideration.  We therefore believe a 
120-day extension is appropriate and necessary. 
 
We would be pleased to respond to any questions that you might have about this request. 
 
[ SIGNATURES ON FOLLOWING PAGE ] 
   
Page 4 of 4 
 
 
  
Respectfully Submitted, 
 
 
 
Robert P. Koch 
President and Chief Executive Officer 
Wine Institute 
 
  
  
Craig Purser 
President and CEO 
National Beer Wholesalers Association 
 
 
Courtney Armour 
Chief Legal Officer 
Distilled Spirits Council 
  
 
 
 
Francis Creighton 
President and CEO 
Wine & Spirits Wholesalers of America 
 
 
 
 
Brian Crawford 
President and CEO 
Beer Institute 
  
  
  
Margie A.S. Lehrman  
Chief Executive Officer 
American Craft Spirits Association 
  
  
 
 
Marc Sorini 
Vice President of Government Affairs 
Brewers Association 
  
 
Michael Kaiser  
Executive Vice President and Director of 
Government Affairs 
WineAmerica 
  
   
 
 
 
 
Amanda Nguyen 
President & CEO 
American Distilled Spirits Alliance 
  
 
 
'}]

comment_text_sources:
[{'source': 'DIRECT (NON-ATTACHMENT)', 'text': 'As a wine professional with 17 years of experience in the United States, I fully support providing consumers with more transparency about the contents of wine. However, certain aspects of this proposal are misguided.

The single most valuable piece of information—final sugar content—is merely optional. This is particularly concerning given that large-scale producers frequently add sugar to mass-market wines, effectively deceiving consumers. Wine shoppers should be able to quickly know which wines have added or natural sugars above the normal level for a table wine (about 1-3g/L). Instead, this proposal would require at best, that consumers calculate the calories from alcohol and deduce the sugar content which is an unrealistic expectation

It makes little sense to require labels to list “no protein” or “no fat” while exempting sugar, which is far more relevant. Eliminating these two superfluous statistics in favor of mandatory sugar disclosure would empower consumers and encourage honesty in the industry. Unfortunately, it appears larger players have influenced the proposal to avoid revealing the truth about added sugars. I hope the final rule is shaped by those who prioritize consumer interests and genuine transparency over corporate advantage.'}]
comment_text:
As a wine professional with 17 years of experience in the United States, I fully support providing consumers with more transparency about the contents of wine. However, certain aspects of this proposal are misguided.

The single most valuable piece of information—final sugar content—is merely optional. This is particularly concerning given that large-scale producers frequently add sugar to mass-market wines, effectively deceiving consumers. Wine shoppers should be able to quickly know which wines have added or natural sugars above the normal level for a table wine (about 1-3g/L). Instead, this proposal would require at best, that consumers calculate the calories from alcohol and deduce the sugar content which is an unrealistic expectation

It makes little sense to require labels to list “no protein” or “no fat” while exempting sugar, which is far more relevant. Eliminating these two superfluous statistics in favor of mandatory sugar disclosure would empower consumers and encourage honesty in the industry. Unfortunately, it appears larger players have influenced the proposal to avoid revealing the truth about added sugars. I hope the final rule is shaped by those who prioritize consumer interests and genuine transparency over corporate advantage.
document_title: Notice No. 237:  Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages

I fully support this regulation. '}]

[{'source': 'DIRECT (NON-ATTACHMENT)', 'text': 'The beer, wine, and distilled spirits industry should not need to be so heavily regulated by the government with regards to serving size, calories, allergens, etc. The wine industry especially has been around for thousands of years and we need to not be "helicopter parents" consumers know how many calories are in a glass of wine, in a can of beer, and in a shot glass of spirits Doing this will not make people healthier, or more aware of their calorie intake. Consumers will have what they will have and this is an added burden that needs to not be sought after. Consumers are very proactive in looking on websites for information especially if there is a QR code that is available for scanning on the bottles thereby giving all the information needed at their fingertips.

In fact I just came across a TTB Beer Resources guide that has QR codes for formula, formula guidance, beer labeling guidance. The alcohol industry would be able to do the same if it is so necessary to list ingredients, calories, serving size, alc content etc.

Changing the labels is an unnecessary expense and a regulation that is not needed for this industry.'}]
comment_title: Comment 42:  Texas SouthWind Vineyard and Winery
comment_text:
The beer, wine, and distilled spirits industry should not need to be so heavily regulated by the government with regards to serving size, calories, allergens, etc. The wine industry especially has been around for thousands of years and we need to not be "helicopter parents" consumers know how many calories are in a glass of wine, in a can of beer, and in a shot glass of spirits Doing this will not make people healthier, or more aware of their calorie intake. Consumers will have what they will have and this is an added burden that needs to not be sought after. Consumers are very proactive in looking on websites for information especially if there is a QR code that is available for scanning on the bottles thereby giving all the information needed at their fingertips.

In fact I just came across a TTB Beer Resources guide that has QR codes for formula, formula guidance, beer labeling guidance. The alcohol industry would be able to do the same if it is so necessary to list ingredients, calories, serving size, alc content etc.

Changing the labels is an unnecessary expense and a regulation that is not needed for this industry.

comment_text_sources:
[{'source': 'DIRECT (NON-ATTACHMENT)', 'text': 'I believe that the addition of a nutrition label to alcoholic beverages would go a long way to improving the transparency of producers to consumers on one of the most commonly consumed beverages in America. Many do not realize the nutritional impact alcohol can have on one's diet beyond feeling tipsy. Alcohol can have a significantly high number of calories and, for some spirits, can contain ingredients that are common allergens. The implementation of a small QR code nearby the label would be a consideration but it is questionable how many people would pull out their phone, scan the QR code, wait for the page to load, etc, as opposed to taking 2 seconds to just reading the actual label.

While there is some argument on an impact to small producers, this impact is outweighed by the benefit of greater transparency from producers on what exactly is being put in alcoholic drinks. Especially for a beverage that, even in small servings consumed over time, can cause significant impacts to health. Alcohol should not be given light treatment simply because its "too much of a burden" or "not necessary". This is a drug that can cause cancer and dependency if abused and does require a label in the interest of public health.'}]
comment_text:
I believe that the addition of a nutrition label to alcoholic beverages would go a long way to improving the transparency of producers to consumers on one of the most commonly consumed beverages in America. Many do not realize the nutritional impact alcohol can have on one's diet beyond feeling tipsy. Alcohol can have a significantly high number of calories and, for some spirits, can contain ingredients that are common allergens. The implementation of a small QR code nearby the label would be a consideration but it is questionable how many people would pull out their phone, scan the QR code, wait for the page to load, etc, as opposed to taking 2 seconds to just reading the actual label.

While there is some argument on an impact to small producers, this impact is outweighed by the benefit of greater transparency from producers on what exactly is being put in alcoholic drinks. Especially for a beverage that, even in small servings consumed over time, can cause significant impacts to health. Alcohol should not be given light treatment simply because its "too much of a burden" or "not necessary". This is a drug that can cause cancer and dependency if abused and does require a label in the interest of public health.

comment_text_sources: [{'source': 'DIRECT (NON-ATTACHMENT)', 'text': 'Alcohol content has always been a requirement for wine labels, but adding nutrition facts to an age old beverage is out right ridiculous. No one who drinks wine, or wine adjacent products, cares about the facts except for how strong the beverage is (ABV), and how good or bad the flavor is. The labeling would be a nightmare, and needing to submit a new label with any changes or updates to the "facts" would be extremely cost prohibitive. No batch is ever identical even if the beverage in question is made the same way, with the same fruits or grains, with the same yeasts, year in and year out. They're all different. They're always different. Not to mention with the smaller businesses, having to get these tests are not in their budget, even if its expected in the range of 200-500 per sample, but if they have multiple flavors, or blends, or even lines of products, it's going to add up. There's no way to enforce it, either. Like most table wine labels, or wines that are made the same way, or blended the same every year, the fluctuation in product never has the same nutritional profile. And if there's a deviation in the product verses what is listed on the label, becomes a logistical nightmare. The sugars might change, even if its by grams. Or the ABV might be a percent higher or lower than what's listed. Which then makes the labeling false, and opens up an entire can of worms that could lead to false advertising or misleading labeling claims, which in turn would spell the end of some of the smaller or starting up businesses. '}]
comment_text: Alcohol content has always been a requirement for wine labels, but adding nutrition facts to an age old beverage is out right ridiculous. No one who drinks wine, or wine adjacent products, cares about the facts except for how strong the beverage is (ABV), and how good or bad the flavor is. The labeling would be a nightmare, and needing to submit a new label with any changes or updates to the "facts" would be extremely cost prohibitive. No batch is ever identical even if the beverage in question is made the same way, with the same fruits or grains, with the same yeasts, year in and year out. They're all different. They're always different. Not to mention with the smaller businesses, having to get these tests are not in their budget, even if its expected in the range of 200-500 per sample, but if they have multiple flavors, or blends, or even lines of products, it's going to add up. There's no way to enforce it, either. Like most table wine labels, or wines that are made the same way, or blended the same every year, the fluctuation in product never has the same nutritional profile. And if there's a deviation in the product verses what is listed on the label, becomes a logistical nightmare. The sugars might change, even if its by grams. Or the ABV might be a percent higher or lower than what's listed. Which then makes the labeling false, and opens up an entire can of worms that could lead to false advertising or misleading labeling claims, which in turn would spell the end of some of the smaller or starting up businesses.
document_title: Notice No. 237:  Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages

comment_text_sources:
[{'source': 'https://downloads.regulations.gov/TTB-2025-0002-0101/attachment_1.pdf', 'text': 'Public Comment on Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages [Docket No. TTB-2025-0002; Notice No. 237] De Maison Selections Inc. is a small business with 20 employees that imports fine wine, cider, and spirits from small, family-run wineries in France and Spain. We are commenting on the questions the TTB posed in the proposed rulemaking notice. Overall Comment on Proposed Rulemaking: Although there has been little to no demand for nutritional information from our distributors and consumers, we understand the motivations behind the Alcohol Facts statement outlined in the proposed rulemaking. Complying with the proposed regulation would require us to incur upfront costs in terms of time and money; however, we appreciate the TTB’s flexibility regarding nutrition labeling, COLA approval, thresholds, and nutrition testing. While we value the TTB's allowance for the alcohol facts label to be displayed linearly, utilizing a QR code would enable us to update information and align with EU labeling protocols. We are thankful for the TTB’s implementation of a five-year period, which will save time and money in the long run. Despite the potential cost savings, the new labeling requirement would impose a minimum expense of $818,260 on our company. Thus, this proposed regulation would still present challenges for small importers and producers. Many small foreign producers struggle to comprehend US regulations and requirements, making it difficult to communicate them accurately and precisely to their production partners. This could lead to numerous errors in attempts at compliance, resulting in lost time and resources. We estimate that fulfilling the proposed regulations will increase production and transit times, as producers must invest time and resources to meet these new requirements. Serving Facts vs Alcohol Facts Labeling alcoholic products with “Alcohol Facts” will help consumers differentiate between alcoholic items and other food products. "Alcohol Facts" is also a more accurate descriptor of the information included in the proposed statement. However, voluntarily labeled products will incur costs to transition from "Serving Facts" to "Alcohol Facts." Alcohol Facts Labeling The back label of a wine or spirit is valuable real estate that includes what consumers desire, such as the terroir, grape varieties, and the technical skills of the winemaker (Bettaglene, 2014). Including alcohol facts on the back label reduces space for these attributes and may hinder small wine producers' ability to connect with consumers. We recognize that not all consumers are wine connoisseurs; however, consumers may be inclined to purchase a product if the producer shares an authentic story, fostering trust with specific regions and producers (Tortolero Cervantes, 2023). With the increasing requirement for warning statements and sulfite content, a QR code or linear Alcohol Facts label would allow producers to showcase important attributes consumers want while providing alcohol facts and allergens. Linear Alcohol Facts Statement: We oppose the back label’s nutrient statement aligning with the nutrition facts label found on foods under the FDA’s labeling jurisdiction. Eighteen percent of individuals in the US read wine labels; among those who do, shorter ingredient lists or clean-labeled wines without listed ingredients are preferred (Pabst et al., 2021). Therefore, we endorse the linear label, which contains all the information required by the TTB while also allowing for listing wine attributes. QR Codes: We advocate using QR codes on labels, enabling consumers to access mandatory Alcohol Facts statements and allergen information on their mobile devices. QR codes are also required in the EU, and producers can include the US alcohol facts regulations on the same webpage, thereby reducing the regulatory burden on these small businesses. Commenters noted that not everyone has a cell phone, particularly those over 65, and that tribal lands and rural areas often lack sufficient 4G LTE coverage. According to the FCC Broadband Data Collection, as of June 30, 2024, most of the US has between 40% and 100% access to 4G LTE data ( FCC National Broadband Map , 2025). The STARLINK availability map reveals that most of the US (>=99%), even in rural areas, has access to high-speed internet ( Starlink , 2025). Therefore, consumers will likely access QR codes on their mobile devices within five years. In 2023, 97% of 18-49-year-olds owned a smartphone, and 89% of those aged 50-64 owned one. Although only 76% of individuals aged 65 and older owned a smartphone, this trend has increased from 46% in 2018 to 61% in 2021 ( Smartphone Ownership in the US by Age 2023 , 2025). Across all age groups, smartphone ownership is on the rise, and this is expected to continue in the coming years. Thus, the commenters' concerns about the lack of smartphone ownership and coverage are unfounded. Labeling Requirements and Competition: As a small business importing wine and distilled spirits from family-owned vineyards, these new requirements will increase costs for our business and foreign producers. We applaud the TTB’s use of the FDA Labeling Cost Model to estimate a per UPC price for label redesign for wine and distilled spirits, finding the cost of $1,636.52 per UPC fair. However, we must hire another employee to manage graphic design, web development, and data analytics to meet the new requirements. This will also incur costs for health insurance, training, and benefits for the new hire. With between 400 and 500 UPCs, our minimum costs would range from $654,608 to $818,260, which may limit our ability to sell wine and distilled spirits in the US market. We commend the TTB for not requiring a new COLA, allowing thresholds, and permitting one-time testing of each product. Implementation Period: We agree with the five-year implementation period. This will provide our producers sufficient time to use existing labels and print new ones with alcohol facts. The number of labels the producer has printed by the time the final rule is established will determine if our compliance period is shorter than five years. Bettaglene, T. (2014). An analysis of ingredient and nutritional labeling for wine. ProQuest , 3 (1), 1–8. https://doi.org/DOI:10.1051/bioconf/20140303006 FCC National Broadband Map . (2025). FCC National Broadband Map. https://broadbandmap.fcc.gov Pabst, E., Corsi, A. M., Vecchio, R., Annunziata, A., & Loose, S. M. (2021). Consumers’ reactions to nutrition and ingredient labelling for wine – A cross-country discrete choice experiment. Appetite , 156 , 104843. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.appet.2020.104843 Smartphone ownership in the US by age 2023 . (2025). Statista. https://www.statista.com/statistics/489255/percentage-of-us-smartphone-owners-by-age- group/ Starlink . (2025). Starlink. https://www.starlink.com Tortolero Cervantes, F. (2023). New Technologies and Wine Law: European lessons to the new world of wine (NWW). BIO Web Conf. , 68 . https://doi.org/10.1051/bioconf/20236803022 '}, {'source': 'DIRECT (NON-ATTACHMENT)', 'text': 'De Maison Selections Inc. is a small business with 20 employees that imports fine wine, cider, and spirits from small, family-run wineries in France and Spain. We are commenting on the questions the TTB posed in the proposed rulemaking notice.

Although there has been little to no demand for nutritional information from our distributors and consumers, we understand the motivations behind the Alcohol Facts statement outlined in the proposed rulemaking. Complying with the proposed regulation would require us to incur upfront costs in terms of time and money; however, we appreciate the TTB’s flexibility regarding nutrition labeling, COLA approval, thresholds, and nutrition testing. While we value the TTB's allowance for the alcohol facts label to be displayed linearly, utilizing a QR code would enable us to update information and align with EU labeling protocols. We are thankful for the TTB’s implementation of a five-year period, which will save time and money in the long run. Despite the potential cost savings, the new labeling requirement would impose a minimum expense of $818,260 on our company. Thus, this proposed regulation would still present challenges for small importers and producers. Many small foreign producers struggle to comprehend US regulations and requirements, making it difficult to communicate them accurately and precisely to their production partners. This could lead to numerous errors in attempts at compliance, resulting in lost time and resources. We estimate that fulfilling the proposed regulations will increase production and transit times, as producers must invest time and resources to meet these new requirements.

We have attached a more detailed comment document. '}]
comment_text:
De Maison Selections Inc. is a small business with 20 employees that imports fine wine, cider, and spirits from small, family-run wineries in France and Spain. We are commenting on the questions the TTB posed in the proposed rulemaking notice.

Although there has been little to no demand for nutritional information from our distributors and consumers, we understand the motivations behind the Alcohol Facts statement outlined in the proposed rulemaking. Complying with the proposed regulation would require us to incur upfront costs in terms of time and money; however, we appreciate the TTB’s flexibility regarding nutrition labeling, COLA approval, thresholds, and nutrition testing. While we value the TTB's allowance for the alcohol facts label to be displayed linearly, utilizing a QR code would enable us to update information and align with EU labeling protocols. We are thankful for the TTB’s implementation of a five-year period, which will save time and money in the long run. Despite the potential cost savings, the new labeling requirement would impose a minimum expense of $818,260 on our company. Thus, this proposed regulation would still present challenges for small importers and producers. Many small foreign producers struggle to comprehend US regulations and requirements, making it difficult to communicate them accurately and precisely to their production partners. This could lead to numerous errors in attempts at compliance, resulting in lost time and resources. We estimate that fulfilling the proposed regulations will increase production and transit times, as producers must invest time and resources to meet these new requirements.

We have attached a more detailed comment document.

comment_text_sources:
[{'source': 'DIRECT (NON-ATTACHMENT)', 'text': 'opposes the proposed Alcohol Facts labelling rule because it is misaligned with historical labelling and consumer trends, imposes substantial economic burdens on producers, and is an impractical use of limited label space.

RATIONALE IN SUPPORT OF REJECTING THE RULE:

1. Consumer confusion has been identified in prior rulemaking and, notably, in this scenario, dietary disclosure lacks demonstrable necessity. People do not consume alcohol for nutritional content, and to suggest otherwise may be at cross purposes to regulations that support responsible alcohol consumption. Proscriptions can avoid market deceptions. Absent a documented market failure, dietary labeling mandates violate rules of necessity (APA §706(2)(A).

2. The economic burden of dietary testing and compliance, particularly considering limited editions, seasonal variations, and batch variations, would be disproportionately borne by small businesses in an industry of aggressive consolidative pressures and marketing obstacles. Small businesses cannot offset recurrent costs through economies of scale. Further, this cost overrun undermines the public benefit, such as through less consumer choice and signal noise. The proposal has not considered less burdensome alternatives such as voluntary and QR disclosures.

3. The proposed rule disrupts established conventions to use limited label space, responsible free speech, and aesthetics. Signals must relate to qualifiers that aid consumers in making informed choices about product differentiation. Consumers may not object to the abstract idea of dietary information on a label; however, they look to qualifiers such as region, source ingredients, production methods, and sustainability. The proposed rule would, therefore, conflict with the comprehensive labeling framework (27 CFR 4.32—4.39). Additional label information would unintentionally increase container sizes.

4. Alcohol consumption is declining significantly among Gen Z. Regulatory cues that accentuate limited dietary benefits would reinforce avoidance behaviors, shift comparison to dietary content of non-alcoholic alternatives, diminish the stated benefits of the regulation, and may represent regulatory overreach. Further, the NIH knows that similar regulations have disparate impacts on socioeconomic groups, including gender, race, and ethnicity.

Babor, T. et al. (2010). Alcohol: No Ordinary Commodity (2nd ed.), Oxford University Press, Ch. 11 [equating alcohol to food may send conflicting messages about healthful diet]
American Radio Relay League, Inc. v. FCC, 524 F.3d 227, 247 (D.C. Cir. 2008)
State Farm Mutual Automobile Insurance Co. v. DOT, 463 U.S. 29, 43 (1983)
Anderson, Peter et al. “Effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of policies and programmes to reduce the harm caused by alcohol.” Lancet (London, England) vol. 373,9682 (2009): 2234-46. doi:10.1016/S0140-6736(09)60744-3; Crain, W. M., & Crain, N. V. (2010). The Impact of Regulatory Costs on Small Firms. SBA Office of Advocacy Report.
https://www.govinfo.gov/content/pkg/GOVPUB-SBA-PURL-LPS95767/pdf/GOVPUB-SBA-PURL-LPS95767.pdf
Motor Vehicle Mfrs. Ass’n v. State Farm, 463 U.S. 29 (1983); Michigan v. EPA, 576 U.S. 743, 752–53 (2015)
https://www.researchgate.net/publication/225709127_What_you_see_may_not_be_what_you_get_Asking_consumers_what_matters_may_not_reflect_what_they_choose
Sunstein, Cass R. "The limits of quantification." Calif. L. Rev. 102 (2014): 1369.(The marginal utility of disclosure declines when consumer trends are toward cautious, risk-averse behavior)
Kilian, Carolin et al. “Reducing alcohol use through alcohol control policies in the general population and population subgroups: a systematic review and meta-analysis.” EClinicalMedicine vol. 59 101996. 10 May. 2023, doi:10.1016/j.eclinm.2023.101996. https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10225668/

'}]
comment_text:
opposes the proposed Alcohol Facts labelling rule because it is misaligned with historical labelling and consumer trends, imposes substantial economic burdens on producers, and is an impractical use of limited label space.

RATIONALE IN SUPPORT OF REJECTING THE RULE:

1. Consumer confusion has been identified in prior rulemaking and, notably, in this scenario, dietary disclosure lacks demonstrable necessity. People do not consume alcohol for nutritional content, and to suggest otherwise may be at cross purposes to regulations that support responsible alcohol consumption. Proscriptions can avoid market deceptions. Absent a documented market failure, dietary labeling mandates violate rules of necessity (APA §706(2)(A).

2. The economic burden of dietary testing and compliance, particularly considering limited editions, seasonal variations, and batch variations, would be disproportionately borne by small businesses in an industry of aggressive consolidative pressures and marketing obstacles. Small businesses cannot offset recurrent costs through economies of scale. Further, this cost overrun undermines the public benefit, such as through less consumer choice and signal noise. The proposal has not considered less burdensome alternatives such as voluntary and QR disclosures.

3. The proposed rule disrupts established conventions to use limited label space, responsible free speech, and aesthetics. Signals must relate to qualifiers that aid consumers in making informed choices about product differentiation. Consumers may not object to the abstract idea of dietary information on a label; however, they look to qualifiers such as region, source ingredients, production methods, and sustainability. The proposed rule would, therefore, conflict with the comprehensive labeling framework (27 CFR 4.32—4.39). Additional label information would unintentionally increase container sizes.

4. Alcohol consumption is declining significantly among Gen Z. Regulatory cues that accentuate limited dietary benefits would reinforce avoidance behaviors, shift comparison to dietary content of non-alcoholic alternatives, diminish the stated benefits of the regulation, and may represent regulatory overreach. Further, the NIH knows that similar regulations have disparate impacts on socioeconomic groups, including gender, race, and ethnicity.

Babor, T. et al. (2010). Alcohol: No Ordinary Commodity (2nd ed.), Oxford University Press, Ch. 11 [equating alcohol to food may send conflicting messages about healthful diet]
American Radio Relay League, Inc. v. FCC, 524 F.3d 227, 247 (D.C. Cir. 2008)
State Farm Mutual Automobile Insurance Co. v. DOT, 463 U.S. 29, 43 (1983)
Anderson, Peter et al. “Effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of policies and programmes to reduce the harm caused by alcohol.” Lancet (London, England) vol. 373,9682 (2009): 2234-46. doi:10.1016/S0140-6736(09)60744-3; Crain, W. M., & Crain, N. V. (2010). The Impact of Regulatory Costs on Small Firms. SBA Office of Advocacy Report.
https://www.govinfo.gov/content/pkg/GOVPUB-SBA-PURL-LPS95767/pdf/GOVPUB-SBA-PURL-LPS95767.pdf
Motor Vehicle Mfrs. Ass’n v. State Farm, 463 U.S. 29 (1983); Michigan v. EPA, 576 U.S. 743, 752–53 (2015)
https://www.researchgate.net/publication/225709127_What_you_see_may_not_be_what_you_get_Asking_consumers_what_matters_may_not_reflect_what_they_choose
Sunstein, Cass R. "The limits of quantification." Calif. L. Rev. 102 (2014): 1369.(The marginal utility of disclosure declines when consumer trends are toward cautious, risk-averse behavior)
Kilian, Carolin et al. “Reducing alcohol use through alcohol control policies in the general population and population subgroups: a systematic review and meta-analysis.” EClinicalMedicine vol. 59 101996. 10 May. 2023, doi:10.1016/j.eclinm.2023.101996. https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10225668/

[{'source': 'https://downloads.regulations.gov/TTB-2025-0002-0065/attachment_1.pdf', 'text': '中国 WTO/TBT 国家通报咨询中心 China WTO/TBT National Notification & Enquiry Center No.20,Hepingli East Street, Dongcheng District, Beijing,China,Tel: 86-10-57954638 Fax:86-10-57954689 FAX TO： USA WTO TBT Enquiry Point Email: usatbtep@nist.gov Date: Mar 21, 2025 Number of pages: 2+2 Copies: Department for WTO Affairs, Ministry of Commerce of P .R. China E-mail: dingtao@mofcom.gov.cn Permanent Mission of P . R. of China to WTO Fax: +41-22-9097688 E-mail: ysroger@sohu.com From: China WTO/TBT National Notification & Enquiry Center. Tel: 86-10-57954638 Fax: 86-10-57954689 E-mail: tbt@customs.gov.cn Subject: Comments from P. R. China on United States Notification G/TBT/N/USA/2182 Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages 1 of 4Comments from P. R. China on United States Notification G/TBT/N/USA/2182 Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages Dear Sir or Madam, We appreciate the opportunity to submit comments on the notified draft proposed by United States of America. Enclosed please find comments in English and Chinese. Please acknowledge receipt of the comments by e-mail to tbt@customs.gov.cn and pengdy_tbt@163.com. Thank you very much in advance for United States of America taking into account comments from P.R. China. Your formal reply will be appreciated. Best regards, Jiao Yang Deputy Director General China WTO/TBT National Notification & Enquiry Center No.20，Hepingli East Street, Dongcheng District, Beijing Post Code: 100013 Tel: 86-10-57954638 Fax: 86-10-57954689 E-mail: tbt@customs.gov.cn pengdy_tbt@163.com 2 of 4Comments from P. R. China on United States Notification G/TBT/N/USA/2182 1. The draft regulation required all alcohol beverage labels regulated by TTB to disclose the alcohol content, calories, and nutritional information of each beverage in the "alcohol content" statement. Due to the fact that alcoholic beverages are mainly composed of ethanol and water, and do not contain conventional nutrients such as protein, fat, carbohydrates, etc., for example, distilled spirits almost do not contain these components. If the product does not add nutritional fortifiers or make nutritional claims, labeling the nutritional content table is meaningless; Fermented alcoholic beverages (such as beer and fruit wine) may contain small amounts of carbohydrates, and it may consider adding only labeled carbohydrates as appropriate. However, beer labels also require labeling malt content, therefore, labeling carbohydrates is not very meaningful for consumers. For ordinary consumers, the nutritional value of alcoholic beverages is limited, and labeling indicators such as carbohydrates may be misleading (such as implying that they have nutritional supplementation functions). The additional and unnecessary laboratory analysis costs incurred are also a heavy burden for producers or traders. According to the relevant standards of the CAC (Codex Alimentarius Commission), most countries do not require the labeling of conventional nutrients such as protein, fat, carbohydrates, etc. for alcoholic beverages. The provision of Regulation (EU) No 1169/2011 of the European Parliament and of the Council on the Provision of Food Information to Consumers concerning the ingredient list and nutrition declaration for alcoholic beverages with an alcohol content exceeding 1.2% is non-mandatory. When the nutrition statement for alcoholic beverages is voluntarily provided, it is limited to energy values only. Based on the principle of scientific evidence and necessity, it is recommended that the United States should coordinate its requirements for alcoholic beverage labeling with international standards, or differentiated the requirements according to the different product forms of alcoholic beverages: consider not mandating the labeling of conventional nutrients such as protein, fat, carbohydrates, etc. on ordinary alcoholic beverage labels as appropriate; If additional ingredients such as sugar, juice, or other nutritional enhancers are added to alcoholic beverages, the carbohydrate content or other nutrient content may be indicated according to the actual situation. To avoid excessive regulation, reduce compliance costs for businesses, and alleviate the burden on small and medium-sized enterprises. 2. The draft regulation required the addition of new subpart L - alcohol factual statements in Parts 4, 5, and 7 of Title 27 of the Code of Federal Regulations (CFR). The current regulations require the display of information such as alcohol content, carmine, sulfite, etc. The proposed rule required an addition of alcohol factual statements such as single portion size, number of portions per container, and liquid ounces per unit of pure ethanol, and the liquid ounce information per unit of pure ethanol should be accurate to one tenth of the liquid ounce. The provision differs from international standards and may impose additional costs and burdens on alcoholic beverage manufacturers and importers, especially small businesses. It is recommended that the United States should maintain the current regulations without 3 of 4adding the provision and not mandating the labeling of information such as "single portion size, number of portions per container, and number of ounces of pure ethanol per serving" to avoid unnecessary barriers to trade. Comments in Chinese are as below: 1、 规章修订提案中要求所有受TTB 监管的酒精饮料标签“酒精含量”声明 中必须披露每份饮料的酒精含量、 卡路里及营养成分信息。 由于酒精饮料的主要 成分为乙醇和水， 基本不含蛋白质、 脂肪、 碳水化合物等常规营养素，比如蒸馏 酒几乎不含这些成分， 若产品未添加营养强化剂或未进行营养声称， 则标示营养 成分表毫无意义；发酵酒（如啤酒、果酒）可能含有少量碳水化合物，可以酌情 考虑仅添加标示碳水化合物， 但啤酒标签也已要求标注麦芽度， 因此标示碳水化 合物对于消费者也无太大意义。对普通消费者而言，酒精饮料的营养价值有限， 标注碳水化合物等指标可能产生误导（如暗示其具有营养补充功能） 。其产生额 外的、不必要的实验室分析费用对生产商或贸易商来说也是繁重的负担。 根据食品法典委员会的相关标准， 国际上绝大多数国家对酒精饮料不强制要 求标注蛋白质、脂肪、碳水化合物等常规营养素。欧盟（EU）第 1169/2011 号条 例《关于向消费者提供食品信息》涉及酒精含量超过 1.2%的酒精饮料提供成分 清单、营养声明的规定属于非强制性条款，当酒精饮料营养声明是自愿提供时， 营养声明仅限于能量值。 本着科学性与必要性， 建议美方对酒精饮料标签的要求与国际标准协调一致， 也可根据酒精饮料的不同产品形式区分要求： 酌情考虑不强制普通酒精饮料标签 标注蛋白质、 脂肪、 碳水化合物等常规营养素； 若酒精饮料中额外添加了糖、果 汁等配料， 或使用其他营养强化剂的， 可根据实际情况要求标示碳水化合物含量 或其他营养素含量。以避免过度监管，降低企业合规成本与中小企业的负担。 2、规章修订提案中要求在《美国联邦法规》第27 篇第 4、5、7 部分中分别 增加新的子部分 L——酒精事实陈述条款。 现行法规已要求显示酒精含量、 胭脂 红、 亚硫酸盐等信息， 该拟议规则要求增加单份份量、 每个容器的份数和每份纯 乙醇的液体盎司数等酒精事实声明， 且每份纯乙醇的液体盎司信息需精确到液体 盎司的十分之一。 该条款与国际通行标准存在差异， 会给酒精饮料制造商和进口 商， 特别是小企业带来额外的成本和负担。 建议美方维持现行法规， 不增加该条 款， 不强制要求标示 “单份份量、 每个容器的份数和每份纯乙醇的液盎司数”等 信息，以避免对贸易造成不必要的障碍。 4 of 4'}, {'source': 'DIRECT (NON-ATTACHMENT)', 'text': 'The attached comments are submitted (in English and in Chinese) on behalf of Jiao Yang, Deputy Director General of China's WTO/TBT National Notification & Enquiry Center.
'}]

comment_text_sources:
[{'source': 'DIRECT (NON-ATTACHMENT)', 'text': 'Dear Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau,

As a U.S. consumer, I do not believe current alcohol labels provide adequate information on alcohol content and nutrition. Please act swiftly to finalize the Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages proposed rule.

I appreciate all the food labeling regulations as I tuly believe haing this information does make a difference in my own health and those of my fellow citizens.

I have learned about the harmful effects of alcoholic beverages and have found that information.

Please work toward the labeling of alcoholic beverages.

Sincerely,
Penny P. Moreau

Sincerely,
Penny Moreau'}]
comment_text:
Dear Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau,

As a U.S. consumer, I do not believe current alcohol labels provide adequate information on alcohol content and nutrition. Please act swiftly to finalize the Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages proposed rule.

I appreciate all the food labeling regulations as I tuly believe haing this information does make a difference in my own health and those of my fellow citizens.

I have learned about the harmful effects of alcoholic beverages and have found that information.

Please work toward the labeling of alcoholic beverages.

Sincerely,
Penny P. Moreau

Sincerely,
Penny Moreau

comment_text_sources:
[{'source': 'DIRECT (NON-ATTACHMENT)', 'text': '1. Summary of the Regulation
This proposed TTB rule revises labeling, registration, and enforcement criteria for alcohol products to promote transparency on ingredients, health warnings, and environmental impact. By focusing on clear disclosures, it aims to advance consumer protection, facilitate equitable market access for small producers, and encourage more sustainable production practices.

2. Related Case Studies and Examples

Scottish Alcohol Labeling Initiative (Scotland)
- Scenario: Public Health Scotland found that clearer alcohol labeling helped reduce alcohol-related hospital admissions by 4% (source: Public Health Scotland, 2022, https://publichealthscotland.scot).
- Proposal: Adopt similarly prominent health disclaimers in the U.S. context, aligning with TTB’s efforts to include expanded warning text in labeling requirements.

California Sustainable Winegrowing Program (California)
- Scenario: This program’s rigorous environmental standards lowered water usage by 15% in participating vineyards (source: California Sustainable Winegrowing Alliance, 2021, https://www.sustainablewinegrowing.org).
- Proposal: Incorporate verifiable sustainability metrics in TTB labeling rules, giving producers the option to display recognized eco-certifications.

Alcohol Tax Reform (Iceland)
- Scenario: Iceland’s progressive tax structure, which adjusts levies based on alcohol content, helped reduce overall consumption (source: European Journal of Public Health, 2020, DOI:10.1093/eurpub/ckz185).
- Proposal: Explore targeted taxation strategies under TTB oversight that incentivize lower-alcohol or responsibly produced beverages.

Cooperative Brewing Ventures (Various U.S. States)
- Scenario: Worker-owned breweries in Oregon and Colorado reported increased employee retention and community engagement (source: Democracy at Work Institute, 2020, https://institute.coop).
- Proposal: Facilitate accessible TTB licensing pathways for cooperative models to expand equitable ownership in alcohol production.

3. Comments and Questions

On Proposed Section 4.2:
- Comment: “Requiring allergen disclosures is critical for public health. The rule should include clear thresholds for potential cross-contamination.”
- Supporting Evidence: CDC, 2022, allergic reaction data, https://www.cdc.gov

On Proposed Section 5.1:
- Comment: “Consider integrating standardized carbon footprint labeling to encourage sustainable practices, especially among craft producers.”
- Supporting Evidence: EPA, 2021, emissions reduction guidance, https://www.epa.gov

On Proposed Section 7.3:
- Question: “Does TTB plan to offer fee waivers or tiered fee structures to smaller, minority-owned distilleries that adopt these new labeling requirements?”
- Supporting Evidence: Small Business Administration, 2022, minority business development report, https://www.sba.gov

On Proposed Section 8.5:
- Comment: “Public health data indicate that stronger health warnings reduce alcohol misuse. Including new language reflecting current CDC findings could improve consumer awareness.”
- Supporting Evidence: CDC, 2023, alcohol-related harm statistics, https://www.cdc.gov

On Data Collection and Oversight:
- Question: “How will TTB verify labeling accuracy and ensure compliance without overburdening small producers?”
- Supporting Evidence: GAO, 2021, regulatory compliance best practices, https://www.gao.gov

4. References and Citations
- Public Health Scotland, 2022, “Alcohol Statistics and Trends,” https://publichealthscotland.scot
- California Sustainable Winegrowing Alliance, 2021, “Annual Sustainability Report,” https://www.sustainablewinegrowing.org
- European Journal of Public Health, 2020, “Alcohol Tax Policy in Iceland,” DOI:10.1093/eurpub/ckz185
- Democracy at Work Institute, 2020, “Worker-Owned Business Data,” https://institute.coop
- CDC, 2022, “Food Allergies and Reactions,” https://www.cdc.gov
- EPA, 2021, “Greenhouse Gas Reduction Guidelines,” https://www.epa.gov
- Small Business Administration, 2022, “Minority Business Ownership,” https://www.sba.gov
- CDC, 2023, “Alcohol and Public Health,” https://www.cdc.gov
- GAO, 2021, “Federal Regulatory Compliance,” https://www.gao.gov '}]

This proposed TTB rule revises labeling, registration, and enforcement criteria for alcohol products to promote transparency on ingredients, health warnings, and environmental impact. 2. Related Case Studies and Examples

Scottish Alcohol Labeling Initiative (Scotland)

California Sustainable Winegrowing Program (California)
- Scenario: This program’s rigorous environmental standards lowered water usage by 15% in participating vineyards (source: California Sustainable Winegrowing Alliance, 2021, https://www.sustainablewinegrowing.org).
