comment_text_sources:
[{'source': 'https://downloads.regulations.gov/TTB-2025-0002-0153/attachment_1.pdf', 'text': ' Comment on Proposed Rule: Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages (Docket No. TTB-2025-0002) Submitted by: Recover Alaska Date: August 7, 2025 To Whom It May Concern, Thank you for the opportunity to comment on the proposed rule to require Alcohol Facts labeling on wines, distilled spirits, and malt beverages. Recover Alaska strongly supports this rule as a long-overdue and commonsense step toward transparency that will help protect public health and empower consumers to make more informed choices. Recover Alaska is a statewide multi-sector coalition working to reduce excessive alcohol use and its harms across our state. Alaska experiences some of the highest alcohol-related death rates in the country. In 2021, our alcohol-induced mortality rate was more than twice the national average, and Alaska continues to grapple with the ripple effects of alcohol misuse—including high rates of suicide, domestic violence, and child maltreatment. These consequences are deeply felt in our rural and Tribal communities, which already face major health disparities and limited access to services. As a public health organization, we ﬁnd it unacceptable that alcohol—the only consumable product in the U.S. directly linked to seven types of cancer—is not required to carry a standard nutrition or content label. Consumers have a right to know what is in the products they consume, just as they do with food, tobacco, and other regulated substances. We urge TTB to ﬁnalize and strengthen this proposed rule in the following ways: 1. Require On-Package Alcohol Facts Labels Vital health information should not be relegated to QR codes or websites. Labels must appear directly on alcohol packaging to ensure accessibility—especially for people in rural or remote regions, older adults, and those without reliable internet or smartphones. In Alaska, this is particularly relevant where broadband access is limited and supply chains are complex. 2. Include Number of Standard Drinks and DGA Guidance To support informed drinking decisions, labels should include the number of standard drinks per container and refer to the Dietary Guidelines for Americans’ advice on moderate drinking. This helps consumers relate alcohol content to recommended limits and personal health goals. 3. Mandate Dual-Column and Expanded Nutrition Labeling Dual-column labeling (per serving and per container) should be mandatory, not voluntary. Many consumers unknowingly consume an entire container of alcohol in one sitting. Additionally, the Alcohol Facts panel should require disclosure of nutrients the DGA advises limiting: added sugars, saturated fat, and sodium. 4. Shorten the Compliance Period to 3.5 Years Public health and safety cannot wait ﬁve more years. A 3.5-year compliance period strikes a more appropriate balance between industry readiness and consumers’ right to know what they’re drinking. As communities and families in Alaska continue to face the heavy burden of alcohol- related harm, this rule represents a simple yet powerful step toward awareness, prevention, and accountability. We commend the TTB for proposing this rule and urge its swift adoption with the enhancements outlined above. Thank you for your leadership in protecting public health through meaningful, transparent alcohol policy. Sincerely, Tiffany Hall President & CEO Recover Alaska '}, {'source': 'DIRECT (NON-ATTACHMENT)', 'text': "To Whom It May Concern,
Thank you for the opportunity to comment on the proposed rule to require Alcohol Facts labeling on wines, distilled spirits, and malt beverages. Recover Alaska strongly supports this rule as a long-overdue and commonsense step toward transparency that will help protect public health and empower consumers to make more informed choices.
Recover Alaska is a statewide multi-sector coalition working to reduce excessive alcohol use and its harms across our state. Alaska experiences some of the highest alcohol-related death rates in the country. In 2021, our alcohol-induced mortality rate was more than twice the national average, and Alaska continues to grapple with the ripple effects of alcohol misuse—including high rates of suicide, domestic violence, and child maltreatment. These consequences are deeply felt in our rural and Tribal communities, which already face major health disparities and limited access to services.
As a public health organization, we find it unacceptable that alcohol—the only consumable product in the U.S. directly linked to seven types of cancer—is not required to carry a standard nutrition or content label. Consumers have a right to know what is in the products they consume, just as they do with food, tobacco, and other regulated substances.
We urge TTB to finalize and strengthen this proposed rule in the following ways:
1.Require On-Package Alcohol Facts Labels
Vital health information should not be relegated to QR codes or websites. Labels must appear directly on alcohol packaging to ensure accessibility—especially for people in rural or remote regions, older adults, and those without reliable internet or smartphones. In Alaska, this is particularly relevant where broadband access is limited and supply chains are complex.
2.Include Number of Standard Drinks and DGA Guidance
To support informed drinking decisions, labels should include the number of standard drinks per container and refer to the Dietary Guidelines for Americans’ advice on moderate drinking. This helps consumers relate alcohol content to recommended limits and personal health goals.
3.Mandate Dual-Column and Expanded Nutrition Labeling
Dual-column labeling (per serving and per container) should be mandatory, not voluntary. Many consumers unknowingly consume an entire container of alcohol in one sitting. Additionally, the Alcohol Facts panel should require disclosure of nutrients the DGA advises limiting: added sugars, saturated fat, and sodium.
4.Shorten the Compliance Period to 3.5 Years
Public health and safety cannot wait five more years. A 3.5-year compliance period strikes a more appropriate balance between industry readiness and consumers’ right to know what they’re drinking.
As communities and families in Alaska continue to face the heavy burden of alcohol-related harm, this rule represents a simple yet powerful step toward awareness, prevention, and accountability. We commend the TTB for proposing this rule and urge its swift adoption with the enhancements outlined above.
Thank you for your leadership in protecting public health through meaningful, transparent alcohol policy.
Sincerely,

Tiffany Hall
President & CEO
Recover Alaska

"}]
comment_text:
To Whom It May Concern,
Thank you for the opportunity to comment on the proposed rule to require Alcohol Facts labeling on wines, distilled spirits, and malt beverages. Recover Alaska strongly supports this rule as a long-overdue and commonsense step toward transparency that will help protect public health and empower consumers to make more informed choices.
Recover Alaska is a statewide multi-sector coalition working to reduce excessive alcohol use and its harms across our state. Alaska experiences some of the highest alcohol-related death rates in the country. In 2021, our alcohol-induced mortality rate was more than twice the national average, and Alaska continues to grapple with the ripple effects of alcohol misuse—including high rates of suicide, domestic violence, and child maltreatment. These consequences are deeply felt in our rural and Tribal communities, which already face major health disparities and limited access to services.
As a public health organization, we find it unacceptable that alcohol—the only consumable product in the U.S. directly linked to seven types of cancer—is not required to carry a standard nutrition or content label. Consumers have a right to know what is in the products they consume, just as they do with food, tobacco, and other regulated substances.
We urge TTB to finalize and strengthen this proposed rule in the following ways:
1.Require On-Package Alcohol Facts Labels
Vital health information should not be relegated to QR codes or websites. Labels must appear directly on alcohol packaging to ensure accessibility—especially for people in rural or remote regions, older adults, and those without reliable internet or smartphones. In Alaska, this is particularly relevant where broadband access is limited and supply chains are complex.
2.Include Number of Standard Drinks and DGA Guidance
To support informed drinking decisions, labels should include the number of standard drinks per container and refer to the Dietary Guidelines for Americans’ advice on moderate drinking. This helps consumers relate alcohol content to recommended limits and personal health goals.
3.Mandate Dual-Column and Expanded Nutrition Labeling
Dual-column labeling (per serving and per container) should be mandatory, not voluntary. Many consumers unknowingly consume an entire container of alcohol in one sitting. Additionally, the Alcohol Facts panel should require disclosure of nutrients the DGA advises limiting: added sugars, saturated fat, and sodium.
4.Shorten the Compliance Period to 3.5 Years
Public health and safety cannot wait five more years. A 3.5-year compliance period strikes a more appropriate balance between industry readiness and consumers’ right to know what they’re drinking.
As communities and families in Alaska continue to face the heavy burden of alcohol-related harm, this rule represents a simple yet powerful step toward awareness, prevention, and accountability. We commend the TTB for proposing this rule and urge its swift adoption with the enhancements outlined above.
Thank you for your leadership in protecting public health through meaningful, transparent alcohol policy.
Sincerely,

Tiffany Hall
President & CEO
Recover Alaska

[{'source': 'https://downloads.regulations.gov/TTB-2025-0002-0145/attachment_1.pdf', 'text': ' 
 
CAMPARI AMERICA LLC 
1114 Avenue of the Americas, 19th Floor – New York, New York 10036 – USA 
www.camparigroup.com 
 
 
 
August 7, 2025 
 
Via Electronic Submission 
 
Ms. Amy R. Greenberg 
Director 
Regulations and Rulings Division 
Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau 
1310 G Street, N.W., Box 12 
Washington, D.C.  20005  
 
Re:  Comments to TTB Notice No. 237: Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, 
Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages (Docket No. TTB–2025–0002) 
 
Dear Director Greenberg,  
 
Campari America LLC (“Campari America”), a producer and importer of distilled spirits in the 
United States, submits the following comments in response to the TTB’s Notice No. 237, “Alcohol Facts 
Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages ,” Docket No. TTB –2025–
0002.  Campari America is a subsidiary of Davide Campari -Milano N.V., which began in 1860 with its 
one eponymous brand.  Today, Campari America sells a wide range of beverage alcohol products in 
the United States, but is most well-known for its portfolio of liqueurs, including Campari, Aperol, Averna, 
Frangelico, Cynar, Braulio , and Grand Marnier .  Many of t hese brands, like those of many other 
suppliers, are not accurately represented in the TTB’s currently proposed serving size reference table, 
pasted below for reference, and which is the basis of our comment today.   
Serving size Alcohol percent by volume 
Wine Distilled spirits Malt beverages 
1.5 fl oz (44 mL), or 50 mL for 50 
mL containers of distilled spirits 
n/a > 24% > 24%. 
2.5 fl oz (74 mL) > 16, up to 24% > 16, up to 24% > 16, up to 24% 
5 fl oz (148 mL) 7 to 16% > 7, up to 16% > 7, up to 16% 
12 fl oz (355 mL) n/a ≤ 7% ≤ 7%. 
 
Proposed Serving Sizes Do Not Reflect How Low ABV Liqueurs Are Consumed in Cocktails 
 
The serving sizes recommended above are based in the assumption that the only means of 
drinking a wine, beer, or spirits beverage is straight, unmixed with other beverages.  While this may be 
mostly true for wine and beer, it is most certainly not true for distilled spirits which often serve as 
“ingredients” in a wide range of cocktails.  By way of example, Aperol , which has an ABV of 11%, is 
most commonly consumed in the form of an Aperol Spritz .  When making the brand’s signature 
cocktail, the typical amount of Aperol used is typically 2 ounces, i.e. less than half of what would be 
considered its reference serving size under the TTB’s proposal.  Another Aperol cocktail growing in 
Docusign Envelope ID: 4BF3A609-7A08-4604-B4FD-DE8BB7C974E2 
 
popularity is the Paper Plane (0.75 oz bourbon, 0.75 oz Aperol, 0.75 oz Amaro Nonino, and 0.75 oz 
lemon juice), in which the Aperol consumed is less than 1/5 of the TTB proposed serving size. 
Campari faces a similar issue.  While it can be served in a Campari Spritz (typically 1.5 to 2 
ounces), it is also popularly served in a Boulevardier (1 oz Campari, 1 .5 oz bourbon, and 1 oz sweet 
vermouth) or a Negroni (1 oz Campari, 1 oz gin, and 1 oz sweet vermouth) or a Negroni Sbagliato 
(substitute prosecco for gin ).  There is also the Americano (1oz Campari, 1oz sweet vermouth, and a 
splash of club soda) and the Garibaldi (1.5 oz Campari and the fresh juice of one orange, approximately 
4 oz). 
Examples of similar uses of other low-ABV liqueurs in cocktails abound.  Simply put, these are 
not products that are typically drunk straight.  So while the ABV of a lower proof distilled spirit may be 
similar to wine, it is not consumed in the same manner – thus using the same serving size as wine of 5 
oz., or even 2.5 oz, significantly overstates and distorts the actual serving size of these low ABV liqueurs 
in a way that is misleading and confusing for consumers.  
 
Proposed Serving Sizes Do Not Reflect How Ready-To-Drink Canned Products Are Consumed 
 
Conversely, for many other products, such as  ready-to-drink can s of  “hard” seltzers and 
cocktails, the currently proposed serving sizes greatly understate the actual serving sizes of these 
products.  These products are commonly sold in a 12 -oz can and can vary from 3.5% to 1 4% ABV.  
Spirits-based cocktails are not the only beverage alcohol products facing this issue:  many beers and 
other malt-based beverages now exceed 7% ABV yet are sold in the same 12 oz size cans.  Likewise, 
canned wines, with ABVs ranging from 8 to 15%, are also sold in sizes larger than the proposed serving 
size of 5 oz.  In these instances, having a serving size reference range that is less than the container 
size will certainly mislead consumers into thinking they are drinking less alcohol than they really are. 
 
Recommended Serving Sizes Already Have A Long-Established Framework and Methodology 
 
As a proposed solution, we recommend adopting an approach similar to  the methodology of 
the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) for recommended serving sizes for food and non-alcoholic 
beverages.  The FDA creates reference points, known as “Reference Amounts Customarily Consumed” 
or “RACCs,” for different categories of food and beverage, and the FDA then recommends that 
manufacturers use those RACCs as a guideline for determining their advertised serving sizes.   
 
In the food and non -alcoholic beverage realm, FDA-required labelling became required in the 
1990s.  Consumers are long accustomed to this method of calculation of serving facts, with 
recommended or actual consumption amounts being the guiding factor in determining the size.   The 
general understanding of most consumers is that a serving size reflects the size portion of intended or 
typical consumption, or, in the case of single -serve packs, the container size, rather than being based 
on the amount of one of its components .  One analogy would be if the FDA mandated serving sizes 
based on the grams of protein in a product, such as 5g of protein equals one serving size.  This would 
result in a double serving size for a granola bar, and a very small serving size for beef jerky.  Similarly, 
the TTB’s proposed serving sizes are based on the amount of alcohol in a product, resulting in arbitrary 
and sometimes incorrect serving sizes.  The current proposed TTB’s serving sizes would conflict with 
Docusign Envelope ID: 4BF3A609-7A08-4604-B4FD-DE8BB7C974E2 
 
the general understanding of most consumers who have been conditioned for decades to perceive a 
serving size as the recommended amount and/or most customarily consumed amount. 
 
If the TTB were to adopt a serving size reference range that mirrors the FDA ’s process, this 
would allow consumers to buy products and understand serving sizes within a framework that they 
already know and are familiar with from the food and non -alcoholic beverage space.  This w ould also 
accommodate the realities of the types of drinks that consumers are currently havin g or making w ith 
beverage alcohol in the 4% to 30% ABV range and would minimize consumer confusion over  serving 
size, especially with respect to ready-to-drink canned products. 
 
Alternatively, if the TTB wants to maintain the serving size reference ranges proposed in Notice 
No. 237, then another recommendation would be for the TTB to allow an exception for suppliers to 
deviate from the proposed serving size reference range if they  can demonstrate that the proposed 
serving size does not reflect the actual amount of their product that is typically consumed.  This would 
allow the TTB to maintain the current framework but still provide flexibility for those suppliers whose  
products are typically consumed as one part of a cocktails. 
 
We thank you for your consideration of our comments.  If you have any questions or require 
additional information, please do not hesitate to contact me at sarah.bradley@campari.com. 
 
Sincerely, 
 
 
 
Sarah Bradley 
General Counsel, Americas and APAC 
 
Docusign Envelope ID: 4BF3A609-7A08-4604-B4FD-DE8BB7C974E2

comment_text_sources:
[{'source': 'https://downloads.regulations.gov/TTB-2025-0002-0154/attachment_1.pdf', 'text': ' COMMENTS FROM THE EUROPEAN UNION REGARDING NOTIFICATION G/TBT/N/USA/2183 and G/TBT/N/USA/2182 Allergen and Nutrition Labeling for Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages The European Union (EU) would like to thank the authorities of the United States of America for providing the opportunity to comment on the draft “ Major Food Allergen Labeling for Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages ”, notified on 22 January 2025 as G/TBT/N/USA/2183. The mandatory labelling of ‘Major Food Allergen’ referred to in the US proposed rulemaking includes fish ingredients. The listing of ‘fish’ would also be required when the processing aid isinglass or fish gelatine is used as a fining agent to clarify wines and beers. At a global level, in a report (1) published last year, the FAO/WHO estimated the exposure details including gelatine and isinglass in wine and beer. The Expert Committee concluded that for the curren tly accepted exemptions (i.e. in the European Union , Australia, New Zealand, Argentina, Paraguay) there is an established history of safe consumption and that the exposure estimates at the reference dose - RfD/30 - level appears to provide an adequate marg in of exposure for derivative safety assessment. The EU invites the United States to consider the possible exclusion of isinglass or fish gelatine as a processing aid in wine and beer from mandatory allergen labelling. As regards the “ Alcohol Facts Stateme nts in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages” notified on 22 January 2025 as G/TBT/N/USA/2182, the EU invites the United States of America to take into account Codex Guidelines on the use of technology to provide food information in food labelling (CXG 105- 2024) and to consider whether some or all of the mandatory information particulars included in the “Alcohol Facts” could be provided to consumers using technology such as QR codes instead of on-pack labelling. The EU would furthermore like to highlight that none of the Codex standards or guidelines requires the mandatory indication of the quantity of pure ethyl alcohol on alcoholic beverages and that, contrary to the alcohol content by volume, this information is nearly never indicated on traded alcoholic beverages. Finally, concerning the proposed transition period, the EU welcomes the proposed 5-years. In a similar vein, the EU requests that the United States grants the operators a possibility to exhaust all their stock which was put on the market before the proposed rule comes into effect. (1) FAO/WHO Report – Risk Assessment of Food Allergens; https://www.who.int/publications/i/item/9789240088924 2 The EU would be grateful if the above -mentioned comments could be taken into account and replied to before adoption of the notified draft. *** Electronically signed on 07/08/2025 11:43 (UTC+02) in accordance with Article 11 of Commission Decision (EU) 2021/2121 '}, {'source': 'DIRECT (NON-ATTACHMENT)', 'text': 'These comments are submitted on behalf of the European Commission, DG Internal Market, Industry, Entrepreneurship and SMEs (GROW) International Value Chains – A3.
'}]

comment_text_sources:
[{'source': 'DIRECT (NON-ATTACHMENT)', 'text': 'See attached comments on behalf of the Kentucky Distillers' Association. Thank you for your consideration.

T. Neal Morris'}, {'source': 'https://downloads.regulations.gov/TTB-2025-0002-0157/attachment_1.pdf', 'text': 'T. NEAL MORRIS nmorris@mcbravelfi rm. com MEElRAYER 20I EAST MAIN STREET, SUITE 9OO LEXINGTON, KY 40507 859.23 l .8780 EXT. 1259 FAX:859.231.1175 l August 8,2025 Uploaded to Regulations.sov Director Regulations and Rulings Division Alcohol and Tobacco Trade and Tax Bureau 1310 G Street NW, Box l2 Washington, DC 20005 RE Notice No.os 237 & 238 - Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages; and Major Food Allergen Labeling for Wineso Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages Comments of the Kentuckv Distillers' Association Dear Director, We are outside counsel for the Kentucky Distillers' Association, located in Frankfort, Kentucky ("KDA"). The KDA is comprised of seventy-two distilled spirits producers licensed and permitted in the Commonwealth of Kentucky, and the KDA and its membership is thankful for the opportunity to provide high-level comments on potential labelling changes for nutritional and allergen information on spirits packaging. While the Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau ("TTB") has issued two notices of proposed rulemaking on complex labeling changes, we are choosing to submit comments to both under a unified response as these issues are directly linked and raise similar concerns for Kentucky's spirits industry. Please accept the following as the KDA's comments relative to both Docket TTB-2025-002 (Notice No. 237) and Docket TTB-2025-003 (Notice No. 238), relating to proposed changes to TTB regulations to require the inclusion of alcohol fact and major food allergen statements on labels of distilled spirits. Since the KDA's founding in 1880, our mission has been to passionately and responsibly promote, protect and elevate Kentucky's signature Bourbon and Distilled Spirits Industry. We produce an estimated ninety-five percent (95%) of the world's supply of Bourbon and our members have operations across the spirits categories. As such, significant changes to current regulations would have an outsized financial and administrative impact on our members. Law Offices: Lexington I Louisville I Frankfort Govennment Affains: Frankfont mcbnayenf inm.comMtrBRAYER Regulations and Rulings Division Alcohol and Tobacco Trade and Tax Bureau August 8,2025 Page 2 1. Increased Cost Burden to Producers The KDA requests that TTB recognize that, first and foremost, the costs associated with the proposed label changes would be significant for large and craft producers alike. Nutritional sampling and testing would add substantial expense to distilling operations and be unduly burdensome for smaller distillers who lack the staff and capital to add this process. Additionally, reformatting and reprinting labels would be an expensive undertaking. With our members producing so many different stock keeping units ("SKUs"), these costs would be astronomical right out of the gate and the continued testing would be cost prohibitive. It is also important to note that so much information is already federally mandated to be on spirits labels. Significant and meaningful data is already provided on spirits labels, and any additions must balance consumer demand for information with economic and logistical considerations, such as testing costs, limited labeling space, and expensive packaging changes. Consumers trust what is labeled now and additional labeling real estate devoted to unnecessary information might confuse the public, or worse, have them ignore key labeling information altogether. 2. Alcohol Fact Statement Creating Confusion The proposed requirements for the Alcohol Facts statement also introduces redundancy to existing labeling requirements by requiring the percentage of alcohol by volume ("ABV") be restated on the Alcohol Facts statement, in addition to the requirement that ABV be presented on the front label. However, the proposal goes further by requiring that the total quantity of pure ethyl alcohol be stated in fluid ounces as well, which will result in customer confusion. Customers are not used to seeing the quantity of alcohol in a beverage being quantified in fluid ounces of pure ethyl alcohol. By redundantly including the ABV on the Alcohol Facts statement in combination with a new measurement of quantity of alcohol in a product, customers will be confused if those measurements are in conflict or misinterpret the label entirely. Further, as identified by TTB in Notice No. 238, the distillation process removes proteins and the resulting spirits are therefore devoid of proteins. Yet, the proposed Alcohol Facts statement would require distilled spirits to state the amount of protein in the product, which will be zero. This would create customer confusion as a customer would reasonably assume that seeing protein on a bottle of distilled spirits means that there are some distilled spirits that do contain proteins. tMtrBRAYER Regulations and Rulings Division Alcohol and Tobacco Trade and Tax Bureau August 8,2025 Page 3 The KDA does not support the proposed Alcohol Facts statement as proposed due to the inclusion of the fluid ounces of pure alcohol and proteins. 3. Digital Labeling Options Spirits labels currently carry an abundance of consumer information. As discussed, to keep consumers' attention and give them the ability to learn more about certain products, a digital label or QR code would be a widely-accepted solution. Such an approach would boost consumer confidence in the product and give buyers an easy 'click through' for the latest and more in-depth product information. Moreover, digital labeling supports sustainability by reducing the need for printing new labels every time regulations change, which can have significant environmental impacts. The widespread use of smartphones in the U.S. (with almost ninety-seven percent (97%) ownership) makes digital labeling a practical solution for helping consumers make informed choices about dietary information while having less environmental effects. 4. Major Allergens and the Distillation Process As TTB properly observed, the distillation process removes all proteins - including gluten - and major allergens from the resulting spirits. The end result of a proper distillation produces an entirely gluten and allergen free spirit. Because distilled spirits do not contain allergens or gluten post-distillation, the KDA supports the exception provided for in proposed 27 CFR $ 5.75(bX2) specifically exempting distilled spirits from disclosing allergens or proteins, unless allergens or proteins are introduced post-distillation. The KDA would suggest that the inclusion of language in the exemption regarding TTB's testing of distilled spirits clarify that such testing will be on a case-by- case basis, and not create a regulatory burden for distilled spirit plants and the TTB itself by requiring lab analysis of every product. If the proposed exception for distilled spirits is not included in the final rulemaking, then the KDA opposes the requirement to disclose allergens and proteins due to the scientific fact that protein and allergens are removed from the final distillation product. Adding protein, not to mention other ingredients, to spirits labels would cause tremendous consumer confusion-particularly those consumers who are trying to be 'gluten-free' due to diet or health concems. These consumers might not be aware about gluten being removed from distillation and may misread bottles containing mash bill information or just protein on the nutrition label and assume it is not safe to consume. Including more language on already crowded distilled spirit labels will only amplifu theMEElRAYERI Regulations and Rulings Division Alcohol and Tobacco Trade and Tax Bureau August 8,2025 Page 4 potential to confuse customers while creating misunderstanding among potential customers. 5. Conclusion As TTB considers additional labeling and allergen information, it is important to consider how highly regulated the spirits industry already is. From traditional regulations that consumers know and trust like the standards of identity that codifu Bourbon and other spirits, to proof, age-requirements, and government warning labels, consumers are already well-educated about distilled spirits products. Adding more could create nothing more than confusion and indifference, all while adding burdensome costs and testing inefficiencies. Sincerely, RRIS TNM 4904-9883-6316, v. 1'}]

comment_text_sources:
[{'source': 'https://downloads.regulations.gov/TTB-2025-0002-0158/attachment_1.pdf', 'text': "10, Rue Pergolèse – 75116 PARIS – Tel +33 1 45 22 75 73 – contact@fevs.com  
 
 
 
 
August 11
th, 2025 
 
 
Comments filed on behalf of FEVS (Fédération des Exportateurs de Vins et Spiritueux de France) 
 
Filed via www.regulations.gov 
 
 
Re: TTB‐2025‐0002: Alcohol Facts Statements in the labelling of wines, distilled spirits, and malt beverages 
 
 
The French Federation of Wine and Spirits Exporters (FEVS), appreciates the opportunity to submit comments 
on Notice No. 238 relative to Major Food Allergen Labelling for Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages. 
 
FEVS is the trade association representing the wine and spirit exporting companies of France. FEVS's 
membership comprises around 600 companies, international corporations as well as small businesses, with 
exports around 15.6 billion Euros in 2024 ($ 16.2 billion). The United States is the largest market in value for 
French wine and spirits exports worldwide (€3.8 billion / $3.9 billion). 
 
FEVS and its members are committed to providing wines and spirits in all price ranges to the American 
consumers, while ensuring that consumers are provided with adequate information as to the identity and 
quality of the wines and spirits they purchase. 
 
Therefore, FEVS is pleased to provide the following comments on TTB’s proposed rulemaking. 
 
 
On the title of the Alcohol Beverage Information Statement 
 
FEVS encourages TTB to adopt the tile “Serving Facts” rather than “Alcohol Facts”, as the proposed content 
of the statement refers to nutrition information in a serving of a specific alcoholic beverage, rather than 
information on alcohol. Therefore, the title “Alcohol Facts” could confuse consumers as it may suggest that 
the statement includes general indication on the consumption of alcoholic beverages. 
 
In addition, consumers are accustomed to the title “ Serving Facts” and to the fact that this is related to 
nutrition information of the beverage they intend to purchase or consume, since most operators who 
currently voluntarily disclose nutrition information use “ Serving Facts ”, as acknowledged by TTB in the 
Notice. As a consequence, choosing the “ Serving Facts” title would also limit costs of re -labelling for these 
operators. 
 
Lastly, FEVS believes that the similarity between “ Serving Facts”, which could apply to alcoholic beverages 
regulated under IRC, and “ Nutrition Facts”, required for alcoholic beverages regulated under FDA rules, is 
more beneficial to consumers as it ensures a kind of coherence on how the nutrition information is provided 
for all products proposed for sale on the market – even if the content of their respective statement may differ 
as proposed by TTB for the former. 
 
2 
On the content of the Alcohol Beverage Information Statement 
 
FEVS thanks TTB to take into account particularities of the wines and spirits production process and sector 
by proposing a content of a nutrition statement which is specific to alcoholic beverages compared to what 
is required for other food products through the FDA Nutrition Facts label. 
 
Nevertheless, FEVS would like to underline that wine or spirits do not contain fat or proteins and is wondering 
whether the compulsory presence of these two elements in a n Alcohol Beverage Information Statement 
would provide useful information to consumers when choosing which alcoholic beverage they want to 
purchase or drink. Whether TTB decides to keep these two elements and considering the limited space of 
wine and spirits labels, FEVS suggests allowing operators to replace these two lines by a unique sentence like 
“Contains negligible amounts of proteins and fat” at the bottom of the Statement. 
 
FEVS takes note of the voluntary sugar content  statement as proposed by TTB. In case operators choose to 
indicate it, FEVS kindly requests TTB to clarify how precisely they will have to label it and how the articulation 
with the carbohydrates content TTB intends to require will have to be made. 
 
More globally, FEVS would like to raise the attention of TTB regarding the difficulty adding other elements 
to the content of the Alcohol Beverage Information Statement, including through a voluntary approach, 
because of: 
• the non-relevance of nutrients like sodium, cholesterol, saturated fat… for alcoholic beverages, 
• the risk introducing nutrients like vitamins or minerals or percentage of the daily value may lead to 
unintended alcohol consumption behaviors, 
• the fact that the more information is added within the Alcohol Beverage Information Statement, the 
more the impact of the most relevant ones for consumers, notably calories, will be diluted, 
• the limited space available on wine and spirits packaging (compared to other food products), 
• the difficulty for operators to put in place the full traceability, risk assessment and analytical procedures 
to guarantee the loyalty and accurate content of such information, 
• the possible impact of such requirement on a trade perspective, for products imported into the US as 
well as for US wine and spirits exported to third countries. 
 
In case TTB is willing to require or to give operators the possibility to include additional elements in the 
Alcohol Beverage Information Statement, FEVS strongly encourages TTB to allow this statement to be 
provided by electronic means like QR-Code (see below). 
 
Finally, FEVS welcomes the tolerance of 20% above or below proposed by TTB as well as the use of “typical 
value” charts in order to ease the ability of wine and spirits operators, especially SMEs, fulfilling the envisaged 
requirements. FEVS strongly encourages TTB to work as far as possible with US trade partners to develop a 
coordinated approach on these “typical values”. 
 
FEVS would like also to stress the importance of including in the TTB regulation the notion of  “average 
values” a s defined by Codex Alimentarius for the nutrition declaration
1. Being complementary to 
tolerances, “average values” would allow operators to provide accurate information to consumers while 
avoiding the re-labelling of their products each year because of crops or evolution of the production method. 
 
 
On the alcohol content statement 
 
FEVS takes note of the TTB proposal requiring an alcohol content statement, expressed as a percentage of 
alcohol by volume, on the labels of all alcohol beverages products, as well as an indication of this statement 
 
1 See Point 3.5 of the Guidelines on Nutrition Labelling: “The values used in nutrient declaration should be weighted average values 
derived from data speciﬁcally obtained from analyses of products which are representative of the product being labelled.” 3 
within the existing  tolerances (in substitution of an indication in terms of ranges). This is aligned with EU 
rules and will ensure consistency in the presentation of products regardless of their alcohol content. 
 
FEVS would also appreciate whether TTB could clarify if this requirement would apply to non-alcoholic wines 
(less than 0.5% alcohol by volume) sold on the US market, too. 
 
On the other hand, FEVS asks TTB not to require the inclusion of the alcohol content in the Alcohol Beverage 
Information Statement. While practical modalities regarding the placement of the alcohol content may differ 
between malt beverages, distilled spirits or wines, c onsumers are used to find this information in the same 
field of vision of other compulsory particulars. In addition, under current TTB regulations, the alcohol content 
has to be labelled in a bigger type size than other compulsory information. Therefore, FEVS does not see why 
including alcohol content in the Alcohol Beverage Information Statement, among several other elements 
related to the product, will guarantee a better visibility or understanding for consumers. 
 
If TTB want s nevertheless going forward on this, FEVS kindly recommends proposing it as an option for 
operators, allowing them the possibility either to indicate the alcohol content as it is today or to include it in 
the Alcohol Beverage Information Statement. 
 
FEVS would also like to share concerns regarding the compulsory indication of the alcohol content in fluid 
ounces of pure alcohol. Firstly, concept of pure alcohol is not always well understood by consumers. Thus, 
providing this information without context would not necessarily empower consumers to make informed 
choices or to understand why and how it differs from the alcohol content expressed in volume by alcohol.  
Second, FEVS notes that TTB is allowing operators, in addition to these two elements, to indicate the alcohol 
content in degrees of proof ; meaning the same information could appear in three different forms in the 
Alcohol Beverage Information Statement. 
 
Beyond issues related to limited available space o n labels and to the complexity for foreign operators who 
do not usually use the fluid ounces of pure alcohol as unit of measurement, FEVS fears the proposed approach 
could lead to an important risk of confusion by consumers. 
 
In addition, FEVS tends to consider that a “per serving size” presentation could increase the difficulties for 
consumers to fully understand the elements provided in the Alcohol Beverage Information Statement. As 
rightly pointed out in the Notice, serving size reference amounts could be considered  by consumers as a 
recommended consumption amount rather than a way to determine the  alcohol, nutrient or calorie intake 
of a specific beverage. Besides, since serving size would have to differ depending on  the alcohol content of 
the product, this will prevent consumers from making comparisons between several alcoholic beverages on 
their respective nutritional impact, due to the lack of an identical basis for comparison. 
 
This approach will also lead to additional complexity for wine and spirits companies, especially exporters who 
are not used to managing serving size and/or will have to manage specific ones for the US market. 
 
FEVS would also like to recall that Codex Alimentarius recommends that the nutrition declaration should be 
expressed per 100 ml and “in addition, this information may be given per serving as quantified on the label“
2. 
 
Whether TTB confirms its intention to request nutrition information to be provided in pure alcohol per 
serving, FEVS strongly suggests TTB to allow the electronic display of these elements. Indeed, the presence 
of a QR -Code on a label could facilitate the provision of substantive information on the concepts of pure 
alcohol and standard drinks, including in relation with the US Dietary Guidelines for Americans  if relevant, 
which would not be practically feasible on a physical label. It  would also reduce the conformity c osts for 
operators, especially those non-US based,  thanks to  automatic calculation of nutrition content of their 
product and conversion of the figures into US unit measures (see below). 
 
 
 
2 See Point 3.4.2 and 3.43 of the Guidelines on Nutrition Labelling 4 
On the Alcohol Beverages Information Statement disclosure 
 
While acknowledging the flexibilities proposed by TTB for the display of the Alcohol Beverages Information 
Statement (ie, linear display option and lesser rules in terms of format and size on the panel), FEVS strongly 
reiterates its call to TTB for allowing these information to be distributed by electronic means. 
 
As previously raised, electronic labelling offers a wide range of advantages to both consumers and operators, 
especially SMEs. Indeed, this digital mean makes it possible: 
• for companies, to have a tool adapted to the variability of wines and spirits, thus limiting the costs of 
modifying packaging, while guaranteeing the loyalty of the information,  
• for the consumer, an easy and permanent access to information (including for people with disabilities), 
updated in real time and in his own language (in or outside the US territory), 
• for public authorities, to avoid the creation of barriers to trade by facilitating convergence of standards 
and administrative cooperation: 
o between the United States and wine and spirits exporting countries, 
o between federal regulations and the increasing number of labelling requirements in force at 
State level (e.g. with regard to beverage packaging deposits schemes). 
 
It also has to be noted that technological challenges (like adequacy of cellular or Wi-Fi coverage) or ability to 
access for particular communities are evolving very quickly, having in mind any final rule on Alcohol Beverage 
Information Statement would only apply in more than five years from now. 
 
In the EU, the labelling of energy and nutrition information and the list of ingredients is compulsory for wine 
products since December 2023 and the spirits sector commit to provide these information on a voluntary 
basis. The EU experience demonstrates the possibility of using the advantages of the QR -Code without 
lowering the ability of consumers to access  key information for their health and for making informed 
choice. Indeed, for companies willing to use digital means, EU regulations oblige them to indicate the calories 
amount as well as the allergens on the physical label, while other information, compulsory or not, are 
displayed online, via a direct and free of marketing information link. 
 
FEVS would like to underline how aligning EU and US requirements on nutrition and energy information 
would be beneficial for economic operators on both sides of the Atlantic, while allowing each party to keep 
its own preference on the content of the information to be provided according to its respective context. This 
would also allow the EU  and US to set a global standard which could support the development of digital 
technologies and avoid trade barriers in third countries market. 
 
In the case of physical labelling, FEVS requests to remove the black box around the Alcohol Beverage 
Information Statement, especially when provided in a linear format . This appear not to be proportionate 
or justified as the title “ Serving Facts” in bold type on a defined space which is a label is sufficient to allow 
consumers to easily locate the information on the packaging. 
 
On the implementation period 
 
FEVS welcomes the proposed 5-year transition period as well as the exemption from requiring new COLA 
when the only change being made to a label is the inclusion or alteration of the statement. 
 
In addition, FEVS kindly requests an unlimited inventory exhaustion clause which would allow operators to 
put on the US market products labelled in accordance with the current rules but before the entry into force 
of any compulsory labelling requirement of major food allergens. 
 
Finally, if TTB adopt s a final rule on Major Food Allergens labelling (as envisaged in Notice  of proposed 
rulemaking No. 238), FEVS asks for an identical date of entry into force for both regulations . This will 
prevent operators changing their label twice, with the disproportionate cost this approach could have for 
them, especially for SMEs. "}, {'source': 'DIRECT (NON-ATTACHMENT)', 'text': 'Please, find enclosed comments on behalf of the Fédération des Exportateurs de Vins & Spiritueux de France (FEVS)'}]
comment_title: Comment 155:  Fédération des Exportateurs de Vins & Spiritueux de France (FEVS)
comment_text: Please, find enclosed comments on behalf of the Fédération des Exportateurs de Vins & Spiritueux de France (FEVS)
document_title: Notice No. 237:  Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages

comment_text_sources:
[{'source': 'DIRECT (NON-ATTACHMENT)', 'text': '
I am a prevention specialist and mother of a daughter in recovery. Her drug of choice was alcohol. Please consider labeling alcoholic beverages in a way that clearly informs consumers about the calories, alcohol and nutrient content and any risks associated with the product.
All other products we consume have basic nutrient, calorie, allergen, and ingredient information, but when it comes to alcohol consumers are left in the dark by the lack of labeling.
Excess alcohol consumption is associated with various harms including injuries, motor vehicle accidents, liver disease, cardiovascular disease, and certain cancers.
Consumers must be better informed.
I agree that the “Alcohol Facts” disclosure should be required to appear on-package and never solely via electronic means (a QR code leading to a webpage), as this would place a barrier between consumers and this vital information and specifically disadvantage populations that are less able to utilize smart phones or similar technology (e.g., those who are older, lower income, or living rurally or on tribal land).
In order to provide consumers with access to this long-overdue, basic information, TTB should adopt a shorter compliance period of 3.5 years instead of the 5-year period proposed
In summary please adopt clear labeling requirements to inform consumers about nutritional content, calories, alcohol content and warnings about cancer and other potential health hazards associated with alcoholic beverages.
Thank you for your consideration.'}]
comment_text:
I am a prevention specialist and mother of a daughter in recovery. Her drug of choice was alcohol. Please consider labeling alcoholic beverages in a way that clearly informs consumers about the calories, alcohol and nutrient content and any risks associated with the product.
All other products we consume have basic nutrient, calorie, allergen, and ingredient information, but when it comes to alcohol consumers are left in the dark by the lack of labeling.
Excess alcohol consumption is associated with various harms including injuries, motor vehicle accidents, liver disease, cardiovascular disease, and certain cancers.
Consumers must be better informed.
I agree that the “Alcohol Facts” disclosure should be required to appear on-package and never solely via electronic means (a QR code leading to a webpage), as this would place a barrier between consumers and this vital information and specifically disadvantage populations that are less able to utilize smart phones or similar technology (e.g., those who are older, lower income, or living rurally or on tribal land).
In order to provide consumers with access to this long-overdue, basic information, TTB should adopt a shorter compliance period of 3.5 years instead of the 5-year period proposed
In summary please adopt clear labeling requirements to inform consumers about nutritional content, calories, alcohol content and warnings about cancer and other potential health hazards associated with alcoholic beverages.
Thank you for your consideration.
document_title: Notice No. 237:  Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages

comment_text_sources:
[{'source': 'https://downloads.regulations.gov/TTB-2025-0002-0156/attachment_1.docx', 'text': '**Comments from Argentina – Notice No. 237: Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages**

Title of the Alcohol Beverage Information Statement

*We consider that the title “Alcohol Facts” better describe the information provided inthe proposed statement.*

Mandatory Calorie and Nutrient Information

*Following the same rationale applied to nutritional information, sugar content should remain voluntary. If most alcohol beverages contain only minimal or negligible amounts of sugar, requiring its inclusion would provide little added value to consumers. Similarly, we agree with TTB’s assessment that sodium and other micronutrients should not be included, and we believe they should not be referenced in the proposal at all.*

*We believe that including daily value percentages for nutrients on alcohol beverage labels would be confusing for consumers. Such information could misleadingly suggest that alcohol contributes meaningfully to meeting daily nutritional requirements, which is not the case. Given the fundamental differences between alcoholic beverages and foods, adopting the Nutrition Facts format used by the FDA would not be appropriate in this context.*

*Given that many alcoholic beverages contain negligible amounts of nutrients beyond calories, requiring full nutrition facts similar to FDA food labels could be unnecessarily burdensome and confusing, potentially disadvantaging certain products in both domestic and international markets.*

Calculating Panel Elements and Tolerance Levels

*We support the proposed tolerances of ±20% and the use of "typical values" as a valid alternative to mandatory testing. Allowing broad tolerances and the use of tables or calculation methods to estimate nutrient levels is important to keep costs down and maintain competitiveness. Requiring precise in-house testing or sending products to third-party labs would create significant financial challenges, especially for small producers who make small batches and cannot spread testing costs over many units.*

Mandatory Listing of Alcohol by Volume on All Alcohol Beverage Products

*We have no objections to the proposal requiring an alcohol content statement expressed as a percentage of alcohol by volume on all alcohol beverage labels. This requirement does not pose any issues, as it is already mandatory in Argentina to indicate the alcohol content on all wines. Such labeling ensures transparency for consumers and aligns with existing international practices.*

Placement of Alcohol Content Statements as Part of the Alcohol Facts Statement

*While it is likely that including alcohol content information within the Alcohol Facts statement could make it easier for consumers to locate this information, this advantage may not be particularly significant. Consumers are generally accustomed to looking for alcohol content in various parts of the label, and the overall impact on their ability to find this information is expected to be minimal.*

*The implications of including the alcohol content within the Alcohol Facts statement should be carefully analyzed to avoid the requirement of declaring the alcohol content in two separate locations on the label. According to the World Wine Trade Group (WWTG) Agreement on Requirements for Wine Labeling, wines may display common mandatory information (CMI), including alcohol content, anywhere on the container’s surface visible within a single field of vision. This approach helps ensure clarity and prevents redundant labeling. Therefore, it is necessary to ensure compliance with the agreements established within the WWTG. If the information must appear in multiple locations on the label, this could increase label redesign and printing costs. Additionally, unclear placement requirements might lead to confusion among producers, complicating compliance efforts and potentially increasing administrative burdens. Moreover, having the alcohol content displayed in two different places with differing values could lead to labeling errors and mislead consumers.*

Mandatory Statement of Alcohol in Fluid Ounces of Pure Alcohol per Serving

*If it is mandatory to indicate the alcohol content as a percentage by volume, requiring additional information about the alcohol content per serving size or standard drink would be redundant and could potentially confuse or mislead consumers. Providing multiple measures of alcohol content on the label may create inconsistency and make it harder for consumers to clearly understand the actual alcohol strength of the product.*

Linear Display, Type Size, and Electronic Display of Alcohol Facts Information

a. Linear Display

*We believe it would be appropriate to provide the option for Alcohol Facts information to be presented either in a panel or linear format, as proposed.*

b. Type Size

*We agree with the proposal that the minimum type size requirements for Alcohol Facts statements should mirror the existing type size requirements for mandatory information*

c. Electronic Display of Alcohol Facts Information

*We suggest allowing the possibility of using electronic means, such as QR codes, to present this information, especially for small containers or labels with limited space, while ensuring that mandatory physical labeling remains the minimum requirement.*

Serving Size Reference Amounts

*Proposed serving size amounts should be reference values only. Each consumer, if interested, can evaluate their total intake of alcohol, nutrients, and calories when consuming amounts greater than the reference serving size. The reference amounts serve their purpose by providing a consistent basis for labeling and informing consumer choices without implying a recommended level of consumption.*

*According to Wine in Moderation, the reference consumption guidelines are: up to 2 units of alcohol per day for women (equivalent to approximately 200 ml of wine at 12.5% ABV), and up to 3 units per day for men (approximately 300 ml of wine at 12.5% ABV). Additionally, no more than 4 units of alcohol should be consumed on a single drinking occasion.*

Dual-Column Alcohol Facts Panel Display

*We agree with allowing the option to present Alcohol Facts in a dual-column format.*

*We also support the proposal requiring containers with a net content of more than 100 percent but less than 200 percent of a single serving size reference amount to be labeled as containing a single serving.*

Implementation Period

*The proposed 5-year compliance period for the new labeling regulations is both adequate and reasonable, as it allows the industry ample time to adapt gradually without imposing excessive economic or operational pressures. This timeframe helps minimize costs and facilitates a smooth transition toward more comprehensive and transparent labeling for consumers.*

*However, a shorter period (e.g., 3 years) could be considered only if the labeling is limited to basic elements (alcohol content and calories) and does not include a broader set of nutrients or ingredient declarations.*

*It is likely that some industry members will choose to begin implementing the labeling changes before the official compliance date. Many producers may prefer to adapt to the new requirements earlier to stay ahead of regulations and manage inventory efficiently.*

*Furthermore, it is essential that new label approval applications (COLA) are not required when changes are limited to the inclusion or modification of nutritional information, such as the Alcohol Facts panel or data on calories and alcohol content.*'}, {'source': 'https://downloads.regulations.gov/TTB-2025-0002-0156/attachment_1.pdf', 'text': 'Comments from Argentina – Notice No. 237: Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, 
Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages
Title of the Alcohol Beverage Information Statement
We consider that the title “Alcohol Facts” better describe the information provided inthe proposed 
statement.
Mandatory Calorie and Nutrient Information
Following the same rationale applied to nutritional information, sugar content should remain voluntary. If 
most alcohol beverages contain only minimal or negligible amounts of sugar, requiring its inclusion would 
provide little added value to consumers. Similarly, we agree with TTB’s assessment that sodium and other 
micronutrients should not be included, and we believe they should not be referenced in the proposal at all.
We believe that including daily value percentages for nutrients on alcohol beverage labels would be 
confusing for consumers. Such information could misleadingly suggest that alcohol contributes 
meaningfully to meeting daily nutritional requirements, which is not the case. Given the fundamental 
differences between alcoholic beverages and foods, adopting the Nutrition Facts format used by the FDA 
would not be appropriate in this context.
Given that many alcoholic beverages contain negligible amounts of nutrients beyond calories, requiring 
full nutrition facts similar to FDA food labels could be unnecessarily burdensome and confusing, potentially 
disadvantaging certain products in both domestic and international markets.
Calculating Panel Elements and Tolerance Levels
We support the proposed tolerances of ±20% and the use of "typical values" as a valid alternative to 
mandatory testing. Allowing broad tolerances and the use of tables or calculation methods to estimate 
nutrient levels is important to keep costs down and maintain competitiveness. Requiring precise in-house 
testing or sending products to third-party labs would create significant financial challenges, especially for 
small producers who make small batches and cannot spread testing costs over many units. 
Mandatory Listing of Alcohol by Volume on All Alcohol Beverage Products
We have no objections to the proposal requiring an alcohol content statement expressed as a percentage 
of alcohol by volume on all alcohol beverage labels. This requirement does not pose any issues, as it is 
already mandatory in Argentina to indicate the alcohol content on all wines. Such labeling ensures 
transparency for consumers and aligns with existing international practices.
Placement of Alcohol Content Statements as Part of the Alcohol Facts Statement
While it is likely that including alcohol content information within the Alcohol Facts statement could make 
it easier for consumers to locate this information, this advantage may not be particularly significant. 
Consumers are generally accustomed to looking for alcohol content in various parts of the label, and the 
overall impact on their ability to find this information is expected to be minimal.The implications of including the alcohol content within the Alcohol Facts statement should be carefully 
analyzed to avoid the requirement of declaring the alcohol content in two separate locations on the label. 
According to the World Wine Trade Group (WWTG) Agreement on Requirements for Wine Labeling, wines 
may display common mandatory information (CMI), including alcohol content, anywhere on the 
container’s surface visible within a single field of vision. This approach helps ensure clarity and prevents 
redundant labeling. Therefore, it is necessary to ensure compliance with the agreements established 
within the WWTG. If the information must appear in multiple locations on the label, this could increase 
label redesign and printing costs. Additionally, unclear placement requirements might lead to confusion 
among producers, complicating compliance efforts and potentially increasing administrative burdens. 
Moreover, having the alcohol content displayed in two different places with differing values could lead to 
labeling errors and mislead consumers.
Mandatory Statement of Alcohol in Fluid Ounces of Pure Alcohol per Serving
If it is mandatory to indicate the alcohol content as a percentage by volume, requiring additional 
information about the alcohol content per serving size or standard drink would be redundant and could 
potentially confuse or mislead consumers. Providing multiple measures of alcohol content on the label 
may create inconsistency and make it harder for consumers to clearly understand the actual alcohol 
strength of the product.
Linear Display, Type Size, and Electronic Display of Alcohol Facts Information
a. Linear Display
We believe it would be appropriate to provide the option for Alcohol Facts information to be presented 
either in a panel or linear format, as proposed.
b. Type Size
We agree with the proposal that the minimum type size requirements for Alcohol Facts statements should 
mirror the existing type size requirements for mandatory information
c. Electronic Display of Alcohol Facts Information
We suggest allowing the possibility of using electronic means, such as QR codes, to present this 
information, especially for small containers or labels with limited space, while ensuring that mandatory 
physical labeling remains the minimum requirement.
Serving Size Reference Amounts
Proposed serving size amounts should be reference values only. Each consumer, if interested, can evaluate 
their total intake of alcohol, nutrients, and calories when consuming amounts greater than the reference 
serving size. The reference amounts serve their purpose by providing a consistent basis for labeling and 
informing consumer choices without implying a recommended level of consumption.
According to Wine in Moderation, the reference consumption guidelines are: up to 2 units of alcohol per 
day for women (equivalent to approximately 200 ml of wine at 12.5% ABV), and up to 3 units per day for 
men (approximately 300 ml of wine at 12.5% ABV). Additionally, no more than 4 units of alcohol should be 
consumed on a single drinking occasion.Dual-Column Alcohol Facts Panel Display
We agree with allowing the option to present Alcohol Facts in a dual-column format.
We also support the proposal requiring containers with a net content of more than 100 percent but less 
than 200 percent of a single serving size reference amount to be labeled as containing a single serving.
Implementation Period
The proposed 5-year compliance period for the new labeling regulations is both adequate and reasonable, 
as it allows the industry ample time to adapt gradually without imposing excessive economic or 
operational pressures. This timeframe helps minimize costs and facilitates a smooth transition toward 
more comprehensive and transparent labeling for consumers.
However, a shorter period (e.g., 3 years) could be considered only if the labeling is limited to basic 
elements (alcohol content and calories) and does not include a broader set of nutrients or ingredient 
declarations.
It is likely that some industry members will choose to begin implementing the labeling changes before the 
official compliance date. Many producers may prefer to adapt to the new requirements earlier to stay 
ahead of regulations and manage inventory efficiently.
Furthermore, it is essential that new label approval applications (COLA) are not required when changes are 
limited to the inclusion or modification of nutritional information, such as the Alcohol Facts panel or data 
on calories and alcohol content.'}, {'source': 'DIRECT (NON-ATTACHMENT)', 'text': 'See attached file(s)'}]

document_title: Notice No. 237:  Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages

comment_text_sources:
[{'source': 'https://downloads.regulations.gov/TTB-2025-0002-0155/attachment_1.pdf', 'text': ' 
From: 
Cámara Nacional 
de la Industria 
Tequilera  
To: Alcohol and Tobacco Tax 
and Trade Bureau (TTB) Subject: 
Comments on: Alcohol Facts Statements in 
the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and 
Malt Beverages 
Docket No. TTB-2025-0002; Notice No. 237 
Notification : G/TBT/N/USA/2182 
 
Agency responsible: 
 
Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau (TTB), Department of the Treasury 
USA WTO TBT Inquiry Point, Email: usatbtep@nist.gov 
 
About the Cámara Nacional de la Industria Tequilera: The Chamber of the Tequila Industry (CNIT – 
for its acronym in Spanish) is the leading voice of the Tequila industry worldwide, championing the 
interests of its members and promoting the responsible production and consumption of Tequila. As 
a globally recognized symbol of Mexico, Tequila has a rich history dating back to the 16th century 
and boasts a Designation of Origin Tequila (DOT) acknowledged by 57 countries. The Tequila 
industry plays a vital role in Mexico's economy, supporting approximately 41,840 agave farmers, 
100,000 distillery employees, and 209 authorized distilleries. 
 
Appreciation Statement: The Chamber of the Tequila Industry extends its sincere gratitude to the 
TTB for the opportunity to submit our comments on this significant matter. We trust that the TTB 
will give due consideration to our perspective and to the potential impact of t his proposed 
rulemaking on the Tequila industry and its supply chain within the United States market. 
 
TTB Proposal on Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, 
Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages 
 
On January 17, 2025, the Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau (TTB) of the U.S. published a 
proposal (Notice No. 237) to amend the labeling of wines, distilled spirits, and malt beverages. The 
main objective is to provide consumers with more comprehensive and clear information about the 
alcoholic beverages they consume, similar to the nutrition information found on foods. 
Key points of the proposal: 
 "Alcohol Facts" Panel: The creation of a mandatory panel  on alcoholic beverage labels is 
proposed, similar to the "Nutrition Facts" panel on foods. This panel would include: 
1. Alcohol content per serving:  Expressed as alcohol by volume (ABV) and as fluid 
ounces of pure alcohol per serving (rounded to the nearest tenth). 
2. Calories per serving: The amount of calories in each standard serving. 
3. Basic nutrients: Includes the declaration of carbohydrates, fats, and proteins. 
4. Standard serving size and number of servings per container:  The proposal 
establishes specific ser ving sizes for each type of alcoholic beverage, which vary 
depending on their alcohol content. For example: 
i. Malt beverages with no more than 7% alcohol: 12 fl oz (355 ml) 
ii. Wines: 
1. 5 fl oz (148 ml) for wines with 7-16% alcohol. 
2. 2.5 fl oz (74 ml) for products with 16% to 24% alc./vol. 
iii. Distilled spirits: 
1. 12 fl oz (355 ml) if they contain up to 7% alc./vol.; 
2. 5 fl oz (148 ml) between 7% and 16% alc./vol.; 
3. 2.5 fl oz (74 ml) between 16% and 24% alc./vol.; and 1.5 fluid 
ounces (44 ml) 
4. 50 ml for 50 ml containers if they exceed 24% alc./vol. 
 
 Flexible presentation formats: The "Alcohol Facts" panel would be presented in different 
formats, adapting to the container size and beverage content. 
 
 
 
 
 
Compliance Period: A period of 5 years from the publication of the final rule in the Federal Register 
is proposed for producers and distributors to comply with the new requirements. 
 
Comments on the proposal: 
 Alcohol content: We view the inclusion of the alcohol content declaration positively, but 
question the necessity of including fluid ounces of ethanol, as this information is not 
considered relevant to the average consumer. In fact, the Official Mexican Standard NOM-
006-SCFI-2012, Alcoholic Beverages -Tequila-Specifications already provides for the 
declaration of the product's alcohol content. 
 Serving and servings per container: The importance of consumers knowing the amount of 
alcohol in each container and each standard serving is recognized. However, it is suggested 
that this information be provided voluntarily or through elect ronic labeling (QR codes, 
digital platforms, websites) to avoid additional costs and unnecessary regulatory burdens. 
 Nutritional information: Including nutritional information (calories, carbohydrates, fats, 
proteins) on alcoholic beverage labels could confuse consumers. It could be interpreted as 
if these beverages have nutritional benefits, which is contrary to CODEX Alimentarius 
guidelines. It is emphasized that alcohol should not be considered a food or nutrient and 
that nutritional information could di stract from the risks associated with alcohol 
consumption. 
Key Questions from the TTB: 
1. Should TTB’s proposed nutrient  content labeling statement be more  consistent with the 
Nutrition Facts Label found on foods that are under FDA’s labeling jurisdiction? Alternatively, do 
the differences  between alcohol beverages and other  foods make it unnecessary, or even  
misleading, to adopt the type of nutrient  labeling required on food labels that are under FDA’s 
labeling jurisdiction? For example, would information on the percentage of the daily value of the 
listed nutrients provided by alcohol  beverages be useful information for  consumers? 
Alternatively, could such statements mislead consumers by implying that they may rely on alcohol 
beverage consumption to satisfy part of their daily nutrient requirements? 
Our position highli ghts that requiring the "Alcohol Facts" panel on labels would not genuinely 
benefit consumers. From a public health perspective, the true objective of alcoholic beverage 
labeling is to discourage harmful alcohol consumption. Including nutritional information on labels 
could easily lead people to believe that these beverages have some sort of health benefit, which 
would only create confusion. Alcoholic beverages simply do not provide nutrients. Putting 
nutritional information on labels could give consumers t he wrong idea, making them think that 
alcohol fits into a balanced diet or offers essential nutrients. This could skew their purchasing 
decisions, distracting them from the most important information: alcohol content. 
Furthermore, it is misleading to compa re alcoholic and non-alcoholic beverages because they are 
fundamentally different. Elements like calories, carbohydrates, sugars, and fats in alcoholic 
beverages simply cannot be compared to normal food, because the key difference is the alcohol 
itself. At tempting to use nutritional labeling (including calories) to prevent harmful alcohol 
consumption could even be counterproductive. It could make consumers perceive alcohol as 
somehow healthy or harmless, potentially leading to worse health consequences than  current 
labeling was trying to prevent. It is risky to confuse non-alcoholic and alcoholic beverages. They are 
distinct products, with distinct target consumers, and should not be presented as comparable. Making this labeling mandatory would also add cost s for producers, importers, and distributors, 
which goes against trade agreements such as the Agreement on Technical Barriers to Trade (TBT 
Agreement) of the World Trade Organization (WTO), which prohibits creating unnecessary barriers 
to international tra de. However, if the "Alcohol Facts" panel becomes mandatory, we strongly 
recommend allowing this information to be presented digitally (QR codes, websites, etc.). This 
makes the information accessible without creating unnecessary regulatory and commercial 
burdens. 
Digital labeling offers many advantages: 
 Unlimited space to inform consumers. 
 Consumer-friendly and easy-to-understand format. 
 Easy updating as regulations change. 
 Effective communication with vulnerable groups (such as young people) about the risks 
of harmful alcohol consumption. 
 Opportunity to create engaging and educational content. 
 
This approach is in line with the "Guidance for providing food information to consumers by using 
technology", which is being developed by the CODEX Alimentarius Committee on Food Labeling. 
Finally, we believe that a gradual implementation period of 5 years would be the best way to 
implement these changes, particularly to give small producers time to adapt their supply chains for 
distribution in the U.S. 
2. For greater consistency with the FDA Nutrition Facts Label, should Alcohol Facts statements be 
allowed or required to include other elements (such as sodium and cholesterol) or a further 
breakdown of fat (to include saturated fat and trans-fat)? 
It is not recommended to include additional information on sodium, cholesterol, or saturated and 
trans fats. The inclusion of more nutritional information could increase confusion and reinforce the 
misconception that alcoholic beverages have nutritional benefits. 
3. Would the inclusion of elements not ordinarily expected to be found in alcohol beverages (such 
as trans-fat and dietary fiber) be useful or potentially misleading? 
The inclusion of items such as trans fats and dietary fiber would not be useful and could be 
misle ading. These elements are not relevant to alcoholic beverages and their inclusion could 
confuse consumers. 
4. Should TTB allow numerical statements of the vitamin and mineral content of alcohol 
beverages, assuming the product contains vitamins or minerals, or could such a statement create 
an erroneous impression that consumption of the alcohol beverage has nutritional value or other 
health-related benefits? 
It is not recommended to include numerical declarations of vitamin and mineral content. This could 
create a misleading  impression that alcoholic beverages have nutritional value, which is not true 
and could be harmful to public health. In Mexico, laws prohibit alcoholic beverages from being promoted with nutritional, therapeutic, or 
rehabilitation benefits. 
The General Health Law, in its article 308, establishes that advertising for these beverages must be 
limited to describing their characteristics, quality, and how they are made, without presenting them 
as something that improves health or well-being. 
Furthermore, article 307 of the same law prohibits advertising for food and non-alcoholic beverages 
from being directly or indirectly related to the consumption of alcoholic beverages, or from 
promoting harmful eating habits. 
The Regulations of the General Health Law on Advertising, in its article 6, reinforces this prohibition 
by establishing that advertising for no product may attribute preventative, therapeutic, 
rehabilitative, nutritional, stimulating, or any other type of quality. 
In summary, Mexican legislation is clear  in prohibiting the attribution of nutritional properties or 
health benefits that they do not possess to alcoholic beverages. This is because including such 
declarations on labeling could confuse consumers instead of providing useful information. 
5. How many industry members already provide nutrient content information on labels, in 
advertisements (such as websites), or upon request (for example, to consumers or restaurants)? 
No comments on this topic. 
6. Do consumers want to see Alcohol Facts labeling on alcohol beverage pro ducts? How might 
consumers benefit from such a label? Do consumers have adequate information about the 
identity and quality of alcohol beverages if alcohol beverage containers do not include Alcohol 
Facts labeling? How do those benefits compare to the cost s and regulatory burdens associated 
with such revisions? 
The current information on alcoholic beverage labeling is sufficient. The inclusion of the "Alcohol 
Facts" panel would not provide significant ben efits to the consumer and would generate 
unnecessary costs and regulatory burdens. 
7. How, if at all, would the new mandatory labeling requirements affect competition in the alcohol 
beverage market? 
This measure would impose excessive costs and regulatory burdens on producers, importers, and 
distributors of alcoholic beverages, particularly harming small and emerging businesses. This would 
go against the spirit of Article 2.2 of the Agreement on Technical Barriers to Trade (TBT Agreement) 
of the World Trade Organization (WTO), which seeks to prevent the imposition of technical 
regulations that unnecessarily restrict international trade, unless there are legitimate objectives 
justified by member states. 
According to the TBT Agreement, technical regulations sho uld not limit trade more than strictly 
necessary to achieve a legitimate objective. Therefore, it is considered that the proposed measures 
would have a disproportionate impact on international suppliers. This is mainly due to the increased 
costs associated  with additional product analyses, modifications to packaging and labeling, new 
shipments, and especially the restructuring of supply chains for the U.S. alcoholic beverage market. 8. How would the new mandatory labeling requirements affect small businesses and, in particular, 
new businesses entering into the alcohol beverage marketplace? 
The proposed regulation would have a disproportionate impact on international suppliers, 
especially small and new producers. This is due to increased costs associated with additional  
analyses, packaging and labeling modifications, new shipments, and the restructuring of supply 
chains for the U.S. market. This burden could even force some small producers to leave the market. 
9. How, if at all, would the new mandatory lab eling requirements affect international trade of 
alcohol beverages? Is there any information that should, or should not, be included to align the 
proposed labeling requirements with those of other countries? 
It is certain that the new labeling requirements would have a negative impact on international trade 
in alcoholic beverages, as they would increase costs and complexity. To avoid this, it is suggested to 
consider harmonizing such requirements with those of other countries, as well as implementing the 
use of tools such as elec tronic labeling, which allows for much more information than physical 
labels, while reducing operational costs. 
Conclusion: Detailed nutritional labeling could confuse consumers, and information about alcohol 
is sufficient. It is proposed that, in any case , nutritional information be voluntary or provided 
electronically. It is reiterated that the implementation of the proposal would generate significant 
costs, especially affecting small and new businesses, as well as international trade in alcoholic 
beverages in general. 
End of the document  '}, {'source': 'DIRECT (NON-ATTACHMENT)', 'text': 'These comments are submitted on behalf of the Chamber of the Tequila Industry, Cámara Nacional de la Industria Tequilera (CNIT for its acronym in Spanish).'}]
comment_title: Comment 152:  Cámara Nacional de la Industria Tequilera (CNIT: Chamber of the Tequila Industry; Mexico)
comment_text: These comments are submitted on behalf of the Chamber of the Tequila Industry, Cámara Nacional de la Industria Tequilera (CNIT for its acronym in Spanish).
