68. Will 5 years provide  enough  time for small businesses  to coordinate  labeling  
changes  required  by regulatory  changes  with labeling  changes  that are planned  in the ordinary  
course  of business?  
BI Response: If the rule makes TTB Ruling 2013-2 mandatory, our experience shows that 5 years 
is sufficient time to expect compliance.
69. Is 5 years too long a compliance period? Should the compliance period instead be 
2 years,  3 years,  or another  length  of time?  
BI Response: If the rule makes TTB Ruling 2013-2 mandatory, our experience shows that 5 years 
is sufficient time to expect compliance. Less time may not be adequate. 
70. If a ﬁnal rule is issued,  will industry  members  begin implementation  of the labeling  
changes  in advance  of the compliance  date?  
BI Response : Industry  members  are likely to begin complying  on a rolling  basis,  changing  
labels  in the normal  course  of business.  If the final rule makes TTB Ruling 2013-2 mandatory, most 
of the beer volume will already be compliant, and our experience shows that 5 years is sufficient 
time to expect compliance from the rest of the industry.
Conclusion
As noted above, assuming there will be a rules change as suggested by NPRM 237, BI strongly 
encourages the TTB to avoid the “Alcohol Facts” concept and codify the existing voluntary rules as 17
outlined by TTB Ruling 80-3 (for “light” or “lite” beer) and the voluntary guidelines outlined in TTB Ruling 
2013-2 and BI’s comments above.
If there are issues for which the TTB sought comment in NPRM 237 that BI does not explicitly address 
in this response, please consider BI’s introductory comment as the response to such inquiries. 
Additionally, BI reserves the right to amend these responses or to comment further as appropriate.'}, {'source': 'https://downloads.regulations.gov/TTB-2025-0002-0196/attachment_1.docx', 'text': 'Comments of the Beer Institute Regarding NPRM 237

This submission represents comments of the Beer Institute (BI) regarding NPRM 237, by which the Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau (TTB) proposes to require disclosure of per-serving alcohol, calorie, and nutrient content information in an “Alcohol Facts” statement on all alcohol beverage labels subject to TTB's regulatory authority under the Federal Alcohol Administration Act (FAA Act).

BI\xa0is a national trade association for the American brewing industry, representing brewers, beer importers, and industry suppliers. This industry supports more than 2.4 million jobs and provides more than $471 billion to the American economy. First founded in 1862 as the U.S. Brewers Association, BI is committed today to developing sound public policy and to the values of civic duty and personal responsibility.

Brewers’ Commitment to Nutritional Transparency

The beer industry prides itself on innovation in product development and forward-thinking, consumer-focused actions. We are proud of our members’ products and brewers’ commitment to transparency through the [Voluntary Disclosure Initiative (VDI](https://www.beerinstitute.org/policy-responsibility/policy/voluntary-disclosure/)). VDI is a pledge by the nation’s leading brewers to provide consumers with information about the alcohol beverage products they choose to consume. For the past twelve (12) years, BI member brewers have led the way in embracing TTB Ruling 2013-2 regarding nutritional disclosures (calories, carbs, fat, and protein) and disclosing alcohol content and ingredients on the label, secondary packaging, or via easily accessible digital platforms. The program has been a resounding success — more than 95 percent of the beer volume sold by the nation’s largest brewers voluntarily includes nutrition, ingredients, alcohol content, and freshness dating, setting an unparalleled standard in transparency within the alcohol industry. These disclosures help consumers make responsible, informed decisions about what they drink and highlight the fundamental differences between distinct types of alcohol beverages.

As a threshold matter, TTB Ruling 80-3 (for “light” beer) and the voluntary guidelines outlined in TTB Ruling 2013-2 (for all other alcohol products regulated by TTB) address the issues raised by NPRM 237. If TTB made the rules for light beer and the voluntary rules in VDI, in use by BI members since 2016 and already well understood by consumers, mandatory for all alcohol products it regulates, the Bureau could cleanly and efficiently accomplish the policy goals stated in its Notice. Reduced lead time and compliance costs would be additional benefits, as most of the beer volume currently in the marketplace already complies with TTB Ruling 80-3 or TTB Ruling 2013-2 in terms of labeling.

What follows are comments on specific issues, questions, and proposals raised in NPRM 237.

* 1. Which title, “Serving Facts” or “Alcohol Facts,” would be more informative to consumers? Does the title “Alcohol Facts” better describe the information provided in the proposed statement, which includes per-serving alcohol content information?

BI Response: “Serving Facts” is more accurately descriptive than “Alcohol Facts.” The term “Serving Facts” reflects the presence of more than just information about alcohol content. “Serving Facts,” which is the term widely used by brewers, provides information about alcohol content, calories, fat, protein, and carbohydrates. Consumers would be confused by an Alcohol Facts descriptor that goes beyond alcohol content. This term would also significantly increase compliance costs by altering a widely used disclosure.

* 1. Would the use of the title “Alcohol Facts” affect compliance costs or regulatory burdens by requiring a title change for products already voluntarily labeled with a “Serving Facts” statement?

BI Response: Yes, compliance costs and regulatory burden would increase significantly for many brewers. In addition to changes in packaging, brewers already adopting TTB Ruling 2013-2 would need to change Point of Sale (POS) and other advertising.

* 1. Are consumers accustomed to ﬁnding nutrient content information in a Serving Facts statement?

BI Response: For over a decade, many brewers have voluntarily included the Serving Facts statement on their labels.

* 1. Would changing the title to “Alcohol Facts” cause confusion?

BI Response: Yes. “Alcohol Facts” is an unfamiliar term for consumers that does not actually reflect the information disclosed: calories, carbs, protein, fat, and alcohol content expressed as alcohol by volume. Alcohol content disclosure placement should also be flexible – either as part of a Servings Facts disclosure or elsewhere on the label, and the widely understood abbreviation “ABV” should be permissible.

* 1. Does the title “Alcohol Facts” make it easier for consumers to readily distinguish alcohol beverages from other food items?

BI Response: No. “Alcohol Facts” is an unfamiliar term for consumers that does not actually reflect the information disclosed: calories, carbs, protein, fat, and alcohol content. It is unnecessary to use the term “Alcohol Facts” to distinguish alcohol beverages from other food items, as there are other sufficient indicators that the product contains alcohol on the label.

* 1. TTB also seeks comments on whether other elements of the Alcohol Facts statement should be optional rather than mandatory, and whether additional elements should be added to the statement on a mandatory or optional basis.

BI Response: The BI’s Voluntary Disclosure Initiative (VDI) is the nation’s leading brewers’ pledge to include average analysis or “Serving Facts” statements consistent with TTB Ruling 2013-2. For the past twelve (12) years, BI member brewers have embraced TTB Ruling 2013-2 regarding nutritional disclosures and disclosing alcohol content and ingredients on the label, secondary packaging, or via easily accessible digital platforms. BI supports using VDI as the mandatory standard for disclosure of Serving Facts. Again, Serving Facts, not Alcohol Facts, is the recognized and appropriate descriptor for these disclosures.

* 1. TTB speciﬁcally seeks comments on whether TTB should harmonize its nutrient labeling requirements with regulations issued by FDA, as updated in 2016.

BI Response: No. FDA regulations address a much broader set of public policy goals for nutritional disclosures, many of which are not necessary or appropriate for alcohol beverage products (e.g., vitamin content). The Serving Facts panel works well for the unique characteristics of alcohol beverages.

* 1. TTB seeks further comments, speciﬁcally comments with market data, on whether any micronutrients, such as sodium, are present in alcohol beverages in sufficient quantities that their disclosure would affect purchasing or consumption decisions, and if yes, whether TTB should require, or permit optional, inclusion of those nutrients on alcohol beverage labels.

BI Response: While market data is not readily available, most micronutrients are seldom present in TTB-labeled alcohol beverages. As such, the disclosure of micronutrients should be optional.

* 1. TTB also seeks comments on whether certain nutrients should be listed only if present at speciﬁc levels. TTB is proposing to require the listing of calories, carbohydrate, fat, and protein content on alcohol beverages, even if the product does not contain, or contains only a de minimis amount of, these components. However, TTB speciﬁcally seeks comments on whether fat and protein, which are not typically found in certain alcohol beverages, should be listed only if present at speciﬁc levels. If so, what levels should trigger these requirements? TTB also seek comments on whether any other nutrients, such as sodium, caffeine, or sugar, should be required to be listed if present at a speciﬁc level, even if they do not otherwise have to be disclosed.

BI Response: Current Serving Facts statements include calories, carbohydrates, fat, and protein, and there is no need to change the existing approach, which is widely used by the brewing industry and understood by consumers. Voluntary disclosure of other nutrients, such as sodium, caffeine, or sugar, may be the best approach for alcohol beverages.

* 1. Should TTB’s proposed nutrient content labeling statement be more consistent with the Nutrition Facts Label found on foods that are under FDA’s labeling jurisdiction?

BI Response: No. FDA labeling requirements address wider public policy goals for the broader food category. Requiring a Nutrition Facts Label on alcohol beverage products would be overwhelming relative to the limited scope of nutrients in alcohol beverages.

* 1. Do the differences between alcohol beverages and other foods make it unnecessary, or even misleading, to adopt the type of nutrient labeling required on food labels that are under FDA’s labeling jurisdiction?

BI Response: Yes. Adopting the type of nutrient labeling required on FDA food labels for alcohol beverages falling under TTB’s labeling authority is unnecessary and potentially misleading. See also the answer to Items #12 and 13 below.

* 1. Would information on the percentage of the daily value of the listed nutrients provided by alcohol beverages be useful information for consumers?

BI Response: While context matters, statements regarding the percentage of daily value of listed nutrients would not be helpful information for consumers, as consumers do not typically consume alcohol beverages for nutrient value.

* 1. Could statements [regarding percentage of the daily value of listed nutrients] mislead consumers by implying that they may rely on alcohol beverage consumption to satisfy part of their daily nutrient requirements?

BI Response: While context matters, consumers who choose to drink alcohol beverages do not consume them for nutritive value. Moreover, existing regulations restrict or prohibit health claims concerning alcohol beverages.

* 1. For greater consistency with the FDA Nutrition Facts Label, should Alcohol Facts statements be allowed or required to include other elements (such as sodium and cholesterol) or a further breakdown of fat (to include saturated fat and trans-fat)?

BI Response: Statements of Average Analysis and Serving Facts labels allowed by TTB Ruling 2013-2, and widely implemented by the BI through VDI, have long been in use, are familiar to consumers, and provide consumers with the information they need about alcohol beverages. Any additional information should be voluntary.

* 1. Would the inclusion of elements not ordinarily expected to be found in alcohol beverages (such as trans-fat and dietary ﬁber) be useful or potentially misleading?

BI Response: The inclusion of elements not ordinarily expected in alcohol beverages is of no utility and could be confusing to consumers.

* 1. Should TTB allow numerical statements of the vitamin and mineral content of alcohol beverages, assuming the product contains vitamins or minerals, or could such a statement create an erroneous impression that consumption of the alcohol beverage has nutritional value or other health-related beneﬁts?

BI Response: While context matters, consumers who choose to drink alcohol beverages do not consume them for their vitamin or mineral content. Moreover, existing regulations prohibit health claims for alcohol beverage products.

* 1. How many industry members already provide nutrient content information on labels, in advertisements (such as websites), or upon request (for example, to consumers or restaurants)?

# BI Response: BI estimates that 95% of the beer volume sold in the U.S. by the nation’s largest brewers already includes serving facts information on the label. Under federal law, restaurants with twelve or more locations must also provide consumers with calorie information on menus and nutrient content information on request.

* 1. Do consumers want to see Alcohol Facts labeling on alcohol beverage products? How might consumers beneﬁt from such a label? Do consumers have adequate information about the identity and quality of alcohol beverages if alcohol beverage containers do not include Alcohol Facts labeling? How do those beneﬁts compare to the costs and regulatory burdens associated with such revisions?

BI Response: Consumers can already see serving facts information on beer labels. TTB Ruling 80-3 (for “light” beer) and the voluntary guidelines outlined in TTB Ruling 2013-2 (for all other alcohol products regulated by TTB) address the issues raised by NPRM 237. If the rules for light beer and VDI – used by BI members since 2016 and already well understood by consumers – became mandatory for all alcohol products regulated by TTB, the Bureau could cleanly and efficiently accomplish the policy goals stated in its Notice. Added benefits include reduced lead time, compliance cost, and less overall regulatory burden, as most beer volume currently in the marketplace already includes Serving Facts statements.

* 1. How, if at all, would the new mandatory labeling requirements affect competition in the alcohol beverage market?

BI Response: Consumers have been receptive to BI’s Voluntary Disclosure Initiative, which BI believes enhances competition in the alcohol beverage market.

* 1. How would the new mandatory labeling requirements affect small businesses and, in particular, new businesses entering into the alcoholic beverage marketplace?

BI Response: While 95% of US beer volume sold by the nation’s largest brewers already includes disclosure of serving facts, some brands will need time to alter their labels. TTB’s proposed 5-year implementation will allow sufficient time to do so. For new businesses entering the alcohol beverage market, knowing the nutrition disclosure requirement, but on an extended time basis, should help with planning and execution.

* 1. How, if at all, would the new mandatory labeling requirements affect international trade of alcohol beverages?

BI Response: Brewers may import brands under license, with those licenses affecting their ability to alter labels. Codifying voluntary standards set for the TTB Ruling 2013-2 and allowing a five-year implementation timeline should allow sufficient opportunity to amend license agreements. Of course, nutrition label requirements for products sold outside of the U.S. would not be subject to these labeling requirements.

* 1. TTB is proposing to modify the tolerances set out in the 2020 guidance by eliminating references to "reasonable ranges" based on "good manufacturing practice limitations." Instead, TTB is proposing an objective standard, which allows a tolerance of 20 percent either above or below the labeled amount for calories, carbohydrates, protein, and fat…. TTB seeks comments on whether the proposed tolerances are broad enough to facilitate reliance on databases for standard products, among other methods for calculating calorie and nutrient content, but still speciﬁc enough to provide accurate information to consumers. Speciﬁcally, TTB seeks comments on whether it should instead propose the same tolerances set forth in TTB Procedure 2020-1 or whether another approach should be considered.

BI Response: TTB Procedure 2020-1 follows FDA guidelines and has been in place for several years. Its continued application is appropriate.

* 1. For beers that are not deﬁned as “malt beverages” under the FAA Act, TTB is proposing to mandate an alcohol content statement on the label of the products under TTB’s IRC authority. However, these beers would not be subject to the proposed Alcohol Facts labeling requirements, including the requirement for a statement of the number of ﬂuid ounces of pure ethyl alcohol per serving, because the Alcohol Facts labeling requirements are being proposed under TTB’s FAA Act authority, which does not apply to these products. Instead, these products are subject to FDA labeling requirements. TTB believes that requiring an alcohol content statement on these products would facilitate revenue. The Beer Institute and the Brewers Association made substantially similar comments in response to Notice No. 232. protection by, among other things, making it readily apparent that the products are subject to tax under the IRC. TTB seeks comments on this issue. TTB also seeks comment on the proposal to increase the labeling tolerance to one percentage point above or below the stated amount for all malt beverages and beers. TTB seeks comment on whether increasing the tolerance for alcohol content to one percent would lower the cost of compliance for a mandatory alcohol content disclosure and thereby promote competition in the marketplace if such disclosure is required. TTB also seeks comment on whether consumers would receive adequate information about the alcohol content of malt beverages if the tolerance were increased.

BI Response: Applying a basic alcohol disclosure standard – like the mandatory and voluntary standards already in place and adding alcohol by volume to all “IRC Alcohol beverages” is appropriate and consistent with the goals of consumer-centric disclosures. Flexibility in the location of disclosure is essential. Furthermore, alcohol by volume is the form of alcohol content disclosure that consumers recognize and understand across all types of alcohol. Adding fluid ounces of pure ethyl alcohol as an additional statement, particularly if mandatory, would confuse consumers and contradict the aim of this rulemaking.

As for increasing the labeling tolerance for malt beverages from 0.3% to 1.0%, BI continues to caution against this change, as there is substantial risk of misinforming consumers about the alcohol content of malt beverages. If TTB believes an increase in tolerance is appropriate for malt beverages, BI suggests increasing the tolerance from .3% to .5%, providing greater flexibility to brewers while still providing accurate information about the alcohol content they are consuming.

* 1. TTB seeks comments on this issue and speciﬁcally invites comments on whether an Alcohol Facts statement should be required for non-alcoholic malt beverages.

BI Response: A Serving Facts statement, not an Alcohol Facts statement, makes sense for non-alcoholic malt beverages, so long as brewers can maintain flexibility in terms of the statement's location.

* 1. What are the potential beneﬁts to consumers and industry members from a requirement for alcohol content statements, expressed as a percentage of alcohol by volume, on the labels of all alcohol beverage products?

BI Response: Alcohol content, expressed as a percentage of alcohol by volume, is valuable information for consumers, and BI supports its inclusion on all alcohol labels. Alcohol by volume is straightforward, recognized, and understood by consumers. Additional statements of alcohol content, such as fluid ounces of pure ethyl alcohol are neither straightforward nor well understood by consumers. BI does not support additional statements of alcohol content on labels.

* 1. Will the proposed requirement for alcohol content labeling for all beer and malt beverages result in additional costs and burdens for brewers and importers, particularly small businesses?

BI Response: The answer to this question will depend on the disclosure criteria and time to comply. A simple requirement for an alcohol by volume statement should not pose a particularly high or onerous burden for brewers, especially if provided sufficient time to comply (*e.g.,* 5 years). A “fluid ounces of pure ethyl alcohol” or “total alcohol” disclosure requirement will pose a greater burden, not provide any recognized useful information, and confuse consumers.

* 1. Will the proposed increase in alcohol content tolerances for malt beverages mislead consumers?

BI Response: An increase in alcohol content tolerance from .3% to 1.0% is too much and will misinform consumers when a producer uses the full tolerance. If TTB believes it must provide additional flexibility, BI recommends only a minor increase in the tolerance level, such as from .3% to .5%.

* 1. Do the proposed labeling requirements for non-alcoholic malt beverages adequately advise the consumer that the products contain less than 0.5 percent alcohol by volume?

BI Response: Yes.

* 1. Should non-alcoholic malt beverages be exempted from calorie and nutrient labeling requirements?

BI Response: No.

* 1. Would an alternative that allowed table wines to indicate alcohol content as a range (e.g., 7–14 percent alcohol by volume) place less of a burden on small wineries and importers? Would this approach provide sufficient information to consumers?

BI Response: BI does not support statements of alcohol content expressed as a range on any alcohol beverage products. This would not be sufficient information for consumers.

* 1. Would it be easier for consumers to locate alcohol content information on a label if it is required to be included in the Alcohol Facts statement and if so, why?

BI Response: Consumers usually see alcohol by volume disclosures separate from Serving Facts disclosures on the label. Suppliers should maintain the flexibility of label placement to minimize additional regulatory burden and associated compliance costs.

* 1. Alternatively, should TTB allow alcohol content labeling as an optional element of the Alcohol Facts statement?

BI Response: TTB should require disclosure of alcohol content, expressed as alcohol by volume, on labels, with the flexibility of placing it as part of a Serving Facts disclosure or elsewhere on the label.

* 1. Does the placement of alcohol content information affect compliance costs and regulatory burdens? If so, how?

BI Response: Disclosure of alcohol by volume with flexibility in placement should not materially increase compliance costs or regulatory burdens.

* 1. Does the proposal to require alcohol content information as part of the Alcohol Facts statement affect competition or issues addressed by international trade agreements or international standards?

BI Response: We do not see the disclosures allowed by TTB Ruling 2013-2 as adversely affecting competition. However, if TTB determines that a Serving Facts statement should include alcohol content, an alcohol-by-volume format is the appropriate disclosure format.

* 1. Would it be easier for consumers to locate alcohol content information on a label if it is required to be included in the Alcohol Facts statement and if so, why?

BI Response: Consumers usually see alcohol by volume disclosures separate from Serving Facts disclosures on the label. There is no reason to change that practice.

* 1. Should TTB allow the use of alcohol per serving as an optional element of the Alcohol Facts statement?

BI Response: It is challenging to reconcile TTB’s goal of providing non-misleading labeling rules with the proposal to allow the use of alcohol per serving as an optional element of a nutrition disclosure for alcohol. First, there are significant differences between malt beverages, wine, and distilled spirits. There is no standard for calculating a uniform serving size for all these products that matches how consumers consume them. TTB should similarly reject using a “standard drink” measurement, which presumes that all alcohol is the same; it is not. The myth of a “standard drink” is merely a self-serving argument used by those who want regulators and legislators to ignore the reality that consumers do not consume malt beverages, wine, and distilled spirits the same. It is a device used to secure tax and marketplace advantages, not a known and tested method of communicating to consumers about the alcohol content of what they are drinking.

* 1. Does the placement of alcohol content information affect costs of compliance and regulatory burdens?

BI Response: Yes, if the placement or form of alcohol content information changes. The industry is well-positioned to continue reflecting Serving Facts information on primary and secondary packaging or near the net contents information on both primary and secondary packaging display panels. However, compliance costs and regulatory burden will increase if the requirements change.

* 1. Does the proposal to require alcohol content information as part of the Alcohol Facts statement affect competition or issues addressed by international trade agreements or international standards?

BI Response: We do not see the disclosures allowed by TTB Ruling 2013-2 as adversely affecting competition.

* 1. Would including information about the fluid ounces of pure ethyl alcohol per serving in the proposed Alcohol Facts statement improve the ability of consumers to follow the consumption and moderation advice provided by governmental and health agencies, if they so choose?

BI Response: The amount of fluid ounces of pure ethyl alcohol per serving does not provide any additional useful or relevant information to the consumer. This information will only serve to confuse consumers. Consumers typically purchase beer in a 12-oz container intended for a single serving. This reference amount for beer and a disclosure of alcohol by volume provide the information consumers need to follow consumption and moderation advice.

* 1. Would requiring information about the fluid ounces of pure ethyl alcohol per serving in the proposed Alcohol Facts statement impose additional costs or burdens for alcohol beverage manufacturers and importers, particularly for small businesses?

BI Response: Yes. BI is unaware of any brewers today who are providing a statement of fluid ounces of pure ethyl alcohol. To include such a requirement would force label changes for the majority volume of beer in the market today, which already provides alcohol content statements expressed as alcohol by volume. Furthermore, this information would only serve to confuse consumers who already widely understand alcohol content expressed as alcohol by volume; therefore, the regulatory costs and burden increase with a negative return on consumer protection.

* 1. Is there a better way of presenting the volume of alcohol content per serving? Specifically, should the term “standard drink” be defined and used in place of or in addition to fluid ounces of pure ethyl alcohol per serving?

BI Response: This question assumes consumers are ill-informed about alcohol content, but the simplest and most efficient way to inform consumers about the alcohol content of the product they purchase is to mandate the alcohol content statement expressed as alcohol by volume. Consumers already understand this format, and many industry members, including the nation’s largest brewers, express alcohol content for their products this way. It is challenging to reconcile TTB’s goal of providing non-misleading labeling rules with the proposal to allow alcohol per serving or “standard drinks” as an element of a nutrition disclosure for alcohol. There are significant differences between malt beverages, wine, and distilled spirits, and no standard for calculating a uniform serving size for all these products that matches how consumers consume them. TTB should reject using a “standard drink” measurement, which presumes that all alcohol is the same; it is not.

* 1. TTB notes that the Dietary Guidelines for Americans, 2020-2025, use the terms “drink,” and “alcoholic drink equivalent,” and seeks comments on whether any of those terms should be used or defined for use on labels.

BI Response: TTB should mandate the statement of alcohol content on all alcohol beverage labels in the alcohol by volume format. This information, together with beer typically purchased in a 12-oz. container representing a single serving, provides sufficient information for consumers to moderate their alcohol consumption if they consume beer.

* 1. Would consumers have trouble locating Alcohol Facts information if that information is presented in a linear display?

BI Response: No. Brewers commonly use linear displays to present statements of average analysis and Serving Facts disclosures permitted by TTB Ruling 2013-2. This method is suitable since alcohol beverage labels are small. The FDA also permits linear display on space-limited labels.

* 1. Does the proposal to require the linear display to appear in a box with the title “Alcohol Facts” in bold-face type allow consumers to better locate the information?

BI Response: A box format is not an issue; however, the proposed title is a significant concern to the beer industry. The problem, as articulated throughout these comments, is the use of the term “Alcohol Facts” versus the current (and more accurate) term, “Serving Facts.” Moreover, we would like to maintain flexibility in terms of placement of the disclosure of alcohol content.

* 1. Alternatively, should industry members be allowed the ﬂexibility to include a linear display that is not surrounded by a box?

BI Response: Yes.

* 1. Do consumers, industry members, or other interested parties have comments on the type size and general formatting requirements proposed for both linear displays and panels?

BI Response: The requirements of the current voluntary Serving Facts statement are adequate.

* 1. How would the proposed formatting requirements, including the linear display option, affect the costs and other regulatory burdens? What are the beneﬁts of the proposed formatting requirements?

BI Response: Changes to formatting and display will adversely affect compliance costs and other regulatory burdens if they change the standards outlined in TTB Ruling 2013-2. Brewers have been following TTB Ruling 2013-2 since 2016. It makes no sense to require them to incur additional costs by changing, without compelling cause, the nature and content of disclosures.

* 1. Should TTB remove the maximum type size limitation for mandatory statements of alcohol content for wine and malt beverages that appear in an Alcohol Facts statement?

BI Response: TTB should encourage consistency across wine and malt beverages. The current minimum and maximum type sizes provide a baseline and consistency.

* 1. For malt beverages, should TTB remove the maximum type size limitation for alcohol content statements that may appear elsewhere on the label as well?

BI Response: TTB should encourage consistency across malt beverages. The current minimum and maximum type sizes provide a baseline and consistency.

* 1. What alternatives exist to convey Alcohol Facts information to consumers?

BI Response: TTB might consider allowing QR codes for voluntary disclosures only.

* 1. How, if it all, would the alternatives affect competition in the marketplace as compared to displaying the information as proposed on the physical label?

BI Response: The question should not be whether alternatives affect competition in the marketplace, but whether alternatives provide consumers with access to information about the products they purchase. If giving information to consumers is the goal, competition in the market may be a secondary consideration, at best. QR codes offer flexibility but are inappropriate for mandatory disclosures. TTB should limit the use of QR codes to voluntary disclosure of information only.

* 1. What are the costs and beneﬁts of aligning Alcohol Facts information to requirements of other countries?

BI Response: BI sees no benefits to aligning nutrition and alcohol content disclosures in the United States with requirements from other countries with different laws and regulatory structures. The costs of compliance and regulatory burden would increase, and consumers in the U.S. may be more confused than informed by labeling requirements imported from other markets.

* 1. If TTB adopts mandatory Alcohol Facts labeling for alcohol beverages, should it include the option of satisfying the requirement by making the information available electronically, for example by including a QR code or website address on the label to allow consumers to view mandatory Alcohol Facts statements on their mobile devices instead of on the product label?

BI Response: Yes, but for voluntary disclosure of information only.

* 1. Would this option provide consumers with sufficient access to Alcohol Facts information at the retail store so that they can make informed decisions, given issues such as the need to use a smartphone, potential issues regarding the adequacy of cellular or Wi-Fi coverage at some retail stores, and other potential technological challenges? Would the provision of mandatory information disclosures via electronic means create disproportional barriers to access for particular communities?

BI Response: Mandatory disclosures should be on the label. TTB should limit the use of electronic disclosures to voluntary information disclosures only.

* 1. How would the option of disclosing the proposed Alcohol Facts information via electronic means affect the costs and other regulatory burdens?

BI Response: Flexibility in disclosing voluntary nutrition information via electronic means would decrease the cost of compliance and regulatory burden. Mandatory information should be on the label.

* 1. If TTB were to allow mandatory information to be disclosed electronically, should TTB allow all of the proposed Alcohol Facts information to be disclosed electronically or should some of the information be required to appear on the physical label?

BI Response: Mandatory disclosures should be on the physical label. TTB should, however, allow for voluntary disclosure of information by electronic means.

* 1. If TTB allowed multiple options to convey Alcohol Facts information to consumers, could the lack of uniformity create consumer confusion?

BI Response: BI members appreciate flexibility, but too many options to convey nutrition and alcohol content information could confuse consumers and prevent them from obtaining this information about all alcohol products.

* 1. Are the proposed reference amounts a reasonably accurate representation of the amount of the product customarily consumed as a single serving?

BI Response: Consumers typically purchase beer in a 12-oz container intended as a single serving.

* 1. What data or other information should TTB consider that would give a better estimate of the amount customarily consumed for a speciﬁc product category?

BI Response: Consumers customarily encounter beer in 12-oz containers, intended as a single serving. The 12-oz container should continue as a serving size reference for beer.

* 1. Are the proposed reference amounts more accurate than the serving sizes set forth in TTB Ruling 2004–1 (1.5 ﬂ oz for distilled spirits, 5 ﬂ oz for wines, and 12 ﬂ oz for malt beverages, regardless of the alcohol content)? Why or why not?

BI Response: Consumers customarily encounter beer in 12-oz containers, intended as a single serving. Servings of wine and distilled spirits often vary based on recipe and glass size. For example, a cocktail may contain three or more “servings.” Moreover, the National Institute on Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism (NIAAA) developed the serving sizes outlined in TTB Ruling 2004-1 to allow for accurate comparison of scientific studies, not as a consumer-facing tool. Granted, specific industry sectors argue that these serving sizes “prove” that all alcohol is the same. However, consumers do not understand and rarely apply that argument, which those industry sectors advance to secure beneficial tax rates and other marketplace advantages.

* 1. Should TTB allow greater ﬂexibility in serving sizes?

BI Response: While consumer behavior does not always match the serving sizes outlined in TTB Ruling 2004-1, providing “flexibility” in serving size would create consumer confusion.

* 1. Should the serving size reference amounts be precisely equal to an alcoholic drink equivalent of 0.6 ﬂuid ounces of alcohol, or would this mislead consumers by not recognizing how alcohol beverages are typically consumed?

BI Response: Using “standard drink” or “drink equivalent” measurements of 0.6 fluid ounces is misleading and confusing. Except for beer, this measurement does not reflect how consumers pour or drink alcohol. It introduces an entirely new measurement standard without credible support that is more useful than the existing approach.

* 1. Does dual-column labeling create the impression that consumption of multiple servings of an alcohol beverage at one time is expected or recommended?

BI Response: No.

* 1. Should dual-column displays be limited to containers with three or fewer servings, consistent with the FDA regulations? Or is a limit of less than ﬁve servings better suited to the way in which alcohol beverages may be bottled and labeled?

BI Response: There is no good reason to change the current voluntary standards of TTB Ruling 2013-2, except to make them mandatory.

* 1. Should dual-column displays be allowed on any container, regardless of the number of servings in that container, consistent with TTB Ruling 2013–2? The proposed rule would require containers with a net content of more than 100 percent but less than 200 percent of a single serving size reference amount to be labeled as containing a single serving. TTB solicits comments on whether this is the best way to convey the alcohol and nutrient content of these products to consumers.

BI Response: There is no good reason to change the current voluntary standards of TTB Ruling 2013-2, except to make them mandatory.

* 1. How frequently do bottlers and importers of alcohol beverages typically change labels?

BI Response: It depends on the products. There are products in the marketplace with labels that have remained unchanged for several years. Some of those products already comply with TTB Ruling 2013-2, while other labels will not change unless the requirements change.

# How long do industry members need to comply with the requirements of the proposed rule?

#

# BI Response: It will depend on the rule. If the rule makes TTB Ruling 2013-2 mandatory, our experience shows that 5 years is sufficient time to expect compliance.

* 1. Will 5 years provide enough time for small businesses to coordinate labeling changes required by regulatory changes with labeling changes that are planned in the ordinary course of business?

BI Response: If the rule makes TTB Ruling 2013-2 mandatory, our experience shows that 5 years is sufficient time to expect compliance.

* 1. Is 5 years too long a compliance period? Should the compliance period instead be 2 years, 3 years, or another length of time?

BI Response: If the rule makes TTB Ruling 2013-2 mandatory, our experience shows that 5 years is sufficient time to expect compliance. Less time may not be adequate.

* 1. If a ﬁnal rule is issued, will industry members begin implementation of the labeling changes in advance of the compliance date?

BI Response: Industry members are likely to begin complying on a rolling basis, changing labels in the normal course of business. If the final rule makes TTB Ruling 2013-2 mandatory, most of the beer volume will already be compliant, and our experience shows that 5 years is sufficient time to expect compliance from the rest of the industry.

Conclusion

As noted above, assuming there will be a rules change as suggested by NPRM 237, BI strongly encourages the TTB to avoid the “Alcohol Facts” concept and codify the existing voluntary rules as outlined by TTB Ruling 80-3 (for “light” or “lite” beer) and the voluntary guidelines outlined in TTB Ruling 2013-2 and BI’s comments above.

If there are issues for which the TTB sought comment in NPRM 237 that BI does not explicitly address in this response, please consider BI’s introductory comment as the response to such inquiries. Additionally, BI reserves the right to amend these responses or to comment further as appropriate.'}]

document_title: Notice No. 237:  Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages

comment_text_sources:
[{'source': 'DIRECT (NON-ATTACHMENT)', 'text': 'To whom it may concern,

I’m writing as the owner of Cairn View Winery to share my concerns about the proposed TTB’s rule, Notice No. 237 and No. 238, which would require new “Alcohol Facts” labels on wine bottles.

While I support educating consumers, this rule would create serious financial challenges for myself and all the other small boutique wineries in Georgia. Redesigning labels and testing for nutritional content is costly and time-consuming—especially for small producers like us, where our margins are already slim.

There are better ways to promote health awareness without hurting local businesses. Public campaigns or online education tools could inform consumers without forcing costly label changes.

Please consider the impact of this rule on Georgia’s wine industry and the small businesses, like ours, that support our state’s economy and agriculture.

Thank you for your time and attention.

Sincerely,

Cairn View Winery
Jasper, GA'}]
comment_title: Comment 178:  Brent Hancock (Cairn View Winery, Jasper, Georgia)
comment_text:
To whom it may concern,

I’m writing as the owner of Cairn View Winery to share my concerns about the proposed TTB’s rule, Notice No. 237 and No. 238, which would require new “Alcohol Facts” labels on wine bottles.

While I support educating consumers, this rule would create serious financial challenges for myself and all the other small boutique wineries in Georgia. Redesigning labels and testing for nutritional content is costly and time-consuming—especially for small producers like us, where our margins are already slim.

There are better ways to promote health awareness without hurting local businesses. Public campaigns or online education tools could inform consumers without forcing costly label changes.

Please consider the impact of this rule on Georgia’s wine industry and the small businesses, like ours, that support our state’s economy and agriculture.

Thank you for your time and attention.

Sincerely,

Cairn View Winery
Jasper, GA
document_title: Notice No. 237:  Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages

People who drink generally underestimate how much they drink and are not readily able to determine their level of drinking with health professional guidance with respect to low-risk drinking.'}]
comment_text:
Please include in the “Alcohol Facts” statement information on serving size based on a US standard drink (14 grams or 0.6 fluid oz of ethanol and the equivlent of 12 oz 5% ABV beer, 5 oz 12% ABV wine, 1.5 oz 40% ABV liquor), % ABV, and calories.

People who drink generally underestimate how much they drink and are not readily able to determine their level of drinking with health professional guidance with respect to low-risk drinking.
document_title: Notice No. 237:  Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages

comment_text_sources:
[{'source': 'https://downloads.regulations.gov/TTB-2025-0002-0193/attachment_1.pdf', 'text': ' 
Distilled Spirits Council of the United States 
101 Constitution Ave. NW , Suite 350 West 
Washington, DC 20001 
 
August 15, 2025 
 
Ms. Amy Greenberg 
Director, Regulations and Rulings Division 
Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau  
1310 G Street NW , Box 12 
Washington, DC 20005 
 
Re: Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wine, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages 
(Notice No. 237; Docket No. TTB–202–0005) (90 Fed. Reg. 6654 (January 17, 2025)) 
 
Dear Ms. Greenberg, 
 
On behalf of the Distilled Spirits Council of the United States, Inc. (DISCUS), a national trade 
association representing the nation’s leading distillers of all sizes and marketers of distilled 
spirits sold in the United States, we appreciate the opportunity to comment upon the Alcohol 
and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau’s (TTB) “Alcohol Facts” notice of proposed rulemaking and 
look forward to a thoughtful evaluation by TTB as you consider regulations on this important 
labeling proposal.  
 
As regulated producers, importers, and marketers of distilled spirits, we share the goal of TTB 
and the Federal Alcohol Administration (FAA) Act of providing consumers with meaningful 
information about the beverages they choose to purchase. It is from that shared objective that 
we respectfully submit our views regarding the instant notice and it is for those reasons that we 
do not support the Bureau's "Alcohol Facts" proposal as drafted either as an option or a 
mandatory requirement on container labels.  
 
Of particular note, we urge the Bureau to consider the following key points: 
• Flexibility to electronically display Alcohol Facts information is critical;  
• Anticipated costs associated will be signiﬁcant and not commensurate with the beneﬁts; 
• Standard drink metrics should be the preferred method of providing alcohol 
information; and 
• TTB’s proposed serving size reference amounts in the nutrient content statements will 
create consumer confusion, damage brand equity, and impede innovation. 
 
It is without doubt that this notice of proposed rulemaking is one of the most signiﬁcant 
undertakings by the Bureau in the last 20 years. It is critical that TTB promulgates a ﬁnal rule 
that serves the public's interests, while also ensuring that regulations do not unduly burden 
distillers, overwhelm agency staﬀ, or inadvertently confuse consumers. We believe this  
  Ms. Amy Greenberg 
August 15, 2025 
Page 2 
 
   
 
proposal, if adopted, would not meet these objectives and urge the Bureau to reconsider 
certain aspects to increase supplier ﬂexibility, reduce the ﬁnancial impact, and enhance 
consumer clarity.  
 
Below we expound on these points and provide additional context that we hope the Bureau will 
consider as it progresses with this rulemaking and its other labeling initiatives.   
 
Areas of Greatest Concern 
 
1. Flexibility to Electronically Display Alcohol Facts Information Is Critical to the Success of This 
Proposal  
 
If the Bureau wishes to ﬁnalize an actionable standard that can be accessible for consumers and 
implemented without overburdening industry members, any new regulations should, at a 
minimum, allow for the ﬂexibility to use quick response (QR) code technology or website 
references on label to provide this information. As we heard during the listening sessions and in 
the written comment period last year, the industry, both domestic and international, almost 
unanimously registered support for additional ﬂexibility, with regard to the use of QR codes or 
website references, and detailed why this ﬂexibility was warranted and necessary. DISCUS 
strongly urges the Bureau to consider introducing a QR code and/or website reference option 
into this proposal.   
 
Allowing the use of QR codes would signiﬁcantly reduce the ﬁnancial burdens for industry 
members to comply, provide eﬃciencies as they are already being utilized on bottles in the 
United States and across multiple international marketplaces for this purpose and can be geo-
tagged for individual markets, and permit producers to quickly change the information without 
needing to revise logistics and supply chain.  
 
Speciﬁc considerations regarding electronic display of Alcohol Facts information include: 
 
A. QR Codes Are Eﬀective, Consumer Friendly, and Would Not Disadvantage Certain 
Communities 
 
While we understand and appreciate that the Bureau considered the issue of QR codes in 
response to comments received during the advance notice of proposed rulemaking last year 
and decided not to include a QR code option due to a concern that it “would create barriers for 
consumer access, particularly for consumers in certain demographics and those living in rural 
areas,”
1 we believe that these perceived barriers are not as large or insurmountable as others 
have argued and that QR codes can be an accessible and sustainable source of providing 
important product information to consumers. From a consumer perspective, we believe using a 
QR code to access e-labels allows producers to provide the consumer with the requisite 
 
1 90 Fed. Reg. at 6671. Ms. Amy Greenberg 
August 15, 2025 
Page 3 
 
   
 
information, and in many cases, with even more fulsome detail than a physical label would be 
able to accommodate. For example, a 50 ml bottle can comfortably accommodate a QR code 
but would not be able to ﬁt the proposed label and all of the other information required by 
both federal and growing state regulations.  
 
Largely due to the rapid expansion of QR codes during and after the COVID-19 pandemic over 
the last ﬁve years, consumers have become extremely comfortable accessing important product 
information in this format for all sorts of consumer brands and services. Consumers are 
increasingly aware that much more information than is shown on the product label can be 
found by simply going to the brand’s website or scanning a QR code on the packaging. Indeed, it 
is now common for a consumer to look up a product online on their smartphone while in the 
store shopping, rather than picking up the product to examine the label. 
 
In the NPRM, TTB questions whether QR codes “[w]ould…provide consumers with suﬃcient 
access to Alcohol Facts information at the retail store so that they can make informed decisions, 
given issues such as the need to use a smartphone, potential issues regarding the adequacy of 
cellular or Wi-Fi coverage at some retail stores, and other potential technological challenges.”
2 
We would argue this format of presenting information is not prohibitive for today’s or 
tomorrow’s consumer, as according to Pew Research,3 over 90% of adult Americans own a 
smartphone device and 95% of adults use the internet. In fact, many Americans can be 
considered “smartphone-dependent,” meaning digital is often the primary information pathway. 
 
Even amongst senior citizens, cellphone ownership is strong. In 2023, Consumer Aﬀairs found 
that the vast majority of seniors own cell phones (94%) or smartphones (76%).
4 Smartphone 
ownership is only expected to grow as well, with future trends predicting that the number of 
American smartphone users will increase to more than 364 million people by 2040.5 Regarding 
cell service, the three largest phone carriers today, Verizon, AT&T and T-Mobile, each claim that 
their 4G LTE network covers more than 99% of the U.S. population, so consumers in both urban 
and rural areas should have the requisite cell service necessary to scan a QR code at the retail 
store no matter where they are in the United States. One can only expect that by 2030, when 
this ﬁnal rule would likely go into eﬀect, that these cell coverages and ﬁgures will have markedly 
increased, further closing any potential gap in accessibility for QR codes in all parts of the 
country.  
 
  
 
2 90 Fed. Reg. at 6672-3. 
3 Pew Research – Mobile Fact Sheet, January 31, 2024, available at https://www.pewresearch.org/internet/fact-
sheet/mobile/#who-owns-cellphones-and-smartphone; Pew Research – Internet, Broadband Fact Sheet. January 31, 2024, 
available at https://www.pewresearch.org/internet/fact-sheet/internet-broadband/. 
4 Consumer Aﬀairs – Cell phone statistics 2025, available at https://www.consumeraﬀairs.com/cell_phones/cell-phone-
statistics.html. 
5 Id. Ms. Amy Greenberg 
August 15, 2025 
Page 4 
 
   
 
Regarding concerns over those who do not own a smartphone being able to access this 
information if only available through QR code, many larger stores have scanning kiosks 
customers can use to learn more about products and consumers could always ask retail 
employees for help accessing the information as well. No method of transmitting product 
information will be 100% accessible, however, as even on-label disclosures are not universally 
accessible for every community given language barriers, literacy challenges, or consumers that 
might be visually impaired. QR code accessibility can actually help to close these gaps by 
providing product information in diﬀerent languages and allowing auditory text-to-speech 
access on devices.  
 
Our position that QR codes would be accessible and beneﬁcial for consumers is not just based 
on theory—these QR codes containing nutrient content information are currently deployed in 
retail locations across a wide variety of markets, including the United States. Based on one 
DISCUS member’s recent data, U.S. consumers are their most active QR scanning population 
across markets, making up 18% of all scanners worldwide. In December 2024 alone, over 15,000 
individuals scanned just one company’s distilled spirits QR codes in the United States.   
 
QR codes provide consumers with the ability to make even more informed purchasing decisions 
because they would potentially have access to more information than they would if information 
was limited to what was physically available on pack, given space constraints. Based on member 
experience with QR codes and electronic labels ("e-labels") in other markets, we believe QR 
codes provide consumers with suﬃcient access to Alcohol Facts information at retail without 
creating disproportional barriers to access for particular communities. One member indicated 
that they currently utilize QR codes across their entire portfolio for consumers to access e-
labels, and they have been successfully implemented on over half a billion bottles across 166 
markets with tailor-made information in local languages to ensure consumer accessibility. These 
e-labels link to webpages that can include, for example, (i) information about the moderate 
consumption guidelines issued by regional health authorities where the QR code is scanned, (ii) 
the full list of nutritional information per portion and per 100 mL, (iii) basic information about 
the company and relevant brand for the purpose of education, and more. 
 
In that same paragraph of the NPRM referenced above, TTB “recognizes that access to 
technology and cultural norms surrounding the provision of information via electronic means 
are rapidly advancing and seeks comment on whether any ﬁnal rule should allow the proposed 
Alcohol Facts information to be disclosed via electronic means.”
6 If you looked back to 
consumer QR code usage pre-2020, the numbers would look very diﬀerent to their level of 
integration and usage now. By 2030, we may experience another leap in technological 
accessibility that accelerates the consumer experience with QR codes and cements the e-label’s  
  
 
6 Consumer Aﬀairs – Cell phone statistics 2025, available at https://www.consumeraﬀairs.com/cell_phones/cell-phone-
statistics.html. Ms. Amy Greenberg 
August 15, 2025 
Page 5 
 
   
 
role in providing valuable product information across all consumer goods. This potential 
outcome is far more likely than seeing a decrease in digitally-communicated consumer product 
information.  
 
Additionally, overcrowded labels have been shown to not be helpful for consumers and do not 
serve the need of adequately informing them regarding product details or components. This is 
especially salient for small container sizes, like 50ml bottles. Thus, requiring this additional 
information, in conjunction with other potential labelling details, such as allergens and 
ingredients, to be placed on label could have the opposite eﬀect, whereby consumers simply 
tune out all information provided. Introducing such a requirement would be especially 
burdensome for small producers. In order to avoid unnecessary barriers to entry and the 
resulting reduced choice for consumers, regulation should not be overly prescriptive in terms of 
format or compliance mechanisms. Rules should be easy to apply even for the smallest operator 
and should acknowledge the dominant mechanism consumers employ for learning about 
product information is via online searching.  
 
If the Bureau ultimately decides to allow QR code nutrient content statements, standards could 
be set requiring explanatory text to accompany the QR code on-label, as well as how the 
resulting QR code website should appear. This might provide TTB more comfort that there is a 
more uniform method of encountering this information on-label and on the ultimate landing 
page to help manage the consumer experience and expectations.  
 
B. QR Codes Promote International Eﬃciencies, Export Potential & Geo Sensitivity  
 
The ﬂexibility QR codes allow also provides important international eﬃciencies and growth 
opportunities to more U.S. distillers by allowing for greater expansion into export markets. For 
example, QR codes are sophisticated enough now to be made “geo sensitive,” allowing for 
diﬀerent languages or information to be displayed based on the location where it is scanned.  
 
This ﬂexibility would also facilitate consistency across European markets, given the newly 
implemented wine regulations and spirits commitment to place certain nutrient information on 
websites that can be accessed via a QR code on label. Other parts of the world also have 
diﬀerent requirements than those proposed in the NPRM, and adoption of this rule will increase 
the probability that U.S. labels aren't accepted into other markets, thereby requiring additional 
stickering or an even more burdensome process of relabeling bottles altogether. This, in turn, 
will cause the management of additional SKUs and label creation, which equates to additional 
cost to bring products into international markets. These amount to market barriers that 
dissuade new entrants and directly impact competition.  
 
As spiritsEUROPE notes in their comment in this docket, the EU spirits sector created an 
ambitious self-regulatory approach to provide consumers with energy information included on 
the back label and the full nutrient content information (including fat, carbohydrates and Ms. Amy Greenberg 
August 15, 2025 
Page 6 
 
   
 
protein) made available via a QR code present on the label. spiritsEUROPE’s latest report on the 
implementation of the provision of this nutrition information from June 2024 shows that the 
share of spirits with on-pack energy information and a QR Code has grown from 0% to 70% in 
just 5 years. In addition, over 900 spirits producers in the EU have created and activated close to 
40,000 QR code labels. They report that more than 75% of all spirits volume sold will feature e-
labels by the end of 2025 and that companies are also increasingly mirroring this approach 
outside of the EU, on a voluntary basis. Having this ﬂexibility in the EU to use QR codes, while 
requiring all information on-pack here in the U.S. could have very real impacts on production 
eﬃciencies and create undue ﬁnancial burdens for all companies participating in both markets.  
 
Aligning U.S. and EU requirements on displaying nutrient content information would be 
incredibly beneﬁcial for producers on both sides of the Atlantic, especially since the EU 
requirements for wine have also been widely adopted by the spirits sector, including well 
beyond the EU. Companies are already fully integrated into the QR space internationally and 
any large-scale deviation, particularly in the largest marketplace, would send shockwaves 
around the world and amongst the companies who have both U.S. and European brands.  
 
C. QR Codes Promote Sustainable Practices and Cut Down on Label Waste 
 
A QR code or website option results in production eﬃciencies for distillers that provide this 
information in multiple markets around the world and also allows for greater ﬂexibility in 
making any necessary changes to the nutrient or ingredient information. With on-label 
declarations, if anything changes in the product formulation, it would require a large-scale 
logistical eﬀort to reprint the labels that can take years to implement, swap out product in the 
marketplace, and change marketing campaigns. Whereas with information provided via a QR 
code or website, a change can be completed in real time with no physical waste through a 
simple revision of the text on the webpage.  
 
These options help reduce unnecessary waste—allowing for this digital labeling could help save 
hundreds of thousands of labels, point-of-sale materials, and other marketing materials from 
being sent to the landﬁll anytime a product formulation changes. From a design and 
sustainability perspective, our members aim to reduce the size of paper labels across all 
products to minimize the materials used and impact on our environment. Utilizing QR codes 
instead of Alcohol Facts statements would help producers avoid the need to create larger labels 
and thus a larger volume of materials needed.  
 
Having the ability to display this information through a digital solution allows for a more even 
distribution of competition in the marketplace. Industry members can quickly pivot in the digital 
space, providing real time information to the consumer. Label inventory management can be 
better controlled since there wouldn't be a need for obsolescence of labels when there are 
changes to alcohol facts (e.g. a sugar reduction project which may only aﬀect calories and  
  Ms. Amy Greenberg 
August 15, 2025 
Page 7 
 
   
 
carbohydrate values). A digital solution also reduces the chances of there being multiple labels 
in market for the same brand as it goes through a reformulation. This, in turn, helps avoid 
consumer confusion when they see labels with diﬀerent values side by side. 
 
Other areas of growing interest to consumers such as sustainability-related information on the 
product or re-use/recycling information can also easily be integrated into digital labels. For 
example, in Italy, mandatory recycling information for glass bottles may be provided in a geo-
localised manner via QR-code-accessible digital labels. This is increasingly important even 
domestically, as diﬀerent states adopt environmental or sustainability regulations requiring 
certain label declarations. These eﬃciencies add up to keep the beverage alcohol industry aﬂoat 
and help smaller producers maintain their business amidst ever-changing regulations.   
 
For these reasons, we respectfully request the Bureau allow producers the option of utilizing a 
QR code or website reference to display any nutrient content information mandated by this 
proposal.  
 
2. The Anticipated Costs Associated with This Proposal Will Be Signiﬁcant and Not 
Commensurate with the Beneﬁts 
 
DISCUS and its members greatly appreciate the Bureau’s thorough and detailed cost analysis 
outlined in the NPRM and eﬀorts to keep potential costs down for industry members, 
particularly for smaller participants in the marketplace. TTB’s decision not to require product 
testing and to provide a robust implementation period will go a long way to reducing the 
potential cost burden on producers resulting from this rule. However, the anticipated ﬁnancial 
impact of this rule cannot be overlooked, as it will still be signiﬁcant and potentially unbearable 
for some marketplace participants, especially given the current economic downturn in the 
industry. Flexibility for producers, including the ability to utilize QR codes or website references, 
is critically important and would blunt much of these anticipated ﬁnancial hardships and allow 
for a more reasoned implementation of this proposal.  
 
A. Diﬃcult Moment in the Spirits Industry to Introduce Additional Regulatory Burdens 
 
The distilled spirits sector, and overall beverage alcohol industry, is currently dealing with a 
multitude of headwinds and external constraints, which have resulted in a constricting and 
increasingly diﬃcult marketplace in which to operate. The slowing post-pandemic marketplace 
has hampered U.S. spirits industry revenue, which decreased by $424M in 2024—a 1.1% year 
over year decline
7—and these trends have only continued in 2025. According to the National 
Beverage Alcohol Control Association (NABCA), in control states, spirits dollar sales are down 
1.4% annually in the 12-month period ending in May 2025.

DISCUS-Annual-Economic-Brieﬁng-Presentation-2025.pdf. 
8 NABCA Monthly Report – May 2025 Control States Results. Ms. Amy Greenberg

Mexico have also declined 16% in April and 18%9 in May in terms of dollar value compared to 
same month a year ago and, from March through the end of April, sales of U.S. spirits in Canada 
plummeted more than 66%10, highlighting the growing trade-related challenges for the industry.  
 
Operating a craft distillery already comes with signiﬁcant ﬁnancial risks—with small margins, 
intense competition, distribution obstacles, challenges building brand equity, rising production 
and materials costs due to inﬂation and tariﬀs, and the daily responsibility of welcoming visitors 
to your distillery and tasting room and keeping your staﬀ paid on time. This economic 
environment has only exacerbated the ﬁnancial constraints on craft distilleries around the 
country. A quick Google search can highlight the sheer number of craft distilleries that have 
closed or ﬁled for bankruptcy over the last several years, as they contend with these broader 
marketplace challenges, which have resulted in craft spirits sales declining by volume and value 
in 2023 for the ﬁrst time.11  
 
Even the larger multinational producers are contending with these economic headwinds by 
downsizing staﬀ, selling oﬀ assets like brands and sites, and even pausing production at 
distilleries around the world. The beverage alcohol industry has been navigating a challenging 
market for the last few years and is being further impacted by ongoing trade disputes. Staﬀ at 
beverage alcohol companies, already dealing with team reductions in many cases, are also 
being tasked with navigating increasingly burdensome regulatory requirements, such as 
extended producer responsibility (EPR) initiatives across a number of states. With the larger 
companies simply trying to keep up with these evolving requirements, smaller producers are at 
a distinct disadvantage as they most likely do not have internal compliance expertise and thus 
need to engage costly outside consultants. 
 
Given these myriad of challenges, it’s not hyperbole to posit that the adoption of this proposal 
with the assumed costs discussed in the NPRM could lead to the closure of even more craft 
distilleries and further attrition throughout the industry. The distilled spirits sector truly cannot 
withstand any additional unplanned regulatory expenditures.

information related to their products, which they argue should reduce overall costs for the 
industry, this information is often being provided through a host of diﬀerent means and formats 
so label redesign will be inevitable for essentially all producers. The NPRM references the 
DISCUS Serving Facts Commitment as one such initiative. The DISCUS Commitment directs

have diverse portfolios of wine, beer, and spirits products that would all need to be relabeled. It 
is clear that this proposal is likely to cost the industry millions of dollars—on the low end—and 
could potentially hamper future innovation or personalization in label design with the prospect 
of increased costs and decreased ﬂexibility. TTB recognizes the potentially severe ﬁnancial 
implications of this proposal when they “estimate the one-time total relabeling costs associated 
with this proposed rule to be approximately $214 million (or $43 million per year) assuming a 
compliance date of 5 years.”
14  
 
The costs estimated by the Bureau most likely fall short of the actual costs of implementing this 
proposal and pose an unreasonable burden on industry members. Allowing ﬂexibility and a 
cost-eﬀective option in QR codes or website references is the only way that distilled spirits

producers across the board can aﬀord to provide nutrient content information to consumers at

C. Voluntary Testing Costs Should Be Included in TTB’s Cost Estimates   
 
DISCUS agrees that the Bureau should be including the cost of voluntary testing in their cost 
analysis estimates. While testing is thankfully not required in the proposal, industry members 
will likely choose to test some of their products, either initially upon development or routinely 
as batches or formulas change to ensure accurate reporting of the nutrients on label. The 
testing frequency and ultimate cost would vary depending on the size of the company, brand 
portfolio, and characteristics of the particular distilled spirits plant and/or production line.  
 
Most distillers are small businesses and are not familiar with nutrient calculations, and any 
additional compliance burdens can quickly become expensive hurdles for smaller players in the 
industry. For example, many craft distillers may have to hire consultants or companies to handle 
these label/formula elements for their brands, adding costs that they cannot aﬀord in an 
already constricting and diﬃcult marketplace. As we heard from small distillers in the ﬁrst 
comment period on these topics last year, even the act of redesigning and reprinting labels to ﬁt 
this additional information will prove costly, as many do not design these in-house, with some 
distillers in the listening sessions predicting it would cost them thousands of dollars to comply. 
While many craft distillers may utilize calculation methods and databases to prepare their 
nutrient content information, there will be a signiﬁcant proportion of them that will not have 
the time or resources necessary to learn how to integrate these tools and will feel obligated to 
send their products oﬀ to the lab for testing—often, as TTB notes in the NPRM, at several 
hundred dollars per test at many of the preeminent industry labs.  
 
TTB themselves state that “[i]f…industry members will continue to send each product 
formulation for analytical testing each year, the ongoing annualized cost of the proposed rule 
would be approximately $64 million.”
 15 Even spread out over the vast numbers of distillers, 
brewers, vintners, and importers in the United States marketplace, this recurring cost would 
place an unnecessary burden on producers who are simply trying to comply with this regulation 
and ensure their data is accurate.  
 
D. Potential for Signiﬁcant Burdens and Impacts on TTB Staﬀ  
 
When considering new labeling proposals, it is critical to also ensure that any new regulations 
do not overburden TTB staﬀ or create confusion for industry members, consumers, and the 
Bureau alike. While this proposal would thankfully not require the submission of additional  
 
15 90 Fed. Reg. at 6682. Ms. Amy Greenberg 
August 15, 2025 
Page 11 
 
   
 
certiﬁcates of label approval (COLAs) to facilitate the inclusion of the nutrient content 
statements, the Bureau still has the daunting task of ensuring industry compliance with the rule.  
 
Unfortunately, we understand that the Bureau has undergone signiﬁcant attrition (over 20% 
agency wide) over the course of this year in response to the whole of government staﬀ 
reductions and early retirements, and that TTB is unable to backﬁll any vacancies due to a 
federal hiring freeze until at least October. As a result, TTB staﬀ are being asked to do more with 
less and would have a diﬃcult time implementing and enforcing additional regulatory 
responsibilities under these circumstances. While we would like to think TTB will have their 
staﬃng and budgetary apportionments raised over the next few years, there is no indication 
that this will be the case, and the Bureau should reassess the proposal through this lens. 
 
Even before the staﬀ losses in 2025, TTB, as a whole, had been experiencing signiﬁcant levels of 
attrition over the last several years, including losing roughly 15% of their workforce from 2020-
2022 through a combination of retirements and other departures.
16 This substantial attrition 
has also been seen in the Alcohol Labeling and Formulation Division (ALFD) with the staﬀ tasked 
with conducting these label and formula reviews. Adding increased label or formula 
components will necessitate specialist review and experience and, thus, has the potential to add 
substantial burdens for TTB staﬀ and delays for industry members in the review and approval 
processes. The Bureau has demonstrated considerable positive gains in this area over the last 
decade; delays and label returns have the potential to undo some of this progress, as they have 
signiﬁcant impacts on product timelines and can upend routes to market, seasonal product 
releases, state brand registrations, marketing campaigns, and production schedules. 
 
If mandatory nutrient labeling is implemented, TTB will need to assess how to approach current 
labels in the marketplace and how to ensure industry member compliance with the rules, both 
of which will inevitably lead to complicated implementation and procedural questions. Will TTB 
staﬀ have the bandwidth and technical expertise to assess and review nutrient content 
statements for accuracy? What’s to stop a bad actor from simply including arbitrary numbers on 
their labels? While it’s not cost eﬀective or feasible for TTB to test each product to ensure 
accuracy, there surely must be the need for some oversight and market compliance programs in 
place, which will deplete the Bureau’s budget and staﬀ time. These technical considerations 
could potentially increase burdens on TTB staﬀ and industry members alike and need to be 
thoroughly contemplated during this rulemaking process.

Another consideration the Bureau will need to assess as they prepare a ﬁnal rule is the 
deregulatory priorities of the Trump Administration. In the Trump Administration’s Executive 
Order on “Unleashing Prosperity Through Deregulation” (January 31, 2025), agencies have been

directed to identify at least 10 prior regulations for elimination for each new regulation issued, 
as well as to “ensure that the total incremental cost of all new regulations, including repealed

Given the Bureau’s own extensive and substantial cost estimates included in the NPRM, it

The distilled spirits industry generally supports our regulatory structure, and we have based our

We respectfully suggest that oﬀering compliance ﬂexibility to regulated entities will be key to
