comment_text_sources:
[{'source': 'DIRECT (NON-ATTACHMENT)', 'text': 'As a primary care doctor, I have a front row seat to the harm caused by alcohol. I've seen plenty of patients who had no idea that alcohol played a role in their disease, whether it was cancer or liver disease.

I strongly support the proposed Alcohol Facts labeling rule and urge you to take it one step further: require standard drink information and explicit cancer warnings on every alcohol label.

Alcohol is not an ordinary consumer product. Even moderate use increases the risk of several cancers. Without clear, accessible information, consumers cannot make fully informed choices. We already do this for other products with health risks. Alcohol should be no exception to the rule.

The TTB should require the following on alcoholic beverage containers:
(1) Standard drink labeling
Listing the number of standard drinks per container would make it far easier for consumers to track their intake, as opposed to ABV and product volume that requires a complex calculation. Studies from Canada’s Yukon territory show that when standard drink information is displayed on alcoholic beverage containers, it is highly effective.

(2) A clear cancer warning.\u2028
U.S. labels currently warn about drinking during pregnancy and impaired driving, but they do not explicitly mention cancer. Yet the evidence is clear: alcohol, even in small amounts, can increase the risk of breast, colon, and other cancers. The World Health Organization, the U.S. Surgeon General, and countries like Ireland have already called for these warnings. The study from Yukon, Canada also found that a simple label “Alcohol can cause cancer” boosted public awareness of the relationship between alcohol and cancer.

By adding these two elements, the TTB could create a labeling standard that is not only informative, but life-saving. Alcohol use is common; its risks should therefore be common knowledge. Giving people the tools to understand what they’re drinking and the health risks involved is a basic public health responsibility.

I strongly support the current proposal and encourage the TTB to strengthen it with standard drink labeling and cancer warnings. These are small changes with the potential for a large impact by protecting health, saving lives, and ensuring consumers have the facts they need.

Please prioritize the health and lives of Americans over alcohol industry profits. '}]
comment_text:
As a primary care doctor, I have a front row seat to the harm caused by alcohol. I've seen plenty of patients who had no idea that alcohol played a role in their disease, whether it was cancer or liver disease.

I strongly support the proposed Alcohol Facts labeling rule and urge you to take it one step further: require standard drink information and explicit cancer warnings on every alcohol label.

Alcohol is not an ordinary consumer product. Even moderate use increases the risk of several cancers. Without clear, accessible information, consumers cannot make fully informed choices. We already do this for other products with health risks. Alcohol should be no exception to the rule.

The TTB should require the following on alcoholic beverage containers:
(1) Standard drink labeling
Listing the number of standard drinks per container would make it far easier for consumers to track their intake, as opposed to ABV and product volume that requires a complex calculation. Studies from Canada’s Yukon territory show that when standard drink information is displayed on alcoholic beverage containers, it is highly effective.

(2) A clear cancer warning. 
U.S. labels currently warn about drinking during pregnancy and impaired driving, but they do not explicitly mention cancer. Yet the evidence is clear: alcohol, even in small amounts, can increase the risk of breast, colon, and other cancers. The World Health Organization, the U.S. Surgeon General, and countries like Ireland have already called for these warnings. The study from Yukon, Canada also found that a simple label “Alcohol can cause cancer” boosted public awareness of the relationship between alcohol and cancer.

By adding these two elements, the TTB could create a labeling standard that is not only informative, but life-saving. Alcohol use is common; its risks should therefore be common knowledge. Giving people the tools to understand what they’re drinking and the health risks involved is a basic public health responsibility.

I strongly support the current proposal and encourage the TTB to strengthen it with standard drink labeling and cancer warnings. These are small changes with the potential for a large impact by protecting health, saving lives, and ensuring consumers have the facts they need.

Please prioritize the health and lives of Americans over alcohol industry profits.
document_title: Notice No. 237:  Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages

comment_text_sources:
[{'source': 'https://downloads.regulations.gov/TTB-2025-0002-0180/attachment_1.pdf', 'text': 'SWA RESPONSE - Docket No. TTB–2025–0003; Notice No. 237 1 15 August 2025 Director Regulations and Ruling Division , Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau 1310 G Street NW, Box 12 Washington, DC 20005 Re: Docket No. TTB -2025-0002; Notices No. 237 and 238 – Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages; and Major Food Allergen Labeling for Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages Dear Director, The Scotch Whisky Association (SWA) is grateful for the opportunity to provide comments to The Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau (TTB) regarding Docket No. TTB -2025-0002; Notice No. 237 on Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits. The SWA is the Scotch Whisky industry ’s trade association . We have over 90 member companies, from multinational spirits producers through to small family -run distillers, bottlers, blenders, and brand owners. Membership accounts for around 97% of the Scotch Whisky industry by production. Any rulemaking in this area is important for the SWA as the United States has long been the Scotch Whisky’s biggest market by value, with exports worth £971 million in 2024. In addition, many of our larger members are also investors in the United States. We fully support TTB's efforts to ensure that consumers have the relevant product information to make informed decisions. Our members have been doing this domestically and in their export markets, and consumers are already familiar with this practice. We w ould therefore like to submit specific comments below for your consideration on behalf of the Scotch Whisky industry. I. Notice No. 237 on Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages Additional on -product labelling requirements present numerous disadvantages both to consumers and businesses, particularly SMEs. Distilled spirits are one of the most highly regulated products in the United States, subject to rigorous pre -approval processes for labels and formulas. Despite this, the industry has proactively developed and implemented various self-regulatory initiatives to provide consumers with additional non -mandatory product information, exceeding TTB guidelines. For example, many distille rs already disclose allergen details and “Serving Facts” statements either on labels, websites, or via QR codes, SWA RESPONSE - Docket No. TTB–2025–0003; Notice No. 237 2 demonstrating the industry’s leadership in enhancing product transparency. Companies using digital labelling in international markets have reported clear benefits. Voluntary information currently provided by our industry is displayed through a host of different means and formats . Specifying mandatory labelling requirements will therefore inevitably cost every spirit producer, as they will be required to incur some form of label redesign and printing costs, no matter their current level of voluntary disclosure of product information. The SWA therefore recommends retaining the voluntary approach to additional product information. However, should the TTB pursue a mandato ry regime, we recommend the following considerations be taken into account. A key concern for us is to ensure that new rules are as flexible as possible, and do not result in unnecessary cost or burden for companies, while improving information to consumers. Product Information Statement: Serving Facts v. Alcohol Facts We recommend that the title of the alcohol beverages information statement be “Serving Facts” instead of “Alcohol Facts” as the content of the statement refers to the serving size and the nutritional information in a serving of a specific alcoholic beverag e. “Alcohol Facts” could confuse consumers as it may suggest that the statement includes general indications on the consumption of alcoholic beverages. In addition, consumers are accustomed to finding nutritional information in a “Serving Facts” statement because most operators who currently voluntarily disclose the information use “Serving Facts” as the title. Changing the labels of alcoholic beverages would generate additional costs for manufacturers, importers, and distributors, negatively affecting an industry that already works well in disclosing information effectively. Display of the Product Information Statement: Digital labelling benefits We continue to recommend that “Serving Facts” information be allowed to be provided through digital labelling, particularly via digital QR codes. Spirits labels are already required to include a great deal of information in the same field of vision. Numero us studies have concluded that the more health information a physical label has, the less attention the consumer pays to that information. To avoid over-crowding labels, and consequently confusing consumers, any newly required information should be allowed to be provided through a website or QR code. While some consumer organisations oppose digital labelling on the grounds that it places the burden on consumers and puts them at a disadvantage , there are no significant studies that support this argument. Digital labelling is not prohibitive for consumers considering that over 90% of adult Americans own a smartphone device and 95% of adults use the internet.1 Notably, mobile phone ownership amongst senior citizens has been found to be as high as 94%, with 76% owning smartphones.2 The three largest phone carriers in the US currently each claim that their 4G LTE network covers more than 99% of the US population, so consumers in both urban and rural areas should have access to the necessary coverage to access online information in retail settings. Furthermore, digital labels can assist with accessibility requirements, facilitating product information in multiple languages and allowing auditory text -to-speech access on devices. 1 Pew Research – Mobile Fact Sheet. January 31, 2024, https://www.pewresearch.org/internet/fact-sheet/mobile/#who- owns-cellphones-and-smartphone; Pew Research – Internet, Broadband Fact Sheet. January 31, 2024, https://www.pewresearch.org/internet/fact-sheet/internet-broadband/. 2 Consumer Affairs – Cell phone statistics 2025. https://www.consumeraffairs.com/cell_phones/cell-phone-statistics.html SWA RESPONSE - Docket No. TTB–2025–0003; Notice No. 237 3 Some research suggests that gender, age, education and socioeconomic status might not have significant influence on intention to purchase product with a QR code applied to it. Additionally, the presence of QR codes on products correlates to increased consumer comprehension and confidence about the product they are buying. It was likened to being in a traditional market, where one can speak to a vendor; a QR code allows the consu mer to find out much more than they would normally be able to do in a supermarket. QR codes also reduce the chances of there being multiple labels in market for the same brand as it goes through reformulation. This assists with avoiding consumer confusion when they encounter brand labels with different values side by side. Consumers are more trusting of digital label claims, in particular about the traceability of ingredients and components, manufacturing processes and environmental claims.3 Today, digital labelling has become a universally accessible, convenient, and user -friendly feature, with consumers being able to access information easily through means of a smart phone or other electronic device. Digital labelling comes with several additional benefits: • Reduction of Costs for SMEs: Digital labelling allows for quick adaptation to new legal requirements without having to design and print new labels. All companies, but especially SMEs, will reduce labelling costs and will have the opportunity to explore new export markets around the w orld, including the US. This will benefit foreign companies, but also US distillers, who will be able to use labels that are commonly used internationally with only additional information to be modified online. • Sustainability: digital labelling is beneficial for environmental protection, as it reduces waste and costs associated with changes to traditional physical labels. Many sectors (including the Scotch Whisky industry) are committed to sustainable packaging practices, of which labels are an essential part. The destruction of labels that are commonly used in the US market and the process of printing new la bels, with the significant amount of energy involved, will have a major environmental impact. This could be a recurring issue every time labelling regulations are updated. However, by using digital labelling businesses can reduce waste, conserve resources, and positively impact the environment. • Geo-specific information: Recycling information and other sustainability -related information which are location -specific can easily be integrated into digital labels. One such example in Europe is in Italy, where mandatory recycling information for glass bottles can be provided in a geo-localised manner via QR-code-accessible digital labels since last year. Digital labels have been broadly implemented as a solution to provide access to product information for consumers across Europe, and we believe this could be replicated for US consumers. The future of food and beverage labelling is digital. The use of this innovative measure is transformative and beneficial for the US market, where almost 97% of the population owns a mobile phone. Future trends predict that the number of American smartphone users will increase to more than 364 million people by 2040 4. Digital labelling would be more effective in enabling consumers to make informed choices about their health, dietary restrictions, and the environmental impact of their consumption. 3 Digital Labelling in the EU State -of-play Report. EDELMAN for Food FoodDrinkEurope. See: https://www.fooddrinkeurope.eu/wp-content/uploads/2024/01/FoodDrinkEurope_State-of-play-research-report-on- digital-labelling_May-2023.pdf 4 Consumer Affairs – Cell phone statistics 2025. See: https://www.consumeraffairs.com/cell_phones/cell-phone- statistics.html SWA RESPONSE - Docket No. TTB–2025–0003; Notice No. 237 4 In the undesirable situation where nutritional information could only be provided on a physical label, we kindly request to be given the option of using a linear display that is not surrounded by a box. The space available for labelling distilled spirits is limited and a box around the claim would unnecessarily take up space on the label. In addition, we believe that the title “Serving Facts” in bold type is sufficient to allow consumers to easily locate the information on the label. Furthermore, we request that TTB, at minimum, consider allowing producers to list only nutrients present in the product instead of having to print the entire statement with multiple zeros. We would like to stress that, pursuant to Articles 2.2 and 2.3 of the WTO TBT Agreement, technical regulations shall not be prepared, adopted, or applied with the purpose or effect of creating unnecessary obstacles to international trade to fulfill the legitimate objectives of member states. Content of Product Information Statement Distilled spirits are not significant sources of nutritional value for consumers. Scotch Whisky, under UK regulation, can only be produced in Scotland from cereals, water and yeast, with no flavourings or sweeteners. Because of the stringently regulated di stillation process, Scotch Whisky spirits do not contain carbohydrates, fat, or protein. Requiring extensive nutritional information on labels, especially when most of the nutritional facts are not applicable to distilled spirits, risks confusing consumers into the belief that they have a "nutritional benefit” and that some alcoholic beverages are more nutritious than others. This is especially so if the statement contains additional information such as protein, vitamins and minerals, sodium, and further breakdown of fats, as considered in Notice No. 237. TTB asked for views on greater harmonization with the Food and Drug Administration’s (FDA) nutrient content statements. We believe this would be unnecessary and misleading for the same reasons outlined above. No other country requires daily value information for listed nutrients on distilled spirits labels, as it would deviate from common global practices . It is well -understood that the consumption of spirits provide no significant nutritional value and is not part of a consumer’s daily dietary needs. Furthermore, the adoption of FDA nutrition facts levels on spirits would also impose significant costs and burdens to our industry. The SWA therefore recommends that any nutritional information required to be provided under the “Serving Facts” be limited in scope and accessible via QR code. If the TTB adopts the requirement for a “Serving Facts” statement, the SWA would also recommend the following: • We welcome the proposed 20% tolerance for energy and nutritional calculations. It would be beneficial for TTB to explicitly recognise that producers can continue to rely on databases and calculators to provide nutrient content information without having to undertake costly and burdensome laboratory testing on each of their products, particularly for brand extensions that might have variation in ABV from bottle to bottle, such as cask-strength whiskies. • The “Serving Facts” statement should not be required to include the alcohol content statement. For distilled spirits, the ABV is already required to appear in the same field of vision as the brand name and the class designation. Consumers are accustomed to finding this information on the main/front label. Particularly in the case of physical labels, space is limited and including it to the “Serving Facts” would not add any value. • We kindly request to keep the provision of the quantity of pure alcohol per serving in the “Serving Facts” statement optional. Providing this information without context would not necessarily empower consumers to make informed choices if the concept of pur e alcohol is not well understood. The presence of a QR code on a label could facilitate the provision of substantive information on the concepts of pure alcohol and standard SWA RESPONSE - Docket No. TTB–2025–0003; Notice No. 237 5 drinks, as well as TTB’s Dietary Guidelines, which would not be practically feasible on a physical label. • We would welcome more flexibility from TTB on the proposed serving sizes , which can vary from country to country depending on the ABV of the product. For instance, Scotch Whisky has a wide variety of products, some of which go beyond 40% ABV and for which the serving size would differ. Furthermore, r igid one-size-fits-all serving size requirements based on ABV could lead to several unintended consequences. This includes consumers incorrectly conflat ing “serving size” with recommended consumption amount, the latter of which may drastically differ depending on the brand and ABV. This is especially so when the spirit is consumed as part of a mixed drink. Rigid serving sizes may undermine brand integrity and inadvertently encourage higher alcohol and calorie consumption. For these reasons, we recommend TTB’s proposed serving size guidelines remain optional, while permitting customized serving sizes where justified by product type and consumption patterns. • We welcome the fact that TTB will not require operators to submit new COLA applications when the only change being made to a label is the inclusion or alteration of the “Serving Facts” statement. This should also be extended to the case where the only change is the inclusion or al teration of the QR code, if it is permitted to provide the “Serving Facts” statement in this manner. Compliance Period, Stock Exhaustion, Alignment with TTB Notice No. 238 In the event the proposed rulemaking contained in Notice No. 237 is adopted, the SWA endorses the proposed transition period of 5 years. Any shorter period for compliance would present difficulties for our members given our sector’s current economic climate. Furthermore, we would like to request the possibility for our operators to exhaust all their stock which was put on the market before the proposed rule comes into effect. The stock turnover of our products can often be slower than for other categories of distilled spirits. Finally, we further recommend that its implementation is aligned with that of Notice No. 238 on Major Food Allergen Labeling for Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages, along with any other ingredient labeling proposal TTB might be considering . This would allow businesses to comply with all labelling requirements within similar implementation periods. In conclusion, the Scotch Whisky industry remains firmly committed to ensuring consumers have access to clear and relevant product information. However, we respectfully urge the TTB to carefully assess the potential impact of any new requirements —both to a void placing undue burdens on businesses, particularly SMEs, and to prevent consumer confusion regarding the nature of our products. Yours sincerely, María José Kong Head of Trade Americas Scotch Whisky Association '}, {'source': 'DIRECT (NON-ATTACHMENT)', 'text': 'The Scotch Whisky Association (SWA) is grateful for the opportunity to provide comments regarding Docket No. TTB-2025-0002; Notice No. 237 on Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages. The SWA is the Scotch Whisky industry’s trade association. We have over 90 member companies, from multinational spirits producers through to small family-run distillers, bottlers, blenders, and brand owners. Membership accounts for around 97% of the Scotch Whisky industry by production. Any rulemaking in this area is important for the SWA as the United States has long been the Scotch Whisky’s biggest market by value, with exports worth £971 million in 2024. In addition, many of our larger members are also investors in the United States. You will find our detailed comments in the attached file.

comment_text: The Scotch Whisky Association (SWA) is grateful for the opportunity to provide comments regarding Docket No. TTB-2025-0002; Notice No. 237 on Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages. The SWA is the Scotch Whisky industry’s trade association. We have over 90 member companies, from multinational spirits producers through to small family-run distillers, bottlers, blenders, and brand owners. Membership accounts for around 97% of the Scotch Whisky industry by production. Any rulemaking in this area is important for the SWA as the United States has long been the Scotch Whisky’s biggest market by value, with exports worth £971 million in 2024. In addition, many of our larger members are also investors in the United States. You will find our detailed comments in the attached file.

comment_text_sources:
[{'source': 'https://downloads.regulations.gov/TTB-2025-0002-0178/attachment_1.pdf', 'text': 'August 15, 2025 
Regulations and Ruling Division  
Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau  
1310 G Street NW, Box 12  
Washington, DC 20005 
Comment on Proposed Rule: Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, 
and Malt Beverages (Docket No. TTB-2025-0002) 
 
The undersigned organizations call on the Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau (TTB) to finalize 
the proposed rule mandating on-package labeling of alcohol content and nutritional information. These 
rules will be a step forward, as current alcohol labels do not provide the information that consumers need 
to make informed purchasing and consumption decisions. 
 
The “Alcohol Facts” panel set forth by the proposed rule includes “alcohol content expressed both as a 
percentage of alcohol by volume and in fluid ounces of pure ethyl alcohol per serving, the number of 
calories, and the number, in grams, of carbohydrates, fat, and protein, per serving.”
1  
While this information represents a major step forward, the rule could be strengthened by additionally 
requiring sugars in grams, added sugars in grams, saturated fat in grams, sodium in milligrams, percent 
Daily Value for each nutrient based on a 2,000-calorie diet, number of standard drinks per container, the 
conversion between standard drinks and fluid ounces of pure ethyl alcohol, and the 2020-2025 Dietary 
Guidelines for Americans moderate drinking advice. The final rule should also make dual-column 
labeling mandatory. 
This additional information is important as part of a commonsense approach to promoting transparency, 
health, and safety for those who consume alcohol. Excess alcohol consumption is associated with various 
harms including motor vehicle accidents, liver disease, cardiovascular disease, and certain cancers.2 
Alcoholic beverages may also contribute to other forms of diet-related chronic disease as alcohol is 
calorie-dense and on average accounts for 9% of daily calories for those who drink.3 Many alcoholic 
beverages also contain carbohydrates, added sugars, and other nutrients to limit. Alcohol content labeling 
is a straightforward approach that increases consumer awareness of the contents of alcoholic beverages 
through greater transparency.4 
 
Consumers desire this information and would use it to make decisions about alcohol consumption and 
purchasing. In a March 2024 poll of 1,509 adults who drink alcohol (commissioned by CSPI and 
conducted by Big Village), strong majorities (78-90%) said alcohol content, calorie content, and 
nutritional content, would be at least somewhat important for their alcohol purchasing decisions.
5 
 
We agree with the requirement in the proposed rule that the “Alcohol Facts” disclosure appear on-
package and never solely via electronic means (e.g., a QR code leading to a webpage), as this would 
specifically disadvantage populations that are less able to utilize smart phones or similar technology 
(including those who are older or living rurally). 
 
We urge TTB to prioritize transparency and health and finalize the proposed Alcohol Facts rule to ensure 
that Americans can make more informed decisions about what and how much to drink. To ensure timely 
consumer access to this important information, the final rule should adopt a shorter compliance period of 
3.5 years instead of the 5-year period proposed. 
 
  Sincerely, 
 
Alcohol Justice 
American Society for Nutrition 
Association of State Public Health Nutritionists 
Celiac Disease Foundation 
Center for Science in the Public Interest 
Consumer Federation of America 
Consumer Reports 
CURED 
FARE (Food Allergy Research & Education) 
Food Equality Initiative 
Interfaith Public Health Network 
National Consumers League 
Project Extra Mile 
Recover Alaska 
The FPIES Foundation 
U.S. Alcohol Policy Alliance 
Winooski Partnership for Prevention 
 
Individuals: 
 
Sarah Ermer, MPH, CHES 
Prevention Specialist 
Tillamook Family Counsel 
 
Thomas K. Greenfield 
Senior Scientist 
Alcohol Research Group 
 
Marissa Hall 
Assistant Professor 
University of North Carolina 
 
Kaela Plank 
Health Program Planner 
San Francisco Department of Public Health 
 
Lisa R. Young, PhD, RDN 
Adjunct Professor of Nutrition 
New York University 
 
  References 
 
1 90 Fed. Reg. 6654. Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt 
Beverages. 
2 World Health Organization. Global Status Report on Alcohol and Health.; 2018. Accessed March 22, 
2024. https://iris.who.int/bitstream/handle/10665/274603/9789241565639-eng.pdf?sequence=1  
3 Dietary Guidelines Advisory Committee. Scientific Report of the 2020 Dietary Guidelines Advisory 
Committee: Advisory Report to the Secretary of Agriculture and the Secretary of Health and Human 
Services. Part D. Chapter 11: Alcoholic Beverages. U.S. Department of Agriculture, Agricultural 
Research Service; 2020. Accessed March 6, 2024. 
https://www.dietaryguidelines.gov/sites/default/files/2020-07/PartD_Ch11_AlcoholicBev_first-print.pdf  
4 Wettlaufer A. Can a Label Help me Drink in Moderation? A Review of the Evidence on Standard Drink 
Labelling. Subst Use Misuse. 2018;53(4):585-595. doi:10.1080/10826084.2017.1349798 
5 Big Village’s CARAVAN U.S. Online Omnibus Survey, administered March 15-20, 2024. '}, {'source': 'DIRECT (NON-ATTACHMENT)', 'text': 'See attached file(s)'}]

Yes,  the  producers  who  are  already  voluntarily  disclosing  serving  facts  and  nutrition  information  
will
 
need
 
to
 
redo
 
all
 
of
 
their
 
existing
 
labels
 
at
 
significant
 
cost.
 
 
3.  Are  consumers  accustomed  to  finding  nutrient  content  information  in  a  Serving  Facts  
statement?
 
Would
 
changing
 
the
 
title
 
to
 
“Alcohol
 
Facts”
 
cause
 
confusion?
 
Yes,  as  described  above,  the  consumer  already  knows  to  look  for  the  alcohol  content  statement,  
and
 
the
 
serving
 
facts
 
should
 
remain
 
separate
 
from

distinguish
 
alcohol
 
beverages
 
from
 
other
 
food
 
items?
 
That  is  unknown,  as  it  does  not  currently  exist  in  any  form.  Alcohol  consumers  already  are  able  
to
 
distinguish
 
alcohol
 
beverages
 
from
 
other
 
food
 
items
 
through

Government
 
Warning
 
statement
 
and
 
alcohol
 
disclosure,
 
which
 
is
 
not
 
on
 
other
 
food

 Linear  Display,  Type  Size,  and  Electronic  Display  of  Alcohol  Facts  Information  
Linear  Display  
TTB  proposes  to  allow  the  option  of  a  linear  display  placed  on  the  container  (including  a  keg),  as  
long
 
as
 
it
 
is
 
set
 
apart
 
from
 
other
 
information
 
and
 
is
 
placed
 
inside
 
a
 
box
 
with
 
the
 
title
 
“Alcohol
 
Facts”
 
in
 
bold-faced
 
type.
 
WineAmerica  supports  the  option  of  a  linear  display  placed  on  a  container  with  the  moniker  
“Serving
 
Facts”
 
in
 
bold-faced
 
type,
 
separate
 
and
 
apart
 
from
 
the
 
existing
 
alcohol
 
content
 
disclosure.
 
We
 
agree
 
with
 
the
 
TTB’s
 
premise
 
that
 
the
 
linear
 
display
 
will
 
allow
 
information
 
to
 
fit
 
on
 
labels
 
of
 
most
 
containers
 
without
 
the

for
 
a
 
back
 
label,

requiring
 
the
 
linear
 
display
 
to
 
be
 
in
 
a
 
box
 
will

more
 
noticeable
 
to

believe
 
this
 
should
 
only
 
be
 
one
 
option
 
for
 
disclosure.
 
Type  Size  
TTB  is  proposing  that  the  minimum  type  size  requirements  for  Alcohol  Facts  statements  mirror  
existing

for

and

4,

and

respectively.
 
 
WineAmerica  agrees  with  TTB  for  on  label  disclosure,  if  the  producer  so  chooses  to  disclose  
their
 
serving
 
facts
 
information
 
on
 
label.
 
Electronic  Display  of  Alcohol  Facts  Information  
TTB  considered,  but  is  not  proposing,  to  allow  the  proposed  Alcohol  Facts  panel  to  be  
distributed
 
by
 
electronic
 
means
 
via

code,
 
or
 
other
 
marking
 
on
 
the

label
 
rather
 
than

the

to

on

itself.
 
TTB
 
believes

allowing

information
 
to

somewhere
 
other
 
than
 
the

would
 
decrease
 
consumer
 
accessibility
 
to

about

and

beverages.
 
WineAmerica  strongly  supports  the  disclosure  of  Serving  Facts  via  electronic  means.  The  
European
 
Union
 
has
 
already
 
allowed
 
for

and

makes
 
logical
 
sense

to

TTB
 
notes
 
that
 
industry
 
comments
 
in
 
the
 
2024
 
Listening
 
Sessions
 
reflected
 
this
 
by
 
outlining
 
our
 
argument
 
as
 
such:
 
1.  Web-based  disclosure  is  a  cost-efficient  means  to  provide  information  to  consumers  that  
provides
 
producers
 
with
 
flexibility
 
and
 
reduces
 
time
 
to
 
market.
 
If
 
a
 
consumer
 
wishes
 
to
 
access
 
the
 
information
 
they
 
are
 
able
 
to
 
without
 
creating
 
significant
 
financial
 
burden
 
to
 
the
 
producer.
 
2.  The  EU  has  already  implemented  this  system.  It  benefits  producers  to  not  have  to  
produce
 
more
 
than
 
one
 
label
 
for
 
the
 
products
 
sold
 
in
 
different
 
markets.
 
Additionally,
 
electronic
 
disclosure
 
allows
 
for
 
easier
 
tailoring
 
of
 
specific
 
information
 
to
 
different
 
markets
 
without
 
needing
 
to
 
print
 
various
 
different
 
labels.
 3.  Web-based  disclosure  is  more  consumer  friendly.  For  example,  a  QR  code  can  prevent  
labels
 
from
 
becoming
 
cluttered,
 
which
 
can
 
ultimately
 
be
 
distracting
 
for
 
the

We  will  now  address  TTB’s  specific  questions:  
1.  Would  consumers  have  trouble  locating  Alcohol  Facts  information  if  that  information  is  
presented
 
in
 
a
 
linear
 
display?
 
Consumers  would  not  have  trouble  locating  Serving  Facts  information  presented  in  a  linear  
display.
 
2.  Does  the  proposal  to  require  the  linear  display  to  appear  in  a  box  with  the  title  “Alcohol  
Facts”
 
in
 
bold-face
 
type
 
allow
 
consumers
 
to
 
better

the

should

be

the

to

a
 
box?
 
A  box  should  not  be  required.  The  title  should  not  be  labeled  as  “Alcohol  Facts”  but  as  “Serving  
Facts”.
 
3.  Do  consumers,  industry  members,  or  other  interested  parties  have  comments  on  the  type  size  
and
 
general

proposed
 
for
 
both

displays
 
and
 
panels?

4.  How  would  the  proposed  formatting  requirements,  including  the  linear  display  option,  affect  
the
 
costs
 
and
 
other
 
regulatory
 
burdens?
 
What
 
are
 
the
 
benefits
 
of
 
the
 
proposed
 
formatting
 
requirements?
 
Any  on-label  disclosure  will  increase  costs  for  producers.  Additionally,  there  is  limited  space  on  
a
 
label.
 
This
 
could
 
lead
 
to
 
clutter
 
on

and
 
consumer

an
 
“off-label”

is

and

burdens.

for

6.  What  alternatives  exist  to  convey  Alcohol  Facts  information  to  consumers?  How,  if  it  all,

the

information

There  should  be  an  “off-label”  option  for  disclosing  Serving  Facts.  This  will  allow  for  less  clutter  
on

7.  If  TTB  adopts  mandatory  Alcohol  Facts  labeling  for  alcohol  beverages,  should  it  include  the

TTB  should  allow  for  electronic  disclosure  of  Serving  Facts  labeling.  This  would  allow  for  the  
consumers
 
that

 (https://www.pewresearch.org/internet/fact-sheet/mobile/)  There  are  minimal  barriers  for  consumers  to  access  Serving  Facts  information  in  2025.  The  ubiquitousness  of  the  smartphone

 Serving  Size  Reference  Amounts  
TTB  is  proposing  that  for  wine  that  is  7%  to  16%  alcohol  by  volume  a  serving  be  considered  5

ounces
 
and

that

fluid

WineAmerica  supports  and  agrees  with  this.  We  also  agree  with  TTB  that  serving  size  reference  
amounts

On  the  specific  questions:

product
 
customarily

If

with

for

Ruling
 
2004-1

fl

Yes,  we  believe  this  is  accurate  for  wine.

ounces
 
is
 
a

are
 
widely

and
 
considered
 
to

the

serving
 
sizes
 
for
 
beverage
 
alcohol.
 
 
Dual  Column  Alcohol  Facts  Display  Panel  
WineAmerica  opposes  a  Serving  Facts  panel  on  wine  labels.  We  are  in  favor  of  a  linear  
disclosure,
 
or
 
a
 
web

off-label
 
disclosure.
 
 
Implementation  Period  
WineAmerica  agrees  with  TTB’s  proposal  of  a  five-year  implementation  period  for  Serving  
Facts
 
disclosure.

believe

of

the
 
label.

is
 
our

will
 
include
 
the
 
option
 
for
 
off-label
 
disclosure.
 
 
TTB  asks  if  producers  will  begin  the  necessary  changes  before  the  end  of  the  implementation

We
 
believe
 
that
 
this
 
will
 
be
 
the

Additional  Comments  on  Testing  of  Products  
WineAmerica  is  in  favor  of  disclosure  of  serving  facts,  but  in  a  way  that  is  not  over  burdensome  
to
 
wine
 
producers.
 
TTB
 
outlines
 
that
 
the
 
estimated
 
cost
 
of
 
changing
 
a
 
label
 
is
 
more
 
than
 
$1600
 
per
 
label.
 
This
 
cost
 
can
 
be
 
cut
 
down
 
considerably
 
if
 
an
 
off-label
 
disclosure
 
is
 
allowed.
 
●  Wineries  should  not  have  to  test  all  of  their  products  for  disclosure  of  serving  facts.  It  has  
been
 
estimated
 
that
 
it
 
could
 
cost
 
up
 
to
 
$500
 
per
 
product
 
if
 
comprehensive
 
testing

required.
 
The
 
proposed
 
rule
 
would
 
not
 
require
 
industry
 
members
 
to

each

to

for

prior

Industry

(for

to
 
accurately
 
label

WineAmerica
 
supports
 
this.
 
 ●  TTB  issued  public  guidance  to  broaden  the  tolerance  levels  for  calorie  statements  on  
labels
 
and
 
in
 
advertisements.
 
In
 
this
 
proposed
 
rule,
 
TTB
 
has
 
included
 
this
 
expanded
 
tolerance
 
level
 
for
 
calories,
 
and
 
is
 
adopting
 
an
 
objective
 
standard
 
for
 
the
 
three
 
nutrients
 
required
 
to
 
be
 
disclosed,
 
allowing
 
a
 
tolerance
 
of
 
20
 
percent
 
above
 
or
 
below
 
the
 
labeled
 
amount.
 
TTB
 
believes
 
that
 
these
 
proposed
 
changes
 
will
 
facilitate
 
the
 
use
 
of
 
“typical
 
values”
 
charts
 
and
 
other
 
methodologies
 
to
 
calculate
 
the
 
calories,
 
carbohydrates,

and

of
 
an

beverage
 
product.
 
TTB
 
is
 
also
 
proposing
 
to
 
expand
 
the
 
alcohol
 
content
 
tolerance
 
for
 
malt
 
beverage
 
labeling
 
statements.
 
This
 
means
 
bottlers
 
would
 
be
 
less
 
likely
 
to
 
have
 
to
 
change
 
labels
 
due
 
to
 
minor
 
variations
 
in
 
alcohol
 
content
 
among
 
different
 
batches.
 
Wine
 
America
 
supports
 
this
 
as
 
well.
 
 
Conclusion  
WineAmerica  would  like  to  thank  TTB  for  the  opportunity  to  comment  on  the  proposed  
rulemaking:
 
Notice
 
237:
 
Alcohol
 
Facts
 
Statements
 
in
 
the
 
Labeling
 
of
 
Wines,
 
Distilled
 
Spirits,
 
and
 
Malt
 
Beverages.
 
To
 
sum
 
up
 
our
 
main
 
points:
  ●  An  off-label/web  based  solution  should  be  allowed  for  disclosure  of  serving  facts.  ●  On-label  disclosure  should  be  in  a  linear  format.  ●  In  order  to  avoid  confusion,  the  disclosure  should  be  referred  to  as  SERVING  FACTS,  
not
 
ALCOHOL
 
FACTS.
 ●  Testing  of  each  product  should  not  be  required.  ●  We  hope  that  TTB  will  bear  in  mind  that  the  10,000+  American  wineries  are  
predominantly
 
small
 
family
 
farms
 
with
 
very
 
limited
 
resources,
 
and
 
that
 
$1600
 
per
 
label
 
and
 
$500
 
per
 
product
 
test
 
would
 
be
 
a
 
major
 
financial
 
burden.
  Respectfully  submitted.    Michael  Kaiser  Executive  Vice  President  and  Director  of  Government  Affairs

comment_text_sources:
[{'source': 'https://downloads.regulations.gov/TTB-2025-0002-0186/attachment_2.pdf', 'text': "Page 1 of 10  
 
 
August 15, 2025 
 
Ms. Amy Greenberg 
Director, Regulations and Rulings Division 
Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau  
1310 G Street NW, Box 12 
Washington, DC 20005 
 
RE: Docket No. TTB-2025-0002, Notice No. 237: Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of 
Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages  
 
Dear Ms. Greenberg, 
 
Wine Institute is the public policy advocacy association representing over 1,000 California 
wineries and affiliated businesses.  Our membership consists of wineries of all sizes including 
many small, family-owned wineries.  California is responsible for more than 81 percent of the 
nation’s wine production and more than 95 percent of US wine exports.   W e provide the 
following comments in response to Notice of Proposed Rulemaking No. 237: Alcohol Facts 
Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages (NPRM 237). 
 
In general, Wine Institute supports the current “Serving Facts” framework as voluntary.  If TTB 
imposes mandatory Serving Facts labeling, we respectfully request a similar framework but 
with several important recommendations and considerations that we outline below.   
 
1. Wine is Unique—it is not a Recipe Product—and Wineries Vary Greatly in Size 
 
It is important to note at the outset that wine is u nique.  Wine is not a recipe product.  Unlike 
other beverages, wine is inherently tied to its place of origin.  Every vintage is different, and 
each wine varies by year, winegrape varietal, location, climate and growing conditions.   
Because the winemaking process is dynamic and highly variable, decisions impacting 
nutritional content can be made right up to the time of blending and bottling.  This is significant 
because wine labels are most often printed many months in advance of bottling and changes 
to those labels can take up to two years to implement. 
Beyond the vineyard and winery, the wine marketplace is also distinct in terms of both the 
number of producers and unique wines available.   According to TTB, there are currently more 
than 17,500 bonded wine producers across the US  and approximately 6,300 of them are in 
California.  Like our membership, the overwhelming majority of these are small, family-owned 
Page 2 of 10  
wineries that operate in a heavily regulated industry with correspondingly high cost s in 
establishing and maintaining their businesses.  Therefore, it is critical that any new regulations 
be fiscally responsible, reasonable, minimally intrusive to winery operations, and adopted only 
if legitimate public goals and established benefits to consumers justify them.  In furtherance 
of those good rulemaking principles, TTB should consider whether it has sufficient information 
and stakeholder input to design and implement new labeling rules  at this time.  We note that 
NPRM 237 poses more than  80 questions and expressly solicits comments on over 45 topics 
that range from general to specific.   That leaves many  of the issues subject to change  and 
creates a challenge for stakeholders to provide sufficient information and data in the time 
provided.  G iven that NPRM 237 constitute s a “significant regulatory action”  if adopted, it is 
important that the issues are fully vetted and TTB  is fully informed before deciding whether or 
how to proceed. 
 
Cost Burden Falls Unevenly on Wine 
It is appropriate that TTB is required to design regulations, including this proposed regulation, 
in the most cost-effective , least burdensome  manner while still achieving the intended 
regulatory objective.  We applaud TTB for seeking industry input in attempting to accurately 
estimate the costs, however, we are concerned that TTB ’s cost analysis does not fully reflect 
the likely fiscal impact on the nation’s 17,000+ wineries.  
 
TTB’s analysis of the cost impact on wineries is based in large part on NielsenIQ data including 
an estimate of the number of universal product codes (UPCs) associated with wines in the US 
marketplace.  We are very concerned that focusing on UPCs  may vastly undercount the 
number of wine labels that this proposal would require to be changed.  Many wine labels do 
not include a UPC  because thousands of wineries rely on non-traditional sales channels 
including direct-to-consumer (DTC) sales and winery tasting room sales  where a UPC is not 
needed.  DTC wine sales are a unique and important feature of the wine marketplace now that 
48 states and the District of Columbia allow some form of DTC wine sales.  Wine analytics firm, 
bw166, has done research showing that Nielsen/NIQ data represents only 54 percent of all tax 
paid volume entering the US wine market in 2024.
1  
 
If TTB’s analysis does  not appropriately account for the gaps in the data it is using , then it is 
likely that its analysis grossly underestimates the potential costs for wineries.   We are 
concerned this analysis undercount s the thousands of wines that do not reach consumers 
through traditional distribution and retail channels  and thus are not accounted for in the 
Nielsen data.  Between 2018 and 2024, TTB approved an average of 113,536 COLAs for wine 
per year.  In recent years, TTB has also expanded the list of items that may be revised on wine 
labels without the need to resubmit a new COLA application.  This list now includes forty 
different pieces of information that can be changed without the need for a new COLA which 
suggests that many COLAs may be active in the marketplace for multiple years  (if not many 
years).  As a result, bw166 estimates that there are between 300,000 and 400,000 distinct wine 
products for sale in the US at any given time  and which would require a newly designed label  
 
1 https://www.bw166.com/data-science-services/  Page 3 of 10  
as a result of this proposed regulation. 2  The sheer size and diversity of the wine marketplace 
means the cost of this proposal would be significant for wineries of all sizes. 
 
We also note that as presented in NPRM 237, TTB’s cost analysis demonstrates that the cost 
burden of the proposal will fall disproportionately on wine producers.  Table 4 shows that with 
a five-year compliance period, fully 49 percent  of the total cost of the proposal would fall to 
wineries, while spirits and beer producers would face half the cost  of wineries.  Yet when TTB 
estimates the number of Total Units in the marketplace in Table 1, wine constitutes only 18  
percent of the Total Units. Wine Institute is very concerned about the impact this uneven cost 
burden will have on the t housands of small and medium sized wineries in the US.  We are 
continuing to review TTB’s cost analysis and seek input from our winery members on the 
anticipated costs of this proposal and will be sharing that information with TTB when available. 
 
2. Wineries Should be Allowed to Provide Serving Facts Information by Electronic 
Means (e.g., QR Codes) 
 
In NPRM 237, TTB explains  that it considered but is not proposing to allow the Serving Facts 
panel to be distributed by electronic means via a link, code, or other marking on the physical 
label.  Instead, TTB proposes requiring the full panel to appear on the physical label, but it also 
sought comments about its assumptions on this topic. 
 
Established Benefits of Permitting QR Codes 
Permitting the use of electronic means —such as a Quick Response ( QR) code—to present 
Serving Facts would provide many be nefits to many  stakeholders including consumers, 
producers, retailers, and regulators.  In NPRM 237, TTB recognized some of the benefits.  They 
included cost -efficiency, flexibility, reduction in time -to-market, and the ability to present 
relevant information in a more consumer -friendly format that is away from overcrowded 
physical labels.  There are other benefits, however, including: 
 
• Translation of e-label content into the language of the consumer  in real time, which is 
not possible using physical labels.   This is already used to comply with the E uropean 
Union’s (EU) labeling requirements for wine—which permits mandatory nutrition and 
ingredient information via QR code—given the EU’s 24 official languages. 
• Enhanced accessibility via new audio technologies for the visually impaired.
3 
• Reduced waste, consistent with industry sustainability goals, since the use of e-labels 
reduces label re-prints. 
 
 
 
2 https://www.bw166.com/2025/07/28/tariffs-pricing-and-volume/  
3 See, e.g., Blind Welfare Society, available at  https://blindwelfaresociety.in/blogs/innovative-food-packaging-solutions-
making-food-more-accessible-for-the-visually-impaired (“QR codes can link to audio descriptions when scanned with 
a smartphone.  This feature can provide detailed information about the product, including ingredients, cooking 
instructions, and dietary information.”) ; see also, BBC News, The codes helping visually -impaired people shop, 
available at https://www.bbc.com/news/business-57679943. Page 4 of 10  
QR Codes in the Marketplace 
Electronic means such as QR codes are already common in the marketplace.   For instance , 
in NPRM 237, TTB cited broad implementation of digital labels  for wine  in the EU and the 
benefits electronic information disclosure could have for international trade.   We agree that 
permitting Serving Facts information by electronic means in the US will help harmonize 
approaches, minimize negative trade impacts, and facilitate US wine exports.  
 
The EU is not the only place where mandatory disclosures are permitted exclusively via 
electronic means.   For example, the US Department of Agriculture (USDA) permits products 
that are subject to the National Bioengineered Food Disclosure Standard to provide the 
mandatory bioengineered symbol via QR code rather than on the physical label.
4  Likewise, in 
2023 amendments to the California Beverage Container Recycling and Litter Reduction Act , 
the Legislature made clear that the Department of Resources Recycling and Recover y “may 
require that a beverage container intended for sale in the state be … marked with a scan code, 
a quick response (QR) code, or a universal product code or similar machine-readable indicia” 
when providing the mandatory California Redemption Value or “CRV” mark rather than 
printing or embossing it on the container.5 
  
Notably, GS1—the international global standards organization for developing and maintaining 
barcodes—is working toward what it calls Sunrise 2027.  That is the year by which the global 
supply chain (manufacturers and retailers ) will move toward “two-dimensional barcodes ” 
(e.g., QR codes) .  According to GS1, b y the end of 2027, retailers w ill need to ensure their 
point-of-sale systems are equipped with scanners capable of reading both traditional 
barcodes and 2D barcodes.  The shift has already begun with the new technology being tested 
in 48 countries across the world.  In short, QR codes will become more ubiquitous, common 
and familiar to consumers, and accessible as manufacturers and retailers make this shift in 
the coming years. 
 
QR Code Accessibility 
As a related point, it is critical for TTB to consider the direction and pace at which technologies 
are trending along with consumer access, familiarity, and preferences.  For example, in NPRM 
237, TTB references a 2023 survey that the Pew Research Center conducted .  TTB notes the 
survey found that “79 percent of adults with annual incomes less than $30,000 owned 
smartphones compared to 90-98 percent of higher income groups.”  The same survey data for 
2024, however,  shows that 84 percent of adults with annual incomes less than $30,000 
reported owning smartphones.
6  That is a five percent increase over just one year.  Pew’s 2024 
survey data also shows that nine out of ten (91 percent) Americans now own a smartphone. 
 
Other information at the inter section of technology, consumer products, and public policy  
demonstrates that  QR codes and other electronic means  of conveying information are 
 
4 See 7 CFR 66.100(b)(3). 
5 See California Public Resources Code section 14561(d). 
6 See Pew Research Center, Mobile Fact Sheet, available at https://www.pewresearch.org/ internet/fact-sheet/
mobile. Page 5 of 10  
increasingly feasible, accept ed, and effective .  The Information Technology and Innovation 
Foundation issued a report in 2022 in which it found that (1) US mobile coverage is 
“ubiquitous,” (2) 4G covers “almost 100 percent of the population,” and (3) “improved fixed 
wireless and low-earth orbit satellites are emerging to fill the remaining gaps” over the coming 
years.7  According to GS1, recent survey data showed that 79 percent of consumers are more 
likely to purchase products with a scannable barcode/QR code (via smartphone) that provides 
the additional product information that they would want to see.8  That number will likely grow 
as QR codes become more common. 
 
Wine Labels Already Contain Other Mandatory Information on Limited Space 
Due to bottle sizes , wine labels are often mere inches  tall and wide .  Some label suppliers 
identify 3.5 x 4 inches as  the “common” or “traditional” size for the front label on a standard 
750 milliliter wine bottle.  Back labels are often  smaller.  In sum, there is limited space  to 
provide information.  That is important to note because physical labels are already subject to 
various federal and state laws that strictly prescribe what wine label s must include, may 
include, and may not include.  Below are non-exhaustive lists with some examples: 
 
• Wine label s must include: a government health warning; brand name; producer, 
bottler, or (if applicable) importer name and address; class or type designation; 
alcohol content statement; sulfite declaration (if present at 10 or more parts per 
million); net contents; color ingredient disclosures (if applicable);  an appellation of 
origin in certain circumstances; and, as a practical reality, a barcode.
9   
• Wine labels may include: a vintage date, winegrape variety, the term “estate bottled,” 
appellation of origin or approved American Viticultural Area, certification claims (if 
applicable), and other descriptive information that consumers desire including tasting 
and sensory notes, food pairing suggestions, recognizable trademarks, or information 
about the winery, winemaker, and winemaking process.
10 
• Wine labels may not include:  any statement that is false or untrue in any particular, or 
that, irrespective of falsity, directly, or by ambiguity, omission, or inference, or by the 
addition of irrelevant, scientific or technical matter, tends to create a misleading 
impression; that is  disparaging of a competitor's products; or any statement, design, 
device, or representation which is obscene or indecent; and more.
11 
 
In addition, labeling laws often dictate not only the  substance of what must or may be 
included on a label, but other details like the specific placement, font type, and font size used 
on labels.  Finally, wines set for export must comply with labeling regimes in the destination 
market.  As noted, this means US wines exported to the EU may use a QR code on the physical 
label to provide mandatory nutrition and ingredient information,  and—given there are 24

8 See id.; see also https://www.gs1us.org/content/dam/gs1us/documents/who-we-are/about-us/How-Product-
Data-Influences-Shoppers.pdf.  
9 See, generally, Wine Labeling: Checklist of Mandatory Labeling Information.

11 See, generally, 27 CFR 4.39. Page 6 of 10  
official languages across the EU—many US wineries use this solution that EU lawmakers 
provided. 
 
In sum, if TTB imposes mandatory provision of Serving Facts, it should permit the use of QR 
codes or other electronic means to disclose that information as an alternative to printing it on 
labels. 
 
3. The Title of the Proposed Panel Should Remain as “Serving Facts” 
 
The current voluntary rules for disclosing nutritional information use the title “Serving Facts”  
and have since those rules initially issued in 2013.  In NPRM 237, TTB proposes now using the 
title “Alcohol Facts” but also seeks input on whether it should continue using “Serving Facts” 
instead. 
 
If TTB imposes mandatory provision of Serving Facts, it should continue using the title “Serving 
Facts” for several reasons.  The most obvious reason is consistency.   Again, since 2013, TTB 
has permitted the optional disclosure of the same nutritional information proposed in NPRM 
237 but under title “Serving Facts.”  That title is what consumers, producers, and retailers 
have come to know not only on labels but also websites and product fact sheets.  Changing 
that title after years of continued use will lik ely cause confusion.  Moreo ver, it is misleading 
and confusing to use the title “Alcohol Facts” when most of the information in the proposed 
panel has nothing to do with alcohol.  Instead, it presents information about serving size, 
servings per container, and respective amounts of calories, carbohydrates, fat, and protein 
per serving.  Finally, “Serving Facts” is sufficiently distinct from FDA’s “Nutrition Facts” title 
and thus avoids any confusion with beverages that do not contain alcohol.  The title sho uld 
remain as “Serving Facts.” 
 
4.  An Implementation Period of Five Years is Reasonable and Necessary 
 
TTB proposes a compliance date of five years from when a final rule is published in the Federal 
Register.  If TTB  imposes mandatory Serving Facts labeling , we strongly agree with the  
proposed five-year compliance period and with TTB’s sound reasons for proposing  it.  Five 
years would allow businesses to exhaust existing label stocks and prepare for new labeling 
processes which will help minimize —but not eliminate—financial and operation burdens.  It 
would allow ample time for public and stakeholder education  and regulatory guidance .  It 
would also allow time to align other resources like product fact sheets, websites, and 
advertising materials and ensure compliance.  Finally, as TTB noted in NPRM 237, five years is 
within the t ypical cycle for food and beverage products to relabel according t o an  FDA 
regulatory impact analysis for a food labeling rule.
12 
 
12 U.S. Food and Drug Administration, Regulatory Impact Analysis for Final Rules On: “Food Labeling: Revision of 
the Nutrition and Supplement Facts Labels” and “Food Labeling: Serving Sizes of Foods That Can Reasonably Be 
Consumed at One Eating Occasion; Dual -Column Labeling; Updating, Modifying, and Establishing Certain 
Reference Amounts Customarily Consumed; Serving Size for Breath Mints; and Technical Amendments,” 2016, 
available at https://www.fda.gov/media/98712/download. Page 7 of 10  
 
5. Proposed Serving Size and Servings Per Container Should be Maintained 
 
TTB proposes including a serving size of 2.5 fluid ounces for wines with above 16 to 24 percent 
Alcohol by Volume (ABV) and 5 fluid ounces for wines with 7 to 16 percent ABV.   TTB also 
proposes including the number of servings per container.  We consider the proposed serving 
sizes and a servings per container disclosure to be reasonable,  familiar to consumers , and 
consistent with what is used under the current voluntary rules and therefore appropriate to 
use if TTB imposes mandatory provision of Serving Facts. 
 
6.  A Single Alcohol Content Statement Expressed as ABV is Appropriate 
 
TTB proposes including an alcohol content statement—expressed as ABV per serving—for all 
wines including for those with 7 to 16 percent ABV and, underneath, a statement of alcohol 
content in fluid ounces of pure alcohol per serving.   
 
If TTB imposes mandatory provision of Serving Facts , it should require only one alcohol 
content statement expressed as ABV and not  require a statement in fluid ounces of pure 
alcohol per serving.  For many decades, ABV has been the near universal means for disclosing 
alcohol content for wines.  This is true in  the US and many parts of the world.  As a result, 
consumers are already familiar with and understand how to interpret ABV levels in wines.   
 
This consumer acceptance of ABV labeling is reflected not only in the US’s current labeling 
regulations but also in multiple trade agreements to which the US is a party.   The World Wine 
Trade Group Agreement on Requirements for Wine Labeling specifies that all parties must 
accept alcohol content labeling by volume (ABV).
13  Additionally, the US -Mexico-Canada 
Agreement (USMCA) includes a similar provision in Annex 3-C which also requires the parties 
to permit alcohol content labeling by volume. 14  In neither case do these agreements require 
or permit alcohol content labeling by other measures such as fluid ounces.  Likewise, the 
International Organization of Vine and Wine (OIV), in its International Standard for the Labeling 
of Wines, also includes alcohol strength expressed as a percentage of volume (ABV) as an 
item of compulsory information.
15 
 
ABV is what consumers know and understand.  A lcohol content expressed as ABV has long 
since been required for wines above 16 percent ABV and voluntarily used for most wines that 
are 7 to 16 percent ABV.  It is also used on spirits and malt beverages.   Thus, if  TTB adopts 
mandatory provision of ABV within the Serving Facts panel , that single disclosure should 
suffice and it should not also be required elsewhere on the label.   Wine Institute urges that  
TTB not require a statement in fluid ounces of pure alcohol per serving.   Unlike ABV, 
consumers are  unfamiliar with alcohol statements  in the form of fluid ounces and thus it  
 
13 https://www.wwtg.gov/assets/uploads/labelling-agreement.pdf. 
14 https://ustr.gov/sites/default/files/files/agreements/FTA/USMCA/Text/03_Agriculture.pdf . 
15https://www.oiv.int/sites/default/files/publication/202503/OIV%20Wine%20Labelling%20Standard%20EN_20
25%20complet.pdf. Page 8 of 10  
would cause confusion.  The fact that it would be presented in addition to ABV, would only 
compound the likelihood for confusion.  The ABV statement provides all that an interested 
consumer needs to determine how much alcohol they are consuming and in a familiar and 
common form.  
  
Likewise, ABV information will provide uniform labeling of alcohol content that will assist 
taxpayers in complying with their obligations under the Internal Revenue Code and will assist 
TTB in identifying alcohol beverage products that pose compliance risks .  Those are reasons 
TTB cites for proposing alcohol content labeling.  Also requiring a statement in fluid ounces of 
pure alcohol per serving  will have no added benefit .  Instead, it will potentially cause 
confusion and burden businesses. 
As a final point, requiring a statement in fluid ounces of pure alcohol per serving  could invite 
misleading and deceptive claims since it presents a number that appears lower than ABV and 
in a form that is unfamiliar to consumers (e.g., “Just 0.7 fluid ounces of alcohol!”).  TTB should 
avoid that problem by requiring only one alcohol content statement expressed as ABV .  It 
should not require a statement in fluid ounces of pure alcohol per serving. 
 
7.  TTB Should Consider Several Points Regarding Calories, Carbohydrate, Fat, 
Protein, and Sugar 
 
TTB proposes mandatory disclosure of calories  per serving, and carbohydrates, fat, and 
protein in grams per serving.  For sugar, the Serving Facts panel may express the number of 
total sugars in grams per serving.   
 
If TTB imposes mandatory provision of Serving Facts, requiring the amounts of calories, 
carbohydrates, fat, and protein in the Serving Facts panel does not present serious concerns 
for our members aside from those raised elsewhere in our comments (e.g., permitting 
provision via electronic means  like a QR code ).  That said, there are at least three important 
points that TTB should consider: 
• For carbohydrates, Wine Institute has  repeatedly expressed concern s about 
inaccuracies of the “by difference” method that TTB and FDA use for calculating 
carbohydrates in wine.  The “by difference” method as described by Merrill and Watt in 
the USDA publication, Energy Value of Foods: Basis and Derivation. Agriculture 
Handbook No. 74 (Merrill & Watt, 1973) is not accurate for wine.  TTB should work with 
FDA to permit the use of the more  accurate “quantitation and summation of sugars” 
approach as an approved method for calculating total carbohydrate content in wine 
and wine-based beverages. 
• In general, fat and protein amounts in wine will almost always be zero. 
• In general, California law prohibits the addition of sugar to wine.
16 
TTB should consider those points and perhaps seek further stakeholder input before imposing 
mandatory provision of Serving Facts. 
 
16 See Cal. Code Regs. tit. 17, § 17010. Page 9 of 10  
 
8. The Proposed Rules for Tolerances, Typical Values, and Format and Placements 
Options Should be Maintained 
TTB proposes an objective standard,  which allows a tolerance of 20 percent either above or 
below the labeled amount for calories, carbohydrates, protein, and fat.  TTB believes these 
proposed tolerances would facilitate the use of “typical values” charts and other 
methodologies to calculate the level of calories, carbohydrates, fat, and protein in alcohol 
beverage products.   
If TTB imposes mandatory provision of Serving Facts, we agree with the proposed “objective 
standard” tolerance of 20 percent and the continued ability to use “typical values” to calculate 
calories, carbohydrates, fat, and protein.  Doing so will help allev iate some of the cost, 
operational, and other burdens—including the need for repeated and expensive testing—while 
still providing adequate information.  We note, however, that most wines have very little or no 
fat or protein.  Consequently, if a winery nee ds to declare a non-zero level (e.g. less than 0.5 
grams per serving for fat and/or protein), a 20 percent tolerance level may be insufficient and 
indeed may be below the level of measurement uncertainty associated with the analytical 
method used.  We recommend that for low levels (e.g. less than one gram per serving) that an 
absolute level be used as the specified tolerance rather than a percent  of the declared value.  
This concept is already used in other markets.  As an example, in the EU for declared le vels of 
carbohydrates, protein, and fat in food that are under 10  grams/100 grams in concentration, 
the allowed tolerances are expressed in absolute terms (i.e., +/- 2 grams for carbohydrates and 
protein, and +/- 1.5 grams for fat).
17 
If TTB imposes mandatory provision of Serving Facts, we agree with its proposal to permit much 
needed flexibility in terms of format (e.g., panel or linear) and placement  (e.g., horizontal or 
vertical).  Likewise, we agree with TTB’s  proposal that if Serving Facts becomes  mandatory, it 
will not require industry members to submit new C ertificate of Label Approval applications 
when the only change being made to a label is the inclusion, or alteration, of a required Serving 
Facts panel or statement containing alcohol content information.  These important and flexible 
elements will help alleviate some of the cost and operational burdens on wineries and provide 
flexibility to decide what works best for their products.   We reiterate, however, that the best 
solution is to permit the provision of mandatory information via electronic means (QR codes) 
for the many reasons stated above. 
***

nutrition -vitamins_minerals-guidance_tolerances_1212_en.pdf.  Page 10 of 10  
In closing, Wine Institute thanks TTB for the opportunity to comment on the issues raised in 
NPRM 237.  We would be pleased to respond to any  follow-up questions that TTB might have 
concerning our comments. 
 
Thank you for your consideration. 
 
Robert P. Koch  
 
 
 
 
President & CEO

RE: Docket No. TTB-2025-0002, Notice No. 237: Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of 
Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages  
 
Dear Ms. Greenberg, 
 
Wine Institute is the public policy advocacy association representing over 1,000 California 
wineries and affiliated businesses.  Our membership consists of wineries of all sizes including 
many small, family-owned wineries.  California is responsible for more than 81 percent of the 
nation’s wine production and more than 95 percent of US wine exports.   W e provide the 
following comments in response to Notice of Proposed Rulemaking No. 237: Alcohol Facts 
Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages (NPRM 237). 
 
In general, Wine Institute supports the current “Serving Facts” framework as voluntary.  If TTB 
imposes mandatory Serving Facts labeling, we respectfully request a similar framework but 
with several important recommendations and considerations that we outline below.   
 
1. Wine is Unique—it is not a Recipe Product—and Wineries Vary Greatly in Size 
 
It is important to note at the outset that wine is u nique.  Wine is not a recipe product.  Unlike 
other beverages, wine is inherently tied to its place of origin.  Every vintage is different, and 
each wine varies by year, winegrape varietal, location, climate and growing conditions.   
Because the winemaking process is dynamic and highly variable, decisions impacting 
nutritional content can be made right up to the time of blending and bottling.  This is significant 
because wine labels are most often printed many months in advance of bottling and changes 
to those labels can take up to two years to implement. 
Beyond the vineyard and winery, the wine marketplace is also distinct in terms of both the 
number of producers and unique wines available.   According to TTB, there are currently more 
than 17,500 bonded wine producers across the US  and approximately 6,300 of them are in 
California.  Like our membership, the overwhelming majority of these are small, family-owned 
Page 2 of 10  
wineries that operate in a heavily regulated industry with correspondingly high cost s in 
establishing and maintaining their businesses.  Therefore, it is critical that any new regulations 
be fiscally responsible, reasonable, minimally intrusive to winery operations, and adopted only 
if legitimate public goals and established benefits to consumers justify them.  In furtherance 
of those good rulemaking principles, TTB should consider whether it has sufficient information 
and stakeholder input to design and implement new labeling rules  at this time.  We note that 
NPRM 237 poses more than  80 questions and expressly solicits comments on over 45 topics 
that range from general to specific.   That leaves many  of the issues subject to change  and 
creates a challenge for stakeholders to provide sufficient information and data in the time 
provided.  G iven that NPRM 237 constitute s a “significant regulatory action”  if adopted, it is 
important that the issues are fully vetted and TTB  is fully informed before deciding whether or 
how to proceed. 
 
Cost Burden Falls Unevenly on Wine 
It is appropriate that TTB is required to design regulations, including this proposed regulation, 
in the most cost-effective , least burdensome  manner while still achieving the intended 
regulatory objective.  We applaud TTB for seeking industry input in attempting to accurately 
estimate the costs, however, we are concerned that TTB ’s cost analysis does not fully reflect 
the likely fiscal impact on the nation’s 17,000+ wineries.  
 
TTB’s analysis of the cost impact on wineries is based in large part on NielsenIQ data including 
an estimate of the number of universal product codes (UPCs) associated with wines in the US 
marketplace.  We are very concerned that focusing on UPCs  may vastly undercount the 
number of wine labels that this proposal would require to be changed.  Many wine labels do 
not include a UPC  because thousands of wineries rely on non-traditional sales channels 
including direct-to-consumer (DTC) sales and winery tasting room sales  where a UPC is not 
needed.  DTC wine sales are a unique and important feature of the wine marketplace now that 
48 states and the District of Columbia allow some form of DTC wine sales.  Wine analytics firm, 
bw166, has done research showing that Nielsen/NIQ data represents only 54 percent of all tax 
paid volume entering the US wine market in 2024.
1  
 
If TTB’s analysis does  not appropriately account for the gaps in the data it is using , then it is 
likely that its analysis grossly underestimates the potential costs for wineries.   We are 
concerned this analysis undercount s the thousands of wines that do not reach consumers 
through traditional distribution and retail channels  and thus are not accounted for in the 
Nielsen data.  Between 2018 and 2024, TTB approved an average of 113,536 COLAs for wine 
per year.  In recent years, TTB has also expanded the list of items that may be revised on wine 
labels without the need to resubmit a new COLA application.  This list now includes forty 
different pieces of information that can be changed without the need for a new COLA which 
suggests that many COLAs may be active in the marketplace for multiple years  (if not many 
years).  As a result, bw166 estimates that there are between 300,000 and 400,000 distinct wine 
products for sale in the US at any given time  and which would require a newly designed label

as a result of this proposed regulation. 2  The sheer size and diversity of the wine marketplace

We also note that as presented in NPRM 237, TTB’s cost analysis demonstrates that the cost

2. Wineries Should be Allowed to Provide Serving Facts Information by Electronic

In NPRM 237, TTB explains  that it considered but is not proposing to allow the Serving Facts 
panel to be distributed by electronic means via a link, code, or other marking on the physical 
label.  Instead, TTB proposes requiring the full panel to appear on the physical label, but it also

Established Benefits of Permitting QR Codes 
Permitting the use of electronic means —such as a Quick Response ( QR) code—to present 
Serving Facts would provide many be nefits to many  stakeholders including consumers, 
producers, retailers, and regulators.  In NPRM 237, TTB recognized some of the benefits.  They 
included cost -efficiency, flexibility, reduction in time -to-market, and the ability to present 
relevant information in a more consumer -friendly format that is away from overcrowded 
physical labels.  There are other benefits, however, including: 
 
• Translation of e-label content into the language of the consumer  in real time, which is 
not possible using physical labels.   This is already used to comply with the E uropean 
Union’s (EU) labeling requirements for wine—which permits mandatory nutrition and 
ingredient information via QR code—given the EU’s 24 official languages. 
• Enhanced accessibility via new audio technologies for the visually impaired.
