comment_text_sources:
[{'source': 'DIRECT (NON-ATTACHMENT)', 'text': "New Belgium Brewing Company, Inc. respectfully submits this comment in response to TTB proposed rule published as Notice No. 237 (Docket No. TTB-2025-0002).

New Belgium Brewing is a leading US premium adult beverage company, known for its iconic portfolio and unique approach to business. Founded in a Fort Collins, Colorado basement in 1991, New Belgium has grown into one of the most successful breweries in the country, expanding into Asheville, North Carolina in 2016, Daleville, Virginia in 2023, and acquired Bell’s Brewery in Kalamazoo, Michigan in 2021. New Belgium is known for producing fan-favorite brands including Voodoo Ranger IPA, Fat Tire Ale, Bell’s Two Hearted IPA, Oberon Ale, an award-winning wood cellar program, and more. Over the past three decades, New Belgium’s Human Powered Business model of caring for people, protecting the environment, and owning our impact has remained consistent, guiding our business practices in all that we do. This ethos continues on today and has enabled us to reach many significant milestones over the past three decades including becoming the first craft brewery to become a certified B Corp still in operation, developing the first carbon-neutral beer in Fat Tire, and much more.\u202f\u202f\u202f

I. Support for the TTB Proposal to Exclude a Small Business Exception

New Belgium agrees with the TTB that there should not be a permanent exemption for small businesses to comply with any new mandatory labeling requirements.\u202f

In addition to the reasoning the TTB presents, New Belgium believes that the practical effects of having a small business exemption would lead to unnecessarily inequitable and anti-competitive results and potentially stifle growth and hiring.\u202f\u202f\u202f

New Belgium and Bell’s combined is currently the largest craft beer producer in the US by volume, yet the company only narrowly exceeds the 1,250 employee threshold to be defined as a small brewery under the SUSB definition.\u202fBased on this, New Belgium is concerned that any small business exemption would result in a majority of craft beer on store shelves excluding any new mandatory label information. It is likely that only New Belgium, and potentially a few other craft brewers, would not be required to provide this information, along with the large brewers who operate mainly outside the craft set.

The anti-competitive effects of an exemption would outweigh any additional costs for small businesses to comply.\u202f Not only would exempt competitors not be required to include nutrition information such as calories per serving, but exempt competitors would be easily identifiable on the shelf as small businesses, when in fact their businesses may be only slightly smaller than those who do not meet the exemption.\u202f Such potential marketing advantages should not be dictated by regulation, particularly when costs to comply with new regulations are minimal.

New Belgium was once a small business, so it understands the challenges faced by small brewers, but equity must also be considered in any mandatory labeling.\u202f There are alternatives to small business exemptions, such as alternative nutrition information calculation processes, that would be less anti-competitive. Therefore, New Belgium agrees with the TTB to not include a small business exemption to any new mandatory labeling requirements.

II. The Proposed “Single Serving Size” Definition Is Likely to Cause Confusion

The proposed serving size with a threshold at 7% alc/vol is likely to cause confusion to craft beer consumers and brewers. Craft beer spans a wide range of alcohol content, typically from 4% alc/vol up to 10% alc/vol, with the higher end of the range often being the distinguishing factor of craft beer from non-craft beer. Using New Belgium’s brands as an example, 7% alc/vol. would split certain products of our brand families with multiple flavors on either side of the proposed 7% dividing line, causing different serving sizes within the family with only minimal shifts in alcohol content. With brand families generally positioned together on retail shelves, consumers would see mismatched information, creating confusion as to alcohol content and any nutrition information, and making it difficult for consumers to compare similar products. Craft beer consumers are familiar with the current disclosures of percentage of alcohol per volume, and New Belgium encourages the TTB to not introduce complicated alcohol content or serving size disclosures that would result in labels that are more confusing to craft beer consumers and brewers.

III. Conclusion

New Belgium agrees with TTB that the goals of the proposal would not be served by treating certain brewers as exempt from mandatory label disclosures. For the above reasons, New Belgium encourages TTB to reconsider the proposed rule on serving size thresholds to limit confusion to craft beer consumers and brewers. "}]
comment_title: Comment 191:  New Belgium Brewing Company, Inc.
comment_text:
New Belgium Brewing Company, Inc. respectfully submits this comment in response to TTB proposed rule published as Notice No. 237 (Docket No. TTB-2025-0002).

New Belgium Brewing is a leading US premium adult beverage company, known for its iconic portfolio and unique approach to business. Founded in a Fort Collins, Colorado basement in 1991, New Belgium has grown into one of the most successful breweries in the country, expanding into Asheville, North Carolina in 2016, Daleville, Virginia in 2023, and acquired Bell’s Brewery in Kalamazoo, Michigan in 2021. New Belgium is known for producing fan-favorite brands including Voodoo Ranger IPA, Fat Tire Ale, Bell’s Two Hearted IPA, Oberon Ale, an award-winning wood cellar program, and more. Over the past three decades, New Belgium’s Human Powered Business model of caring for people, protecting the environment, and owning our impact has remained consistent, guiding our business practices in all that we do. This ethos continues on today and has enabled us to reach many significant milestones over the past three decades including becoming the first craft brewery to become a certified B Corp still in operation, developing the first carbon-neutral beer in Fat Tire, and much more.   

I. Support for the TTB Proposal to Exclude a Small Business Exception

New Belgium agrees with the TTB that there should not be a permanent exemption for small businesses to comply with any new mandatory labeling requirements. 

In addition to the reasoning the TTB presents, New Belgium believes that the practical effects of having a small business exemption would lead to unnecessarily inequitable and anti-competitive results and potentially stifle growth and hiring.   

New Belgium and Bell’s combined is currently the largest craft beer producer in the US by volume, yet the company only narrowly exceeds the 1,250 employee threshold to be defined as a small brewery under the SUSB definition. Based on this, New Belgium is concerned that any small business exemption would result in a majority of craft beer on store shelves excluding any new mandatory label information. It is likely that only New Belgium, and potentially a few other craft brewers, would not be required to provide this information, along with the large brewers who operate mainly outside the craft set.

The anti-competitive effects of an exemption would outweigh any additional costs for small businesses to comply.  Not only would exempt competitors not be required to include nutrition information such as calories per serving, but exempt competitors would be easily identifiable on the shelf as small businesses, when in fact their businesses may be only slightly smaller than those who do not meet the exemption.  Such potential marketing advantages should not be dictated by regulation, particularly when costs to comply with new regulations are minimal.

New Belgium was once a small business, so it understands the challenges faced by small brewers, but equity must also be considered in any mandatory labeling.  There are alternatives to small business exemptions, such as alternative nutrition information calculation processes, that would be less anti-competitive. Therefore, New Belgium agrees with the TTB to not include a small business exemption to any new mandatory labeling requirements.

II. The Proposed “Single Serving Size” Definition Is Likely to Cause Confusion

The proposed serving size with a threshold at 7% alc/vol is likely to cause confusion to craft beer consumers and brewers. Craft beer spans a wide range of alcohol content, typically from 4% alc/vol up to 10% alc/vol, with the higher end of the range often being the distinguishing factor of craft beer from non-craft beer. Using New Belgium’s brands as an example, 7% alc/vol. would split certain products of our brand families with multiple flavors on either side of the proposed 7% dividing line, causing different serving sizes within the family with only minimal shifts in alcohol content. With brand families generally positioned together on retail shelves, consumers would see mismatched information, creating confusion as to alcohol content and any nutrition information, and making it difficult for consumers to compare similar products. Craft beer consumers are familiar with the current disclosures of percentage of alcohol per volume, and New Belgium encourages the TTB to not introduce complicated alcohol content or serving size disclosures that would result in labels that are more confusing to craft beer consumers and brewers.

III. Conclusion

New Belgium agrees with TTB that the goals of the proposal would not be served by treating certain brewers as exempt from mandatory label disclosures. For the above reasons, New Belgium encourages TTB to reconsider the proposed rule on serving size thresholds to limit confusion to craft beer consumers and brewers.
document_title: Notice No. 237:  Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages

comment_text_sources:
[{'source': 'https://downloads.regulations.gov/TTB-2025-0002-0190/attachment_1.pdf', 'text': ' 
AIM Global | 100 Allegheny Drive, Suite 105C| Warrendale, Pennsylvania 15086 USA 
www.aimglobal.org | +1.724.742.4470 | @AIM_Inc_ 
 
August 15, 2025 
 
 
Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau 
Regulations and Rulings Division 
1310 G Street NW, Box 12 
Washington, DC 20005 
 
Re: Docket No. TTB–2025–0002; Notice No. 237 – Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling 
of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages 
 
To Whom It May Concern: 
 
On behalf of AIM we appreciate the opportunity to provide comments on the Alcohol and Tobacco 
Tax and Trade Bureau’s (TTB) proposed rule to require “Alcohol Facts” statements on alcohol 
beverage labels. 
 
About AIM 
AIM is the global industry alliance for stakeholders in Automatic Identification and Data Capture 
(AIDC) technologies, including barcoding, RFID, smart packaging, and connected solutions that 
enable accurate, accessible, and interoperable data. Our members represent all industries and 
applications that depend on trusted product information from manufacturing and supply chain to 
healthcare, retail, and consumer goods. For over 50 years, AIM has advanced the adoption of open, 
international standards to improve data quality, enhance transparency, and empower informed 
decision-making. 
 
Our Position 
AIM strongly supports TTB’s goal of improving consumer access to accurate, standardized 
information on alcohol beverage labels. Transparency is central to consumer trust, and 
standardized labeling built on internationally recognized data formats and identification systems 
ensures that the information provided is not only accurate and readable but also interoperable 
across platforms, supply chains, and digital environments. 
 
We believe that: 
 
• Standardization is essential – Mandatory “Alcohol Facts” labeling should use consistent 
data structures and presentation formats so that the information can be reliably 
understood by consumers, regulators, and digital systems alike. Utilizing recognized 
standards such as ISO/IEC 15459-1:2014 (Information technology — Automatic 
identification and data capture techniques — Unique identification Unique Identifiers) 
ISO/IEC 18004:2024 (Information technology — Automatic identification and data capture 
techniques — QR Code bar code symbology specification) and ISO/IEC 30161-1:2020 (Internet of Things (IoT) — Data exchange platform for IoT services Part 1: General 
requirements and architecture) will help ensure consistency and interoperability. 
• Digital access complements physical labels – Alongside printed information, machine-
readable data carriers (such as standardized barcodes or QR Codes linked to authoritative 
product data) can provide extended content, including multilingual details, allergen alerts, 
and sustainability information. The use of GS1 General Specifications, including GS1 
DataMatrix and GS1 Digital Link standards, will ensure that the “Alcohol Facts” label can 
integrate seamlessly into domestic and international distribution, retail, and e-commerce 
systems. 
• Interoperability enables efficiency – Leveraging established AIDC standards and best 
practices can help industry meet compliance requirements while reducing costs and errors, 
particularly for companies operating across multiple jurisdictions. 
 
AIM’s Offer of Support 
As the recognized authority for AIDC standards and best practices, AIM is willing to assist TTB and 
the industry in developing the technical guidance and frameworks necessary to implement these 
requirements effectively. We can provide expertise on: 
• Selection and application of appropriate data carriers 
• Data encoding standards to ensure interoperability 
• Integration guidance of physical and digital labeling for consumer engagement and 
regulatory compliance 
 
We commend TTB for advancing this initiative and share its commitment to protecting 
consumers, fostering transparency, and supporting fair competition. We welcome the opportunity 
to participate in future discussions or technical working groups that will help ensure the 
successful rollout of standardized alcohol labeling. 
 
 
Sincerely yours, 
 
 
Chuck Evanhoe     Mary Lou Bosco 
Chair, AIM Board     CEO, AIM Global 
President, Aware Innovations   marylou@aimglobal.org 
       724-742-4473

comment_text_sources:
[{'source': 'DIRECT (NON-ATTACHMENT)', 'text': 'RE: Docket No. TTB 2025-0002; Notice 237: Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages

The American Cider Association (ACA) appreciates the opportunity to submit comments on the proposed rulemaking regarding mandatory nutritional, allergen, and ingredient labeling for alcohol beverages. Our association represents more than 1,200 cider and perry producers across the United States—from orchard-based family operations to regional brands selling across multiple states. While our members vary in size and structure, they are unified by their commitment to transparency, craftsmanship, and agricultural tradition.

We support the Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau’s (TTB) goal of modernizing beverage alcohol labeling to ensure consumers have clear, consistent access to information about what they’re drinking. However, we respectfully urge the TTB to consider the operational impact of these changes on small and agricultural-based producers—particularly those in the cider sector.

Nutritional Labeling Requirements
The proposed nutritional labeling requirement presents one of the most significant challenges for small cideries—many of which are closely tied to local agriculture and farm-based production. Cider makers often rely on fruit grown on their own farms or purchased from nearby orchards, supporting agricultural diversity and rural economies. Many producers do not have access to in-house laboratories and would be required to send each product—or in many cases, each vintage or seasonal batch—out for expensive third-party testing. This would be cost prohibitive for many and could discourage the use of varied, seasonal fruit that reflects annual harvest conditions.

We strongly encourage the TTB to adopt a tiered approach to nutritional labeling, including:
- Exemptions or simplified compliance pathways for producers under a defined annual production threshold, similar to the FDA’s model for small food manufacturers.
- The option to provide average or representative nutritional values rather than batch-specific data.
- Permission to disclose nutritional information digitally via QR code — a system that is already accepted under the European Union’s labeling requirements. This approach would promote international regulatory alignment, minimize packaging changes, and allow consumers ready access to accurate product information without imposing undue cost or operational burdens on producers. For limited-release, non-packaged, or taproom-only products, QR codes would allow minimal testing requirements while still meeting transparency goals.

Without such accommodations, the cost and logistical burden of compliance could significantly affect the smallest and most innovative segments of the cider industry—many of which are rooted in agriculture and depend on flexibility to highlight the diversity of fruit from year to year.

Label Flexibility for Small-Batch and Direct-to-Consumer Products
Innovation is a hallmark of the craft cider movement. Many of our members release limited-edition blends, experimental fermentations, or single-varietal ciders in small volumes—sometimes only a few kegs or cases. These products are often sold directly to consumers and are not distributed through traditional retail channels.

For these types of products, we ask the TTB to allow more flexible labeling options, including:
- Universal batch-level nutritional and allergen disclosures available on-premise or online.
- Expanded use of QR codes to communicate required information without relabeling every SKU.

Implementation Timeline and Industry Support
Should these proposed labeling changes be adopted, it is critical that cideries—especially those with limited staffing and infrastructure—are given sufficient time and support to comply. We support the phased rollout of the final rule, with five years of lead time for producers to comply.

In addition, we recommend the development of technical guidance materials, including sample label formats and FAQs. These resources would help ensure that the final rule is not only effective, but also achievable.

Conclusion
We support the TTB’s goal of creating a more transparent and consumer-friendly labeling system across all alcohol categories. At the same time, we believe it is essential to preserve the diversity and accessibility of our industry, which includes many small, regional, and agricultural producers who will be disproportionately affected by these changes.

With thoughtful modifications, this rule can accomplish both goals—empowering consumers and supporting the sustainability of small producers. We appreciate the opportunity to share our perspective and look forward to working with the TTB as this rulemaking process continues.

Sincerely,
Monica Cohen, CEO
American Cider Association'}]
comment_text:
RE: Docket No. TTB 2025-0002; Notice 237: Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages

The American Cider Association (ACA) appreciates the opportunity to submit comments on the proposed rulemaking regarding mandatory nutritional, allergen, and ingredient labeling for alcohol beverages. Our association represents more than 1,200 cider and perry producers across the United States—from orchard-based family operations to regional brands selling across multiple states. While our members vary in size and structure, they are unified by their commitment to transparency, craftsmanship, and agricultural tradition.

We support the Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau’s (TTB) goal of modernizing beverage alcohol labeling to ensure consumers have clear, consistent access to information about what they’re drinking. However, we respectfully urge the TTB to consider the operational impact of these changes on small and agricultural-based producers—particularly those in the cider sector.

Nutritional Labeling Requirements
The proposed nutritional labeling requirement presents one of the most significant challenges for small cideries—many of which are closely tied to local agriculture and farm-based production. Cider makers often rely on fruit grown on their own farms or purchased from nearby orchards, supporting agricultural diversity and rural economies. Many producers do not have access to in-house laboratories and would be required to send each product—or in many cases, each vintage or seasonal batch—out for expensive third-party testing. This would be cost prohibitive for many and could discourage the use of varied, seasonal fruit that reflects annual harvest conditions.

We strongly encourage the TTB to adopt a tiered approach to nutritional labeling, including:
- Exemptions or simplified compliance pathways for producers under a defined annual production threshold, similar to the FDA’s model for small food manufacturers.
- The option to provide average or representative nutritional values rather than batch-specific data.
- Permission to disclose nutritional information digitally via QR code — a system that is already accepted under the European Union’s labeling requirements. This approach would promote international regulatory alignment, minimize packaging changes, and allow consumers ready access to accurate product information without imposing undue cost or operational burdens on producers. For limited-release, non-packaged, or taproom-only products, QR codes would allow minimal testing requirements while still meeting transparency goals.

Without such accommodations, the cost and logistical burden of compliance could significantly affect the smallest and most innovative segments of the cider industry—many of which are rooted in agriculture and depend on flexibility to highlight the diversity of fruit from year to year.

Label Flexibility for Small-Batch and Direct-to-Consumer Products
Innovation is a hallmark of the craft cider movement. Many of our members release limited-edition blends, experimental fermentations, or single-varietal ciders in small volumes—sometimes only a few kegs or cases. These products are often sold directly to consumers and are not distributed through traditional retail channels.

For these types of products, we ask the TTB to allow more flexible labeling options, including:
- Universal batch-level nutritional and allergen disclosures available on-premise or online.
- Expanded use of QR codes to communicate required information without relabeling every SKU.

Implementation Timeline and Industry Support
Should these proposed labeling changes be adopted, it is critical that cideries—especially those with limited staffing and infrastructure—are given sufficient time and support to comply. We support the phased rollout of the final rule, with five years of lead time for producers to comply.

In addition, we recommend the development of technical guidance materials, including sample label formats and FAQs. These resources would help ensure that the final rule is not only effective, but also achievable.

Conclusion
We support the TTB’s goal of creating a more transparent and consumer-friendly labeling system across all alcohol categories. At the same time, we believe it is essential to preserve the diversity and accessibility of our industry, which includes many small, regional, and agricultural producers who will be disproportionately affected by these changes.

With thoughtful modifications, this rule can accomplish both goals—empowering consumers and supporting the sustainability of small producers. We appreciate the opportunity to share our perspective and look forward to working with the TTB as this rulemaking process continues.

Sincerely,
Monica Cohen, CEO
American Cider Association

[{'source': 'DIRECT (NON-ATTACHMENT)', 'text': 'I support the proposal to require an “Alcohol Facts” label showing alcohol content, calories, and nutrients because it helps consumers make informed choices and promotes transparency.
Requiring alcohol content on all malt beverages, beer, and wine will reduce confusion and make labeling more consistent and consumer friendly.
The 5-year guideline gives all the producers enough time to adjust and I also agree that clear guidance on serving sizes, nutrient testing, and label formatting will ensure the rule is easy to follow. Overall, this rule is a positive step for consumer information and public health.
'}]
comment_text:
I support the proposal to require an “Alcohol Facts” label showing alcohol content, calories, and nutrients because it helps consumers make informed choices and promotes transparency.
Requiring alcohol content on all malt beverages, beer, and wine will reduce confusion and make labeling more consistent and consumer friendly.
The 5-year guideline gives all the producers enough time to adjust and I also agree that clear guidance on serving sizes, nutrient testing, and label formatting will ensure the rule is easy to follow. Overall, this rule is a positive step for consumer information and public health.

comment_text_sources:
[{'source': 'DIRECT (NON-ATTACHMENT)', 'text': 'Speaking as a consumer and adult beverage producer, requiring yet another government mandated info panel that goes mostly unread is onerous on the producer (lab analysis is very costly) and a time waster for the consumer. The alcohol level is already required on spirits and other adult beverages and requiring a nutrient contents would also be useless for the consumer as the nutritional content is really besides the point.

What would be more useful are policies requiring more transparency by producers: for example, requiring the alcohol content for ALL adult beverages, requiring disclosure of any post-processing additives such as common allergens, colorants, sweeteners, glycerin, etc.

'}]
comment_text:
Speaking as a consumer and adult beverage producer, requiring yet another government mandated info panel that goes mostly unread is onerous on the producer (lab analysis is very costly) and a time waster for the consumer. The alcohol level is already required on spirits and other adult beverages and requiring a nutrient contents would also be useless for the consumer as the nutritional content is really besides the point.

What would be more useful are policies requiring more transparency by producers: for example, requiring the alcohol content for ALL adult beverages, requiring disclosure of any post-processing additives such as common allergens, colorants, sweeteners, glycerin, etc.

comment_text_sources:
[{'source': 'https://downloads.regulations.gov/TTB-2025-0002-0198/attachment_1.pdf', 'text': '1 National Press Building Suite 1300-NPC Washington, DC 20045 August 15, 2025 Submitted by regulations.gov Director, Regulations and Ruling Division Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau 1310 G Street NW, Box 12 Washington, DC 20005 ATTN: Curt Eilers, Regulations and Rulings Division Re: Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages, Notice No. 237, Docket No. TTB-2025-0003, 90 Fed. Reg. 6654 (January 17, 2025) Dear Ms. Greenberg and Mr. Eilers: The National Association of Beverage Importers (NABI) greatly appreciates the opportunity to provide comments on the notice of proposed rulemaking (NPRM) on Alcohol Facts Labeling.1 In the past, the Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau (TTB) has referred to this information as “Serving Facts.” The topic here is more longstanding than simply the Treasury Report on Competition2 cited by TTB. For the past 20 years, TTB has considered the Serving Facts rulemaking and issued an administrative ruling on this topic, along with proposed rulemaking, and nutritional labeling guidance. TTB has a continuing experience with this labeling topic. And as noted during the listening sessions, several public advocacy groups have filed Federal litigation to seek action 1 Prior to the publication of this notice, the Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau (TTB) held two virtual “Listening1 Sessions” on these topics in February 2024, and NABI presented a statement and submitted a written comment at https://www.regulations.gov/comment/TTB-2024-0002-0416 2 This report resulted from President Biden’s Executive Order 14036, Promoting Competition in the American Economy, dated July 9, 2021 at https://www.federalregister.gov/documents/2021/07/14/2021-15069/promoting- competition-in-the-american-economy On August 13, 2025, the President issued an Executive Order that revoked Executive Order 14036 at https://www.whitehouse.gov/presidential-actions/2025/08/revocation-of-executive-order- on-competition/ The Chairman of the Federal Trade Commission applauded this action as “protecting everyday Americans from anticompetitive practices through tailored action, promoting economic growth, and ensuring that American workers benefit from competition for their labor.” at https://www.ftc.gov/news-events/news/press- releases/2025/08/ftc-chairman-applauds-revocation-biden-harris-executive-order- competition?utm_source=govdelivery 2 here and that litigation is stayed (and not dismissed) during the pendency of this current rulemaking. TTB has dealt with rulemaking and administrative rulings on these issues during the George W. Bush, Barack Obama, Donald Trump, and Joseph Biden Administrations. Typically, the regulatory climate of Washington, DC changes with each new Administration. The current Administration has issued several executive orders on the promulgation of new regulations and review of existing regulations to ensure “regulations [are] squarely authorized by constitutional Federal statutes, and to commence the deconstruction of the overbearing and burdensome administrative state.”3 Additionally, the trend of recent United States Supreme Court judicial decisions on review of regulations has changed where agencies now face a higher burden to show that the regulation is authorized by the underlying statute.4 The proposed regulations were published for public comment before the current Administration took office. NABI believes they will face a higher bar of review and clearance by Administration officials and by the Office of Management and Budget (OMB), in particular. Accordingly, NABI’s comments recognize the regulatory climate of the current Administration and the higher bar facing TTB in a judicial review of its regulations. NABI respectfully recommends that the alcohol facts statements regulation remain as a voluntary statement that may appear on a label or is accessible to consumers by a Quick Response (QR) code. Sufficiency of Voluntary Alcohol Facts Statement TTB has dealt with the “Servings Fact”-type label disclosure regulatory considerations through proposed regulations and a TTB Ruling. The proposed Alcohol Facts Statement labeling regulations require the same elements of information as the voluntary Serving Facts label: • Serving Size • Servings per Container • Alcohol by volume 3 Executive Order, dated February 19, 2025, titled “Ensuring Lawful Governance and Implementing the President’s ‘Department of Government Efficiency’ Deregulatory” Initiative.” https://www.whitehouse.gov/presidential-actions/2025/02/ensuring-lawful-governance-and-implementing-the- presidents-department-of-government-efficiency-regulatory-initiative/ Executive Order, dated January 31, 2025, titled “Unleashing Prosperity through Deregulation.” https://www.whitehouse.gov/presidential-actions/2025/01/unleashing-prosperity-through-deregulation/ Presidential Memorandum, dated April 9, 2025,“Memorandum for the Head of Departments and Agencies, Directing the Repeal of Unlawful Regulations” https://www.whitehouse.gov/presidential- actions/2025/04/directing-the-repeal-of-unlawful-regulations/ Executive Order, dated May 9, 2025, titled “Fighting Over Criminalization in Federal Regulations” at https://www.whitehouse.gov/presidential-actions/2025/05/fighting-overcriminalization-in-federal-regulations/ and White House Fact Sheet at https://www.whitehouse.gov/fact-sheets/2025/05/fact-sheet-president-donald-j-trump- fights-overcriminalization-in-federal-regulations/ 4 Loper Bright Enterprises v. Raimondo, 603 U.S.369 (2024) overruling Chevron U. S. A. Inc. v. Natural Resources Defense Council, Inc., 467 U. S. 837 (1984). 3 • Fluid ounces of Alcohol per Serving • Calories • Carbohydrate by grams • Fat by grams • Protein by grams The information may appear in a panel or in a linear display. The current requirements for the voluntary use of the Serving Facts label were issued in TTB Ruling 2013-2, May 28, 2013, V oluntary Nutrient Content Statements in the Labeling and Advertising of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages.5 The current proposed rulemaking seeks comments on whether the Alcohol Facts Statement label should be mandatory information on a label affixed to the container or continue to be voluntary. The proposal also seeks comments on multiple options about the presentation of the label. In this regard, NABI is only commenting on the use of the electronic alternative to communicate the voluntary information to consumers. Mandatory or Voluntary Under the Federal Alcohol Administration Act,6 TTB is authorized to issue labeling regulations that, among other things, will provide “adequate information as to the identify and quality of the products.” TTB has broad discretion in issuing regulations under this standard.7 While the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) is required to issue such food labeling requirements on the nutrient statement under the Nutrition Labeling and Education Act of 1990, TTB is not covered by that law. Accordingly, TTB’s decision to issue the Alcohol Facts/Serving Fact requirement is discretionary. A review of the Supplementary Information on comments submitted previously to TTB opposing the Serving Facts label requirement shows that the singular opposition raised is the potential costs associated with a mandatory requirement. In particular, the burden of these product testing costs on small and medium size importers and producers was noted.8 NABI agrees that this information may be valuable to many consumers and believes that many industry members will include it voluntarily on a label or in a QR code reference. TTB lists a number of steps it has taken to mitigate these costs, such as increased tolerance ranges, use of typicity charts, and the five-year transition period. A pivotal concern is whether making this requirement mandatory will attract or raise concerns in the regulatory approval process which would not arise were the requirement remains voluntary. 5 https://www.ttb.gov/media/72036/download?inline 6 27 USC 205(e)(2). 7 Center for Science in the Public Interest v. Department of Treasury, 797 F. 2d 995 (D.C. Cir. 1986) at https://law.justia.com/cases/federal/appellate-courts/F2/797/995/104822/ 8 See, 90 Federal Register at 6664 (January 17, 2025) 4 In a survey of NABI members, many of the following reasons were cited for keeping the Alcohol Fact Statement voluntary. • The voluntary option has worked. Industry members can present this information if they believe that their consumers want it. • Congress did not enact a specific legal requirement for the Alcohol Facts/Serving Facts label for beverage alcohol unlike other beverages. • The information must be understandable to the consumer. For example, does the average consumer know what a serving size is? It is not explained on the label and the consumer would have to look at a chart in the regulations in order to determine it. Similarly, do consumers understand that the disclosures of quantities are subject to a tolerance of plus or minus 20 percent? • Have the petitioners established and do the past comments show that consumers want all of this information? • Compliance costs are passed along to consumers in higher prices. • The necessary testing is expensive and is recurring. While TTB cites ways to mitigate the costs, do those undercut the value of the information for the consumer? Broader tolerances and typicity charts provide less accurate and more general information to consumers. • Logistical challenges of the global market in these products arise where labeled product enter U.S. to be shipped to another country’s market where that country does not allow the information presented in the same manner as does the U.S. • From a cost perspective, a five-year implementation date still poses economic challenges to new entrants near the effective date or those who enter the business after the effective date. • Quick Response (QR) codes are a good option but still have costs to update and maintain. • V oluntary option is consistent with the Administration’s executive directives that regulations must not be burdensome and must be based on clear statutory authorization. • Importers are currently under economic stress due to the tariffs and this labeling requirement is an additional expense to mandate now. These reasons support maintaining the Alcohol Fact/Serving Facts.as voluntary information. Quick Response (QR) Codes for Voluntary Alcohol Facts Statements are Valuable if Properly Regulated Quick Response (QR) codes are valuable for conveying large amounts of information about a product without cluttering a front, neck, and back label given the limited physical “real estate” on a bottle or other consumer container. NABI supports the use of a QR code. The quality and quantity of additional information that may be given to a consumer via the QR code is enormous and, moreover, the QR code allows this additional information to be updated constantly at a cost to the industry that is far less than a paper label. The QR code gives the industry member the opportunity to include some explanation about the element of information that would not otherwise be available on the limited "real estate" of labels on the bottle or container. Moreover, broad generational 5 acceptance of e-devices and I-phones necessitate their use today. Consumers today look for the QR code on a label as an information resource. There is certain information about the wine, distilled spirits, and beer/malt beverages that must be available to all consumers and appear on a label on the bottle or consumer container. The brand name, class and type of wine or distilled spirit or category of beer, name of the producer and/or bottler, and alcohol content are the elements of information that fall within this category. The alcohol by volume (ABV) content should appear on the label while the additional details provided in the alcohol facts statement could be accessed through the QR code. Finally, as a practical matter, for a country like the United States that has a pre-approval review of labels, how does TTB envision the label specialist reviewing the QR code information? The information on the QR code site would need to comply with the TTB advertising regulations.9 Would the importer have to submit a transcript or copy of all of the information behind the QR code? Given the importer must obtain the certificate of label approval (COLA) and it is possible that the foreign producer will operate the QR code site, the importer will need to monitor the QR code sites that appear on the label. Whatever approach is adopted by TTB, it must be reasonably administrable in order to protect the consumer. Please do not hesitate to reach out with any questions or requests for clarification. NABI greatly appreciates your time on this important public policy decision. Sincerely, Robert M. Tobiassen Robert M. Tobiassen, NABI President 9 TTB Industry Circular 2024-1, Use of Social Media in the Advertising Alcohol Beverages at https://www.ttb.gov/public-information/industry-circulars/ttb-industry-circular-2024-1 '}, {'source': 'DIRECT (NON-ATTACHMENT)', 'text': "NOTE: Regulations.gov would not let me upload this comment letter. Because it exceeds the 5000-character limit, I am pasting part of it here and I have emailed Mr. Eilers and Ms. Greenberg the full letters. Hopefully, Mr. Eilter will be able to put them in the Public Comment folder. Thank you.
National Press Building
Suite 1300-NPC
Washington, DC 20045
August 15, 2025

Submitted by regulations.gov

Director, Regulations and Ruling Division
Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau
1310 G Street NW, Box 12
Washington, DC 20005
ATTN: Curt Eilers, Regulations and Rulings Division

Re: Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages, Notice No. 237, Docket No. TTB-2025-0003, 90 Fed. Reg. 6654 (January 17, 2025)

Dear Ms. Greenberg and Mr. Eilers:

The National Association of Beverage Importers (NABI) greatly appreciates the opportunity to provide comments on the notice of proposed rulemaking (NPRM) on Alcohol Facts Labeling. In the past, the Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau (TTB) has referred to this information as “Serving Facts.”

The topic here is more longstanding than simply the Treasury Report on Competition cited by TTB. For the past 20 years, TTB has considered the Serving Facts rulemaking and issued an administrative ruling on this topic, along with proposed rulemaking, and nutritional labeling guidance. TTB has a continuing experience with this labeling topic. And as noted during the listening sessions, several public advocacy groups have filed Federal litigation to seek action here and that litigation is stayed (and not dismissed) during the pendency of this current rulemaking.

TTB has dealt with rulemaking and administrative rulings on these issues during the George W. Bush, Barack Obama, Donald Trump, and Joseph Biden Administrations. Typically, the regulatory climate of Washington, DC changes with each new Administration. The current Administration has issued several executive orders on the promulgation of new regulations and review of existing regulations to ensure “regulations [are] squarely authorized by constitutional Federal statutes, and to commence the deconstruction of the overbearing and burdensome administrative state.” Additionally, the trend of recent United States Supreme Court judicial decisions on review of regulations has changed where agencies now face a higher burden to show that the regulation is authorized by the underlying statute.

The proposed regulations were published for public comment before the current Administration took office. NABI believes they will face a higher bar of review and clearance by Administration officials and by the Office of Management and Budget (OMB), in particular. Accordingly, NABI’s comments recognize the regulatory climate of the current Administration and the higher bar facing TTB in a judicial review of its regulations.

NABI respectfully recommends that the alcohol facts statements regulation remain as a voluntary statement that may appear on a label or is accessible to consumers by a Quick Response (QR) code.


Sufficiency of Voluntary Alcohol Facts Statement

TTB has dealt with the “Servings Fact”-type label disclosure regulatory considerations through proposed regulations and a TTB Ruling. The proposed Alcohol Facts Statement labeling regulations require the same elements of information as the voluntary Serving Facts label:

•Serving Size
•Servings per Container
•Alcohol by volume

"}]
comment_title: Comment 195:  National Association of Beverage Importers (NABI)
comment_text:
NOTE: Regulations.gov would not let me upload this comment letter. Because it exceeds the 5000-character limit, I am pasting part of it here and I have emailed Mr. Eilers and Ms. Greenberg the full letters. Hopefully, Mr. Eilter will be able to put them in the Public Comment folder. Thank you.
National Press Building
Suite 1300-NPC
Washington, DC 20045
August 15, 2025

Submitted by regulations.gov

Director, Regulations and Ruling Division
Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau
1310 G Street NW, Box 12
Washington, DC 20005
ATTN: Curt Eilers, Regulations and Rulings Division

Re: Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages, Notice No. 237, Docket No. TTB-2025-0003, 90 Fed. Reg. 6654 (January 17, 2025)

Dear Ms. Greenberg and Mr. Eilers:

The National Association of Beverage Importers (NABI) greatly appreciates the opportunity to provide comments on the notice of proposed rulemaking (NPRM) on Alcohol Facts Labeling. In the past, the Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau (TTB) has referred to this information as “Serving Facts.”

The topic here is more longstanding than simply the Treasury Report on Competition cited by TTB. For the past 20 years, TTB has considered the Serving Facts rulemaking and issued an administrative ruling on this topic, along with proposed rulemaking, and nutritional labeling guidance. TTB has a continuing experience with this labeling topic. And as noted during the listening sessions, several public advocacy groups have filed Federal litigation to seek action here and that litigation is stayed (and not dismissed) during the pendency of this current rulemaking.

TTB has dealt with rulemaking and administrative rulings on these issues during the George W. Bush, Barack Obama, Donald Trump, and Joseph Biden Administrations. Typically, the regulatory climate of Washington, DC changes with each new Administration. The current Administration has issued several executive orders on the promulgation of new regulations and review of existing regulations to ensure “regulations [are] squarely authorized by constitutional Federal statutes, and to commence the deconstruction of the overbearing and burdensome administrative state.” Additionally, the trend of recent United States Supreme Court judicial decisions on review of regulations has changed where agencies now face a higher burden to show that the regulation is authorized by the underlying statute.

The proposed regulations were published for public comment before the current Administration took office. NABI believes they will face a higher bar of review and clearance by Administration officials and by the Office of Management and Budget (OMB), in particular. Accordingly, NABI’s comments recognize the regulatory climate of the current Administration and the higher bar facing TTB in a judicial review of its regulations.

NABI respectfully recommends that the alcohol facts statements regulation remain as a voluntary statement that may appear on a label or is accessible to consumers by a Quick Response (QR) code.


Sufficiency of Voluntary Alcohol Facts Statement

TTB has dealt with the “Servings Fact”-type label disclosure regulatory considerations through proposed regulations and a TTB Ruling. The proposed Alcohol Facts Statement labeling regulations require the same elements of information as the voluntary Serving Facts label:

•Serving Size
•Servings per Container
•Alcohol by volume

comment_text_sources:
[{'source': 'https://downloads.regulations.gov/TTB-2025-0002-0203/attachment_3.pdf', 'text': ' 
 
August, 14, 2025.  
 
 
Agency responsible: 
Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau (TTB), Department of the Treasury 
USA WTO TBT Inquiry Point, Email: usatbtep@nist.gov 
 
Subject: Comments on: Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and 
Malt Beverages  
 
To whom it may concern, 
 
I write to you today on behalf of the Mezcal Sustainability Alliance , a strategic collaboration  among 
companies and with institutions in the sector, committed to the sustainable development of Mezcal. Its 
purpose is to  strengthen the identity of the spirit by disseminating good practices, promoting joint 
projects and generating a positive impact on producing communities. With a focus on innovative  
solutions, the Alliance seeks to accelerate change and preserve the artisanal tradition that  defines 
Mezcal.  
 
The Mezcal Sustainability Alliance thanks the TTB  for notifying its proposed regulation to the TBT 
Committee, in compliance with its commitments as a member of the World Trade Organization, in 
accordance with article 2.9.2 of the Agreement, which establishes that notifications of technical 
regulations should occur at a stage where comments can be considered and modifications to the initial 
proposal can be made. 
 
Background 
 
On January 17, 2025, the Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau (TTB) of the U.S. published a 
proposal (Notice No. 237 ) to amend the labeling of wines, distilled spirits, and malt beverages. The 
main objective is to provide consumers with more comprehensive and clear information about the 
alcoholic beverages they consume, similar to the nutrition information found on foods 
 
Key points of the proposal: 
• "Alcohol Facts" Panel:  The creation of a mandatory panel on alcoholic beverage labels is 
proposed, similar to the "Nutrition Facts" panel on foods. This panel would include  alcohol 
content per serving; calories per serving; basic nutrients; standard serving size and number 
of servings per container .  The proposal establishes specific serving sizes for each type of 
alcoholic beverage, which vary depending on their alcohol content.   
• Flexible presentation formats:  The "Alcohol Facts" panel would be presented in different 
formats, adapting to the container size and beverage content. 
 
 
 
 
 
• Compliance Period : A period of 5 years from the publication of the final rule in the Federal 
Register is proposed for producers and distributors to comply with the new requirements. 
 
General comments on the proposal:  
 
Alcohol content 
It is acknowledged that declaring the alcohol content on alcoholic beverage labels is important to 
inform consumers and help prevent harmful consumption. However, expressing this content in fluid 
ounces of pure ethanol per serving is considered unnecessari ly complex and not easily understood by 
the average consumer. Therefore, it is recommended that only alcohol by volume (% ABV) be declared, 
and that this information be allowed anywhere on the label as long as it is clearly visible, without 
requiring placement in a specific panel or format. 
 
Serving and servings per container: 
The proposal aims to standardize the declaration of serving size and number of servings per container 
across all regulated alcoholic beverages, placing this information within the “Alcohol Facts” panel. 
While it is considered essential for consumers to understand how much alcohol is in a container and in 
a standard drink to promote moderation, it is suggested that this information be provided voluntarily. If 
mandated, it should be included through electronic labeling (e.g., QR code, digital platform, or website), 
which would ensure access to relevant information without imposing unnecessary regulatory or 
commercial burdens. 
 
Nutritional information 
 
The proposal seeks to include nutritional information —such as calories, carbohydrates, fats, and 
proteins—within the “Alcohol Facts” panel on alcoholic beverage labels. However, this approach may 
confuse consumers by implying that alcoholic beverages offer  nutritional benefits, which contradicts 
Codex Alimentarius guidelines that prohibit the addition or promotion of nutrients in alcohol. Alcohol 
 
should not be considered a food or nutrient and presenting it as such could mislead consumers into 
viewing it as comparable to non -alcoholic beverages, potentially influencing purchasing decisions 
based on inappropriate criteria. This could divert attention from the health risks associated with alcohol 
consumption and negatively impact public health perceptions. 
 
 
Key Questions from the TTB: 
1. Should TTB’s proposed nutrient content labeling statement be more consistent with the 
Nutrition Facts Label found on foods that are under FDA’s labeling jurisdiction? 
Alternatively, do the differences between alcohol beverages and other foods make it 
unnecessary, or even misleading, to adopt the type of nutrient labeling required on food 
labels that are under FDA’s labeling jurisdiction? For example, would information on the 
percentage of the daily value of the listed nutrients provided by alcohol beverages be useful 
information for consumers? Alternatively, could such statements mislead consumers by 
implying that they may rely on alcohol beverage consumption to satisfy part of their daily 
nutrient requirements? 
 
We believe that requiring the inclusion of the "Alcohol Facts" panel on labels would not provide any 
benefit to consumers, since the objective of alcoholic beverages labeling, from a health perspective, is 
to prevent harmful alcohol use. Therefore, including nutritional information on such beverages could 
create the perception that they have a "nutritional benefit," which could cause confusion among 
consumers. 
 
We consider that this measure, which implies including information on caloric content, sodium content, 
sugar or fat content, among others, can influence the consumer’s perception of alcohol as healthier 
than other products or foods. Therefore, it is extremely risky to combine two health objectives that could 
confuse non -alcoholic beverages with alcoholic beverages, given that the calorie content, sodium 
content, sugar or fat content, among others, and the amount of alcohol, are diff erent elements in the 
consumer's diet and are not comparable. 
 
By its nature, alcohol should not be considered a food or a nutrient, so including the nutrimental 
information on the label of alcoholic beverages can lead to consumer confusion, understanding that 
alcoholic beverages provide nutrients similar to food, and this may influence their purchasing decision 
and favor the consumption of one beverage over another without taki ng into account the amount of 
alcohol that each product contains. 
 
Making this labeling mandatory would also add costs for producers, importers, and distributors, which 
goes against trade agreements such as the Agreement on Technical Barriers to Trade (TBT Agreement) 
of the World Trade Organization (WTO), which prohibits creating unnecessary barriers to international  
trade. However, if the "Alcohol Facts" panel becomes mandatory, we strongly recommend allowing this 
information to be presented digitally (QR codes, websites, etc.). This makes the information accessible 
to consumers without creating unnecessary regulatory and commercial burdens. 
Digital labeling offers many advantages: 
• Unlimited space to inform consumers. 
• Consumer-friendly and easy-to-understand format. 
• Easy updating as regulations change. 
• Effective communication with vulnerable groups (such as young people) about the risks of 
harmful alcohol consumption. 
• Opportunity to create engaging and educational content. 
 
This approach is in line with the "Guidance for providing food information to consumers by using 
technology", which is being developed by the CODEX Alimentarius Committee on Food Labeling. 
Finally, we believe that a gradual implementation period of 5 years would be the best way to implement 
these changes, particularly to give small producers time to adapt their supply chains for distribution in 
the U.S. 
 
2. For greater consistency with the FDA Nutrition Facts Label, should Alcohol Facts statements be 
allowed or required to include other elements (such as sodium and cholesterol) or a further 
breakdown of fat (to include saturated fat and trans-fat)? 
 
As previously noted, the inclusion of expanded nutritional information on alcoholic beverage labels 
could lead consumers to mistakenly believe these products offer nutritional benefits, causing serious 
confusion. Evidence from the Organization for Economic Co -operation and Development (OECD) 
shows that labeling can be an effective tool for informing consumers, but only when the information is 
clear, concise, and relevant. Overloading labels with excessive or complex data may result in confusion 
or misinformation, undermining the goal of providing accessible and useful consumer information. 
 
 
3. Would the inclusion of elements not ordinarily expected to be found in alcohol beverages (such 
as trans-fat and dietary fiber) be useful or potentially misleading? 
 
As previously mentioned, including nutritional information on alcoholic beverages may lead consumers 
to believe these products offer nutritional benefits, causing significant confusion. Specifically, elements 
like dietary fiber could reinforce this misconception, suggesting added health value. Therefore, it is not 
recommended to include any of the nutritional components proposed. Rather than being helpful, such 
declarations could directly mislead consumers and result in misinterpretation. 
 
4. Should TTB allow numerical statements of the vitamin and mineral content of alcohol 
beverages, assuming the product contains vitamins or minerals, or could such a statement create  
an erroneous impression that consumption of the alcohol beverage has nutritional value or other 
health-related benefits? 
 
Including nutritional information on alcoholic beverage labels may lead consumers to mistakenly 
believe these products offer nutritional benefits, causing serious confusion. Specifically, elements like 
dietary fiber could reinforce this misconception by su ggesting added health value. Therefore, such 
information should not be required in any form.  
 
In Mexico, legislation explicitly prohibits alcoholic beverages from referencing any nutritional benefits 
or therapeutic properties. According to Article 308 of the General Health Law, advertising must focus 
solely on product characteristics, quality, and production methods, without implying health or wellness 
benefits. Additionally, Article 307 prohibits associating non -alcoholic food and beverage advertising 
with alcohol consumption or promoting harmful dietary habits, while Article 6 of the Advertising 
Regulation reinforces the ban on attributing preventive, therapeutic, or nutritional qualities to products. 
These declarations, rather than being helpful, could mislead consumers and distort public health 
messaging. 
 
In summary, Mexican legislation is clear in prohibiting the attribution of nutritional properties or health 
benefits that they do not possess to alcoholic beverages. This is because including such declarations 
on labeling could confuse consumers instead of providing useful information. 
 
 
5. How many industry members already provide nutrient content information on labels, in 
advertisements (such as websites), or upon request (for example, to consumers or restaurants)? 
No comments on this topic. 
 
 
6. Do consumers want to see Alcohol Facts labeling on alcohol beverage products? How might 
consumers benefit from such a label? Do consumers have adequate information about the identity 
and quality of alcohol beverages if alcohol beverage containers do not  include Alcohol Facts 
labeling? How do those benefits compare to the costs and regulatory burdens associated with 
such revisions? 
 
The current information on alcoholic beverage labeling is sufficient. The inclusion of the "Alcohol Facts" 
panel would not provide any benefits to consumer s and would generate unnecessary costs and 
regulatory burdens. 
 
 
7. How, if at all, would the new mandatory labeling requirements affect competition in the alcohol 
beverage market? 
  
Making a change in the labels of these products would generate an extra cost for manufacturers, 
importers, and distributors, particularly harming small and emerging businesses. Therefore, if adopted, 
this proposal would create unnecessary barriers to trade in violation of Article 2.2 of the WTO 
Agreement on Technical Barriers to Trade, that establishes that “… technical regulations shall not be 
more trade-restrictive than necessary to fulfil a legitimate objective, taking account of the risks non -
fulfilment would create”. 
 
8. How would the new mandatory labeling requirements affect small businesses and,  in 
particular, new businesses entering into the alcohol beverage marketplace? 
 
The proposed regulation would have a disproportionate impact on international suppliers, especially 
small and new producers. This is due to increased costs associated with additional analyses, packaging 
and labeling modifications, new shipments, and the re structuring of supply chains for the U.S. market. 
This burden could even force some small producers to leave the market. 
 
9. How, if at all, would the new mandatory labeling requirements affect international trade of 
alcohol beverages? Is there any information that should, or should not, be included to align the 
proposed labeling requirements with those of other countries? 
 
To reduce operational costs and improve access to detailed information, electronic labeling is 
recommended. This approach would help avoid trade barriers and harmonize requirements 
internationally, minimizing the impact of new labeling rules on producers and supply chains. 
 
 
Conclusion: 
 
Detailed nutritional labeling on alcoholic beverages may confuse consumers by implying health 
benefits. If required, such information should be provided voluntarily or via electronic labeling to avoid 
regulatory burdens and disproportionate costs, especially for international and small producers. 
 
 
Best regards, 
 
 
 
Rocio Melendrez Ramirez 
Representative 
 
Members of the “Alianza para la Sustentabilidad”: Casa Xipe; Del Maguey Single Village Mezcal; Mezcal Los Danzantes; Mezcal Amarás; Mezcal El Tinieblo; 
Mezcal Júrame; Marqués del Jaral de Berrio; Casa Mezcal Huitzila; Mezcal Amaxak; Promotora y Comercializadora de Destilados SA de CV; Casa Parada 
Mezcal; Santa Fátima; WYN Spirits S. de R.L de C.V./Dos Hombres.  '}, {'source': 'https://downloads.regulations.gov/TTB-2025-0002-0203/attachment_2.pdf', 'text': ' 
From: 
Cámara Nacional 
de la Industria 
Tequilera  
To: Alcohol and Tobacco Tax 
and Trade Bureau (TTB) Subject: 
Comments on: Alcohol Facts Statements in 
the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and 
Malt Beverages 
Docket No. TTB-2025-0002; Notice No. 237 
Notification : G/TBT/N/USA/2182 
 
Agency responsible: 
 
Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau (TTB), Department of the Treasury 
USA WTO TBT Inquiry Point, Email: usatbtep@nist.gov 
 
About the Cámara Nacional de la Industria Tequilera: The Chamber of the Tequila Industry (CNIT – 
for its acronym in Spanish) is the leading voice of the Tequila industry worldwide, championing the 
interests of its members and promoting the responsible production and consumption of Tequila. As 
a globally recognized symbol of Mexico, Tequila has a rich history dating back to the 16th century 
and boasts a Designation of Origin Tequila (DOT) acknowledged by 57 countries. The Tequila 
industry plays a vital role in Mexico's economy, supporting approximately 41,840 agave farmers, 
100,000 distillery employees, and 209 authorized distilleries. 
 
Appreciation Statement: The Chamber of the Tequila Industry extends its sincere gratitude to the 
TTB for the opportunity to submit our comments on this significant matter. We trust that the TTB 
will give due consideration to our perspective and to the potential impact of t his proposed 
rulemaking on the Tequila industry and its supply chain within the United States market. 
 
TTB Proposal on Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, 
Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages 
 
On January 17, 2025, the Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau (TTB) of the U.S. published a 
proposal (Notice No. 237) to amend the labeling of wines, distilled spirits, and malt beverages. The 
main objective is to provide consumers with more comprehensive and clear information about the 
alcoholic beverages they consume, similar to the nutrition information found on foods. 
Key points of the proposal: 
 "Alcohol Facts" Panel: The creation of a mandatory panel  on alcoholic beverage labels is 
proposed, similar to the "Nutrition Facts" panel on foods. This panel would include: 
1. Alcohol content per serving:  Expressed as alcohol by volume (ABV) and as fluid 
ounces of pure alcohol per serving (rounded to the nearest tenth). 
2. Calories per serving: The amount of calories in each standard serving. 
3. Basic nutrients: Includes the declaration of carbohydrates, fats, and proteins. 
4. Standard serving size and number of servings per container:  The proposal 
establishes specific ser ving sizes for each type of alcoholic beverage, which vary 
depending on their alcohol content. For example: 
i. Malt beverages with no more than 7% alcohol: 12 fl oz (355 ml) 
ii. Wines: 
1. 5 fl oz (148 ml) for wines with 7-16% alcohol. 
2. 2.5 fl oz (74 ml) for products with 16% to 24% alc./vol. 
iii. Distilled spirits: 
1. 12 fl oz (355 ml) if they contain up to 7% alc./vol.; 
2. 5 fl oz (148 ml) between 7% and 16% alc./vol.; 
3. 2.5 fl oz (74 ml) between 16% and 24% alc./vol.; and 1.5 fluid 
ounces (44 ml) 
4. 50 ml for 50 ml containers if they exceed 24% alc./vol. 
 
 Flexible presentation formats: The "Alcohol Facts" panel would be presented in different 
formats, adapting to the container size and beverage content. 
 
 
 
 
 
Compliance Period: A period of 5 years from the publication of the final rule in the Federal Register 
is proposed for producers and distributors to comply with the new requirements. 
 
Comments on the proposal: 
 Alcohol content: We view the inclusion of the alcohol content declaration positively, but 
question the necessity of including fluid ounces of ethanol, as this information is not 
considered relevant to the average consumer. In fact, the Official Mexican Standard NOM-
006-SCFI-2012, Alcoholic Beverages -Tequila-Specifications already provides for the 
declaration of the product's alcohol content. 
 Serving and servings per container: The importance of consumers knowing the amount of 
alcohol in each container and each standard serving is recognized. However, it is suggested 
that this information be provided voluntarily or through elect ronic labeling (QR codes, 
digital platforms, websites) to avoid additional costs and unnecessary regulatory burdens. 
 Nutritional information: Including nutritional information (calories, carbohydrates, fats, 
proteins) on alcoholic beverage labels could confuse consumers. It could be interpreted as 
if these beverages have nutritional benefits, which is contrary to CODEX Alimentarius 
guidelines. It is emphasized that alcohol should not be considered a food or nutrient and 
that nutritional information could di stract from the risks associated with alcohol 
consumption. 
Key Questions from the TTB: 
1. Should TTB’s proposed nutrient  content labeling statement be more  consistent with the 
Nutrition Facts Label found on foods that are under FDA’s labeling jurisdiction? Alternatively, do 
the differences  between alcohol beverages and other  foods make it unnecessary, or even  
misleading, to adopt the type of nutrient  labeling required on food labels that are under FDA’s 
labeling jurisdiction? For example, would information on the percentage of the daily value of the 
listed nutrients provided by alcohol  beverages be useful information for  consumers? 
Alternatively, could such statements mislead consumers by implying that they may rely on alcohol 
beverage consumption to satisfy part of their daily nutrient requirements? 
Our position highli ghts that requiring the "Alcohol Facts" panel on labels would not genuinely 
benefit consumers. From a public health perspective, the true objective of alcoholic beverage 
labeling is to discourage harmful alcohol consumption. Including nutritional information on labels 
could easily lead people to believe that these beverages have some sort of health benefit, which 
would only create confusion. Alcoholic beverages simply do not provide nutrients. Putting 
nutritional information on labels could give consumers t he wrong idea, making them think that 
alcohol fits into a balanced diet or offers essential nutrients. This could skew their purchasing 
decisions, distracting them from the most important information: alcohol content. 
Furthermore, it is misleading to compa re alcoholic and non-alcoholic beverages because they are 
fundamentally different. Elements like calories, carbohydrates, sugars, and fats in alcoholic 
beverages simply cannot be compared to normal food, because the key difference is the alcohol 
itself. At tempting to use nutritional labeling (including calories) to prevent harmful alcohol 
consumption could even be counterproductive. It could make consumers perceive alcohol as 
somehow healthy or harmless, potentially leading to worse health consequences than  current 
labeling was trying to prevent. It is risky to confuse non-alcoholic and alcoholic beverages. They are 
distinct products, with distinct target consumers, and should not be presented as comparable. Making this labeling mandatory would also add cost s for producers, importers, and distributors, 
which goes against trade agreements such as the Agreement on Technical Barriers to Trade (TBT 
Agreement) of the World Trade Organization (WTO), which prohibits creating unnecessary barriers 
to international tra de. However, if the "Alcohol Facts" panel becomes mandatory, we strongly 
recommend allowing this information to be presented digitally (QR codes, websites, etc.). This 
makes the information accessible without creating unnecessary regulatory and commercial 
burdens. 
Digital labeling offers many advantages: 
 Unlimited space to inform consumers. 
 Consumer-friendly and easy-to-understand format. 
 Easy updating as regulations change. 
 Effective communication with vulnerable groups (such as young people) about the risks 
of harmful alcohol consumption. 
 Opportunity to create engaging and educational content. 
 
This approach is in line with the "Guidance for providing food information to consumers by using 
technology", which is being developed by the CODEX Alimentarius Committee on Food Labeling. 
Finally, we believe that a gradual implementation period of 5 years would be the best way to 
implement these changes, particularly to give small producers time to adapt their supply chains for 
distribution in the U.S. 
2. For greater consistency with the FDA Nutrition Facts Label, should Alcohol Facts statements be 
allowed or required to include other elements (such as sodium and cholesterol) or a further 
breakdown of fat (to include saturated fat and trans-fat)? 
It is not recommended to include additional information on sodium, cholesterol, or saturated and 
trans fats. The inclusion of more nutritional information could increase confusion and reinforce the 
misconception that alcoholic beverages have nutritional benefits. 
3. Would the inclusion of elements not ordinarily expected to be found in alcohol beverages (such 
as trans-fat and dietary fiber) be useful or potentially misleading? 
The inclusion of items such as trans fats and dietary fiber would not be useful and could be 
misle ading. These elements are not relevant to alcoholic beverages and their inclusion could 
confuse consumers. 
4. Should TTB allow numerical statements of the vitamin and mineral content of alcohol 
beverages, assuming the product contains vitamins or minerals, or could such a statement create 
an erroneous impression that consumption of the alcohol beverage has nutritional value or other 
health-related benefits? 
It is not recommended to include numerical declarations of vitamin and mineral content. This could 
create a misleading  impression that alcoholic beverages have nutritional value, which is not true 
and could be harmful to public health. In Mexico, laws prohibit alcoholic beverages from being promoted with nutritional, therapeutic, or 
rehabilitation benefits. 
The General Health Law, in its article 308, establishes that advertising for these beverages must be 
limited to describing their characteristics, quality, and how they are made, without presenting them 
as something that improves health or well-being. 
Furthermore, article 307 of the same law prohibits advertising for food and non-alcoholic beverages 
from being directly or indirectly related to the consumption of alcoholic beverages, or from 
promoting harmful eating habits. 
The Regulations of the General Health Law on Advertising, in its article 6, reinforces this prohibition 
by establishing that advertising for no product may attribute preventative, therapeutic, 
rehabilitative, nutritional, stimulating, or any other type of quality. 
In summary, Mexican legislation is clear  in prohibiting the attribution of nutritional properties or 
health benefits that they do not possess to alcoholic beverages. This is because including such 
declarations on labeling could confuse consumers instead of providing useful information. 
5. How many industry members already provide nutrient content information on labels, in 
advertisements (such as websites), or upon request (for example, to consumers or restaurants)? 
No comments on this topic. 
6. Do consumers want to see Alcohol Facts labeling on alcohol beverage pro ducts? How might 
consumers benefit from such a label? Do consumers have adequate information about the 
identity and quality of alcohol beverages if alcohol beverage containers do not include Alcohol 
Facts labeling? How do those benefits compare to the cost s and regulatory burdens associated 
with such revisions? 
The current information on alcoholic beverage labeling is sufficient. The inclusion of the "Alcohol 
Facts" panel would not provide significant ben efits to the consumer and would generate 
unnecessary costs and regulatory burdens. 
7. How, if at all, would the new mandatory labeling requirements affect competition in the alcohol 
beverage market? 
This measure would impose excessive costs and regulatory burdens on producers, importers, and 
distributors of alcoholic beverages, particularly harming small and emerging businesses. This would 
go against the spirit of Article 2.2 of the Agreement on Technical Barriers to Trade (TBT Agreement) 
of the World Trade Organization (WTO), which seeks to prevent the imposition of technical 
regulations that unnecessarily restrict international trade, unless there are legitimate objectives 
justified by member states. 
According to the TBT Agreement, technical regulations sho uld not limit trade more than strictly 
necessary to achieve a legitimate objective. Therefore, it is considered that the proposed measures 
would have a disproportionate impact on international suppliers. This is mainly due to the increased 
costs associated  with additional product analyses, modifications to packaging and labeling, new 
shipments, and especially the restructuring of supply chains for the U.S. alcoholic beverage market. 8. How would the new mandatory labeling requirements affect small businesses and, in particular, 
new businesses entering into the alcohol beverage marketplace? 
The proposed regulation would have a disproportionate impact on international suppliers, 
especially small and new producers. This is due to increased costs associated with additional  
analyses, packaging and labeling modifications, new shipments, and the restructuring of supply 
chains for the U.S. market. This burden could even force some small producers to leave the market. 
9. How, if at all, would the new mandatory lab eling requirements affect international trade of 
alcohol beverages? Is there any information that should, or should not, be included to align the 
proposed labeling requirements with those of other countries? 
It is certain that the new labeling requirements would have a negative impact on international trade 
in alcoholic beverages, as they would increase costs and complexity. To avoid this, it is suggested to 
consider harmonizing such requirements with those of other countries, as well as implementing the 
use of tools such as elec tronic labeling, which allows for much more information than physical 
labels, while reducing operational costs. 
Conclusion: Detailed nutritional labeling could confuse consumers, and information about alcohol 
is sufficient. It is proposed that, in any case , nutritional information be voluntary or provided 
electronically. It is reiterated that the implementation of the proposal would generate significant 
costs, especially affecting small and new businesses, as well as international trade in alcoholic 
beverages in general. 
End of the document  '}, {'source': 'https://downloads.regulations.gov/TTB-2025-0002-0203/attachment_1.pdf', 'text': 'On behalf of the Government of Mexico, please find attached the consolidated 
comments of the Mexican alcoholic beverages industry regarding the Alcohol 
and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau’s (TTB) proposal (Notice No. 237) to amend 
the labeling of wines, distilled spirits, and malt beverages, notified
(G/TBT/N/USA/2182) to the WTO TBT Committee in accordance with Article 2.9.2 
of the WTO Agreement on Technical Barriers to Trade (TBT Agreement).
While Mexico recognizes the objective of providing consumers with clear and 
comprehensive information, our industry expresses serious concerns that the 
proposed mandatory “Alcohol Facts” panel—particularly the inclusion of detailed 
nutritional information—could mislead consumers by suggesting that alcoholic 
beverages provide nutritional or health benefits. This approach contradicts 
Codex Alimentarius guidelines, Mexican legislation (General Health Law, Articles 
307 and 308, and its Advertising Regulation), and may distract from the core 
health objective of preventing harmful alcohol consumption.
Furthermore, the requirement to declare alcohol content in both % ABV and fluid 
ounces of pure ethanol per serving is unnecessarily complex and not easily 
understood by the average consumer. Similarly, the proposed mandatory 
declaration of serving size and servings per container would impose 
disproportionate regulatory and commercial burdens, particularly on small 
producers and exporters.
The Government of Mexico therefore strongly recommends that:
1. Nutritional information be provided on a voluntary basis or through
electronic labeling (QR codes, websites, or digital platforms), ensuring
access to relevant information without creating unnecessary barriers to
trade, in line with Article 2.2 of the TBT Agreement.2. Alcohol content be declared exclusively in % ABV, allowing its placement
anywhere on the label as long as it is clearly visible.
3. Implementation be gradual, with a minimum transition period of five (5)
years, to allow producers—particularly SMEs—to adapt their supply chains.
Mexico reiterates that the creation of labeling requirements that may mislead
consumers or impose excessive costs on producers could constitute an
unnecessary obstacle to international trade and have a disproportionate impact
on small and emerging businesses in the alcoholic beverages sector.
We thank you in advance for your kind attention to these comments and
respectfully request that they be duly considered in the elaboration of the final
rule.
Kind regards,'}, {'source': 'DIRECT (NON-ATTACHMENT)', 'text': 'See Attached'}]
